column2: INDIAN PRISONER IN PAKISTAN DIES AFTER BEATING
column3: MULTAN, Pakistan – An Indian man on death row in Pakistan for espionage has died after being attacked by fellow inmates, Pakistan’s state television said early Thursday.

column2: INDIAN PRISONER IN PAKISTAN DIES AFTER BEATING
column3: Sarabjit Singh, 51, died in a hospital in the eastern city of Lahore, where he had been in a coma for at least five days.

column2: INDIAN PRISONER IN PAKISTAN DIES AFTER BEATING
column3: Singh was convicted of espionage in relation to bombings in two Pakistani cities in 1990.

column2: INDIAN PRISONER IN PAKISTAN DIES AFTER BEATING
column3: His fate has been a source of tension between Pakistan and India since he was attacked Friday.

column2: INDIAN PRISONER IN PAKISTAN DIES AFTER BEATING
column3: In a statement, the Indian prime minister, Manmohan Singh, said he was “deeply saddened” by Sarabjit Singh’s death, describing him as a “brave son of India.”

column2: INDIAN PRISONER IN PAKISTAN DIES AFTER BEATING
column3: Singh, the prime minister, criticized the Pakistani government’s refusal to repatriate the injured prisoner to India for emergency treatment.

column2: INDIAN PRISONER IN PAKISTAN DIES AFTER BEATING
column3: According to the Pakistani police, Sarabjit Singh was assaulted by two prisoners as he left his cell at Kot Lakhpat jail, outside Lahore, to exercise last Friday.

column2: INDIAN PRISONER IN PAKISTAN DIES AFTER BEATING
column3: He suffered severe head injuries and was later taken to the city’s Jinnah hospital in critical condition.

column2: INDIAN PRISONER IN PAKISTAN DIES AFTER BEATING
column3: Singh’s Pakistani lawyer said that his client had previously spoken of threats from inmates following the hanging of Afzal Guru, an accused Kashmiri militant, by the Indian authorities in February.

column2: INDIAN PRISONER IN PAKISTAN DIES AFTER BEATING

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Jacques Vergès, the French lawyer who embraced anti-colonial causes and the role of devil’s advocate on a world stage to defend war criminals, terrorists, dictators and other notorious villains of the 20th century, died Thursday in Paris.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: He was 88.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: The cause was a heart attack at around 8 p.m. as he was preparing to dine with friends, according to his publisher, Éditions Pierre-Guillaume de Roux.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: He died in the Parisian house where the Enlightenment philosopher Voltaire once lived, the publisher said in a statement.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: “The ideal place for the last theatrical act that was the death of this born actor who, like Voltaire, cultivated the art of permanent revolt and volte-face,” the statement said, reflecting the lawyer’s reputation for asking disturbing questions on behalf of notorious clients.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Is a killer a terrorist or a patriot?

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Can laws be used to judge good and evil?

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: For more than 50 years, Vergès raised such questions in defense of clients who claimed to be acting for political causes, although they were charged with genocide, crimes against humanity, bombings, hijackings and the murder of innocents.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: They included the Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie; the terrorist Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, aka Carlos the Jackal; and Cambodia’s Khmer Rouge head of state, Khieu Samphan.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Vergès also sought to defend former presidents Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who was executed for crimes against humanity, and Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, who represented himself in a war-crimes trial but died before a verdict.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Like many of his clients, Vergès, the son of a Vietnamese woman and a French diplomat, was an enigma.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Assassins targeted him.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: There were hints of ties to secret services, to terrorists he defended and to Mao Zedong, Che Guevara and other revolutionaries.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: He was a confidant of Pol Pot, the tyrant blamed for the deaths of at least 1.7 million Cambodians.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: He married a terrorist he saved from the guillotine, but left her and his two children and disappeared for eight years.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: “He’s a slippery man,” director Barbet Schroeder, who made “Terror’s Advocate,” a 2007 documentary on Vergès and terrorism as a political weapon, told The New York Times in 2007.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: “You can never touch him.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: He loves the mystery.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: The reason is that there are certain things he cannot talk about.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: He would be in deep trouble if the truth came out.”

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: In a career that paralleled the postwar disintegration of colonial empires in Asia, Africa and the Middle East, Vergès rose to prominence in the late 1950s defending Algerians accused of terrorist bombings.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Instead of contesting the evidence of French prosecutors in court, he insisted that the defendants were resistance fighters in a just war of liberation and challenged the legal and moral legitimacy of the trials.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: While most of his clients were convicted, the trials drew international attention to Vergès, and long after Algerian independence in 1962 his tactics served as a blueprint for his cases, which became public platforms to indict France and other Western nations for what he called crimes of racist colonialism and the exploitation of Third World peoples.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: In the late 1960s, Vergès broadened his horizons, defending Palestinians charged with attacks on El Al aircraft in Athens and Zurich.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: He later represented members of the Red Army Faction in Germany, whose bombings he called the work of “soldiers in a noble cause.”

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Vergès’ most famous case was his defense of Klaus Barbie, the wartime Gestapo leader known as “the Butcher of Lyons” for his role in the torture, execution and deportation to death camps of thousands of French citizens.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: After years in hiding, during which he is believed to have assisted Western intelligence services, Barbie was extradited from Bolivia to France in 1983.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: At his war-crimes trial in 1987, Barbie walked out, refusing to hear testimony of his horrors.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Vergès virtually ignored the charges, and attacked Israel, France and other nations for committing “crimes against humanity” that he called “more serious” than those ascribed to Barbie.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Critics said he trivialized genocide to defend a monster.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Barbie was convicted and sentenced to life in prison, where he died in 1991.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: “I practice the 'defense de la rupture,'” Vergès told The New York Times during his work on the Barbie case, meaning a tactic of confrontation with the judicial system rather than one that works within it.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: “My law is to be against all laws.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: My morality is to be against all morality.”

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Jacques Vergès and his twin brother, Paul, were born March 5, 1925, in Ubon Ratchathani, Siam, now Thailand.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Their Vietnamese mother died when they were 3 and their father, Raymond Vergès, a French diplomat, raised them on the Indian Ocean island of Réunion.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Paul became a founder of the Réunion Communist Party and a member of the European Parliament.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: In 1942, with his father’s encouragement, Jacques sailed to England, joined Charles de Gaulle’s Free French Forces and fought in the Resistance.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: After the war, he studied law at the University of Paris, joined the Communist Party and in 1949 became a leader of an anti-colonial student movement.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: His student friends included Khieu Samphan and Saloth Sar, the future Pol Pot.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: In the early 1950s Vergès led a Communist youth organization in Prague.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Returning to Paris, he became a lawyer in 1955 and gained fame defending Algerian guerrilla fighters.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: In a notorious case, Djamila Bouhired was convicted in 1957 of killing 11 people in an Algiers bombing and sentenced to death.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: As she awaited the guillotine, it was revealed that she had been tortured during questioning.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Vergès campaigned for a reprieve.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Many world leaders, including the Soviet leader, Nikita Khrushchev, demanded her release.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Her execution was postponed, and in 1962 she was released.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: In 1965, Vergès and Bouhired were married.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: They had two children, Meriem and Liess.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: The couple founded a popular magazine, Révolution, in 1968.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: In 1970, Vergès disappeared.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: His whereabouts remained a mystery, although he was rumored to be in Cambodia with Pol Pot and in the Middle East with Palestinian groups.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: He reappeared in Paris in 1978 and resumed his law practice.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: His ties to Carlos the Jackal were murky but probably dated to 1982, when he defended Magdalena Kopp, the terrorist’s girlfriend and accomplice (and later his wife), who was caught with explosives in Paris.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Wanted for many terrorist acts in the name of Palestinian liberation in the 1970s and '80s, Carlos was captured by French agents in Sudan in 1994 and flown to Paris.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Vergès called it a kidnapping and represented Carlos in the early stages of his case, but they had a falling out over tactics.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: The Venezuelan-born terrorist hired other lawyers, was convicted in 1997 and sentenced to life in prison.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: The verdict and sentence were affirmed in another trial years later.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: After Saddam Hussein was captured in 2003, Vergès, who had been hired to defend other ousted Iraqi leaders, offered to represent him.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: The family of the deposed Iraqi leader chose another lawyer, and Saddam was executed in 2006.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Vergès also offered to defend Milosevic, but he chose to represent himself in a trial that began in The Hague in 2002.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: Milosevic died in 2006 before the case could be concluded.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: In 2008, as Khieu Samphan made his first appearance before Cambodia’s genocide tribunal, Vergès, representing his old friend, created a tumultuous scene and stormed out after erupting at a panel of judges because documents for the pretrial hearing had not been translated into French.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: He argued that his client had held no real power as Cambodians had died of starvation, disease, forced labor and massacres during the brutal Khmer Rouge drive to create a classless society.

column2: JACQUES VERG È S, DEFENDER OF WAR CRIMINALS AND TERRORISTS, DIES AT 88
column3: He insisted that the power - and responsibility for the Cambodian tragedy - belonged to Pol Pot, who died in 1998.

ISRAELI HOUSING PLAN ADDS TO TENSIONS AHEAD OF TALKS
column3: JERUSALEM - Israel published bids Sunday for the construction of more than 1,000 housing units in contested areas of East Jerusalem and several large West Bank settlements, intensifying the already charged atmosphere three days before the resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks here and hours before Israel was to announce the names of Palestinian prisoners to be released this week.

column2: ISRAELI HOUSING PLAN ADDS TO TENSIONS AHEAD OF TALKS
column3: While the planning and building of settlements have continued in the months preceding the talks, causing constant friction, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s new governing coalition had so far refrained from issuing construction bids since it was formed in March.

column2: ISRAELI HOUSING PLAN ADDS TO TENSIONS AHEAD OF TALKS
column3: The publishing of bids is the final bureaucratic stage before new construction can begin.

column2: ISRAELI HOUSING PLAN ADDS TO TENSIONS AHEAD OF TALKS

column3: The prime minister’s office offered no immediate comment.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: by John Romano,

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: Times Columnist

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: A strict diet, designed for medical purposes, is just part of the deal.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: That includes hiding the salt shaker and steering clear of alcohol.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: Smoking is out of the question, and frequenting the gym whenever your body is agreeable would also qualify as part of the routine.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: When you are waiting on a kidney transplant to prolong your life, you accept certain hassles along the way.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: Ronald Yaffe expected all of that.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: Here’s what he did not expect:

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: A yearlong battle with Wells Fargo concerning $10,000 in cashier’s checks from the 1980s that the bank says it is not obligated to pay.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: ''I’m mad.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: This has gotten personal, and I’m not going to let it go,'' Yaffe said Monday.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: ''Who would ever think that if you give your money to a bank, they won’t give it back to you when you ask for it?''

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: This story begins more than 30 years ago when Yaffe began turning his spare cash into cashier’s checks at Central Fidelity Bank in Richmond, Va., where he was an optometrist.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: The idea, he said, was to have emergency funds to take with him on long sailing trips.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: The checks, totaling $11,800, went unused and Yaffe stashed them in a safe deposit box when he retired to Sarasota a short time later.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: With his medical condition worsening and a transplant or dialysis likely, Yaffe, 73, retrieved the checks last year, figuring his prescription costs would soon skyrocket.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: He deposited the funds in an account, but Wells Fargo soon notified him that the checks were invalid.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: The bank, Yaffe said, told him they could not find the necessary paper trail.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: Central Fidelity was sold to Wachovia in 1998, and Wachovia was acquired by Wells Fargo in 2009.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: The Virginia Department of Treasury found a record for one of the checks in unclaimed funds and sent Yaffe $1,800.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: The agency said the other $10,000 was reclaimed by Central Fidelity in 1987, according to Sarasota’s Herald-Tribune, which originally reported the story.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: That’s when Yaffe took the matter to court, and won a judgment last month for the $10,000 plus interest accrued from the time he tried to deposit the checks.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: Wells Fargo has since filed an appeal, saying Florida law has a five-year statute of limitations on cashier’s checks.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: ''We are abiding by the law,'' said Wells Fargo spokeswoman Kathy Harrison.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: ''The judge in this case elected to ignore the case law that supports it.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: It’s an unfortunate situation, and now that it’s in litigation, there is not much more we can do or say.''

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: Today’s cashier’s checks typically carry disclaimers saying they will be voided if not cashed in a specified period of time, often 90 days or six months.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: Yaffe said there were no time limits written on his checks in 1982.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: Even if the judgment is upheld in appeals, Yaffe says a portion of the $10,000 will go to attorney fees.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: And so a sick man might lose a large chunk of money, and a bank risks looking greedy and coldhearted.

column2: Bank's tight grip on cash is ill-advised
column3: At this point Wells Fargo would be justified if it was worried about setting a legal precedent, but a little compassion a year ago could have avoided the whole mess.

column2: AMERICAN AMONG 3 KILLED IN EGYPT AS UNREST SPREADS
column3: In Cairo, tens of thousands of people took to the streets in competing protests that remained separate, and as a result, largely peaceful.

column2: AMERICAN AMONG 3 KILLED IN EGYPT AS UNREST SPREADS
column3: Anti-government protesters gathered in Tahrir Square, around the Defense Ministry and in front of the presidential palace, which has been ringed with new barriers, including concrete blocks and shipping containers.

column2: AMERICAN AMONG 3 KILLED IN EGYPT AS UNREST SPREADS
column3: Calls for Morsi to resign have intensified as Egypt lurches from crisis to crisis, the most recent one over the endless gas lines that have clogged roads around the country.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: LONDON - Tony Hayward was appointed interim chairman of the mining company Glencore Xstrata on Thursday, almost three years after he resigned as chief executive of BP in the wake of a huge oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: The appointment of Hayward, currently a senior independent director at the company, comes after the departure of Glencore Xstrata’s chairman, John Bond, who failed to receive enough shareholder support at an investor meeting Thursday to retain his position.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: The new role represents a significant turnaround for Hayward, who was widely criticized for his role in the aftermath of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in 2010.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: Since leaving BP, Hayward has become chief executive of Genel Energy, which is exploring for energy reserves in northern Iraq.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: Hayward will step down from his new position at Glencore Xstrata as soon as a new chairman is appointed, according to a company statement.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: The executive shuffle at the top of Glencore Xstrata is the most recent management change after the commodities giant Glencore International completed its $30 billion all-stock takeover of the mining company Xstrata on May 2.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: As part of the deal, Xstrata’s chief executive, Mick Davis, announced that he was leaving the merged company earlier than had been expected, while a number of his top lieutenants have also departed.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: Steve Robson, a company director, announced his resignation Thursday.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: Bond, 71, a former chief executive and chairman of the British bank HSBC, had previously said he would step down as Glencore Xstrata chairman as soon as a successor could be found.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: He had faced anger in November when shareholders voted against multimillion-dollar bonuses that were aimed at retaining some of Xstrata’s senior managers.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: On Thursday, however, Bond, who received less than 20 percent approval from investors to be reappointed chairman, told shareholders he did not have enough support to continue in his role.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: “I recognize and respect the strong opposition among many to the retention arrangements which the board felt appropriate to ensure management stability,” Bond said in a statement, in reference to the vetoed bonuses.

column2: FORMER BP CHIEF EMERGES AS INTERIM CHAIRMAN AT GLENCORE XSTRATA
column3: The changes come as the chief executive, Ivan Glasenberg, has announced plans to reduce costs at Glencore Xstrata.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: RIO DE JANEIRO – The Brazilian police have arrested a businessman listed by the United States as a member of Hezbollah, the powerful Lebanese militant group, under suspicion of operating a fraudulent scheme in the clothing industry – a far cry from the arms, drugs, explosives and counterfeit bills that U.S. officials have suspected him of trafficking in the past.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: Officials with Brazil’s Civil Police said the suspect, Hamzi Ahmad Barakat, 50, a Lebanese citizen with ties to the Triple Frontier region of Brazil, Argentina and Paraguay, was arrested Thursday in the city of Curitiba in southern Brazil in connection with creating a network of front companies to defraud Lebanese immigrants who had recently arrived in Brazil.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: The arrest focuses new attention on the Triple Frontier, a smuggler’s haven that has long been under the scrutiny of intelligence agencies from the United States, Israel and South American nations.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: In 2006, the Treasury Department designated Barakat as a member of Hezbollah and said he owned and managed a store in Paraguay that “served as a source of funding” for the group, which the United States considers a terrorist organization.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: Cassiano Aufiero, the police investigator in charge of the case, said that officials were aware that Barakat had been linked to Hezbollah but added that their investigation was in connection to other activities.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: Aufiero said that charges against Barakat would include embezzlement and creating false documents in schemes involving the resale of clothing.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: “He was preying on his own countrymen, using their identities to create companies to carry out schemes,” Aufiero said.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: Barakat has been held in a state penitentiary in Curitiba since his arrest, he said.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: John Sullivan, a spokesman for the Treasury Department in Washington, says that the description of Barakat as a Hezbollah member still stands.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: After the Treasury Department described the links of Barakat and eight others in the Triple Frontier region to Hezbollah, Brazil’s government responded by saying that there were no signs of terrorism financing in the border region, which has long attracted large numbers of immigrants from the Middle East.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: In 2004, the Treasury Department called Barakat’s brother, Assad Ahmad Barakat, one of Hezbollah’s “most prominent and influential members,” and said he used an electronics wholesale store in the Triple Frontier as a cover for raising funds for Hezbollah.

column2: MAN LINKED BY U.S. TO HEZBOLLAH IS ARRESTED IN BRAZIL
column3: Brazilian police arrested Assad Ahmad Barakat in 2002 and deported him to Paraguay, where he went to prison for tax evasion.

column2: MANAGER HIRES CHRISTIE'S TO APPRAISE DETROIT ART MUSEUM HOLDINGS
column3: The city of Detroit, which has filed for bankruptcy, has formally hired the international auction house Christie’s to appraise part of the city-owned art collection held by the Detroit Institute of Arts, the auction house said Monday.

column2: MANAGER HIRES CHRISTIE'S TO APPRAISE DETROIT ART MUSEUM HOLDINGS
column3: A decision about whether to sell the art to satisfy creditors has not been made, city officials have said, although all the city’s assets are being evaluated in light of the situation in Detroit, the largest U.S. city ever to file for bankruptcy.

column2: MANAGER HIRES CHRISTIE'S TO APPRAISE DETROIT ART MUSEUM HOLDINGS
column3: Christie’s representatives had previously visited the museum in early June and confirmed Monday that the company had been hired to appraise the collection but gave no details about which portion of the collection it would be looking at.

column2: MANAGER HIRES CHRISTIE'S TO APPRAISE DETROIT ART MUSEUM HOLDINGS
column3: “Christie’s was asked to assist due to our expertise in this area across all fine art categories and eras,” it said in its statement.

column2: MANAGER HIRES CHRISTIE'S TO APPRAISE DETROIT ART MUSEUM HOLDINGS
column3: It said, “In addition we will also assist and advise on how to realize value for the City while leaving the art in the City’s ownership.”

column2: MANAGER HIRES CHRISTIE'S TO APPRAISE DETROIT ART MUSEUM HOLDINGS
column3: The office of Detroit emergency manager Kevyn Orr will pay Christie’s $200,000 for the appraisal, which is expected to be completed by mid-October, the Detroit Free Press reported on its website.

column2: MANAGER HIRES CHRISTIE'S TO APPRAISE DETROIT ART MUSEUM HOLDINGS
column3: Christie’s will appraise only artworks that are clearly owned by the city and that are not bound by donor restrictions that might rule out a possible sale, the newspaper said, citing Orr’s spokesman Bill Nowling.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: SEOUL, South Korea - The children of a former military dictator of South Korea, Chun Doo-hwan, said Tuesday that they will pay 167 billion won ($154 million) that their father owed the government in fines.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: Their decision closes a chapter on South Korea’s prolonged struggle with the legacy of one of its most brutal former leaders.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: Chun, then an army major general, came to power in a coup in 1979 following the assassination of another military-backed strongman, President Park Chung-hee, who was the father of the current South Korean leader, President Park Geun-hye.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: Chun ruled until 1988, when he was succeeded by Roh Tae-woo, his partner in the 1979 coup.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: After South Korea’s transition to democracy, both Chun and Roh were convicted on charges of treason for their roles in the coup and a 1980 military crackdown on a pro-democracy uprising in the southern city of Kwangju that left hundreds dead.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: They were also convicted of collecting huge bribes from big business while in office.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: In 1997, Chun was sentenced to life in prison and Roh to 17 years.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: Although they were later pardoned and freed, Chun and Roh had failed to pay the 220.5 billion won ($203 million) and 268.8 billion won ($248 million) that they were fined, respectively.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: Chun has so far paid only a quarter of his fine, claiming to have only 290,000 won ($267), in his bank accounts.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: But opposition lawmakers have said he might have huge assets stashed away.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: “We bow deeply in apology,” Chun Jae-kook, the eldest son of Chun, said in a family statement that he read Tuesday.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: He said Chun’s three sons and daughter would give up buildings, land and paintings and other assets to help pay their father’s fine.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: He said the house where Chun and his wife live would also be sold to help pay the fine, though he asked government officials to let his parents live there until they die.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: Chun is 82.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: Lee Jin-han, a senior prosecutor, told reporters that the assets prosecutors have secured so far from Chun’s family members, including those they said they would give up on Tuesday, amounted to 170 billion won ($156 million) enough to cover Chun’s unpaid fine.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: Earlier this month, Roh paid off his fine.

column2: FAMILY OF EX-SOUTH KOREAN DICTATOR TO PAY HIS FINES
column3: His brother and a businessman whose daughter divorced Roh’s son helped him pay the 23 billion won ($21 million) he still owed the government in fines.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: SAN FRANCISCO - T-Mobile US, the fourth-largest U.S. carrier, lost thousands of customers over the past few years to rivals that offered cooler phones.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: But it appears to be getting its groove back.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: The company Thursday said it had gained 1.1 million customers, including 685,000 contract subscribers, over its second quarter.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: That compares with losing 557,000 contract subscribers, the most valuable type of customer, in the same period a year ago.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: The uptick represents its largest customer growth in four years.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: The company, based in Bellevue, Wash., only started offering the iPhone in April, when it also began offering new phone plans that address common frustrations with wireless companies, like confusing contracts and expensive data plans.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: “By fixing the things that drive them mad, like contracts and upgrades, and freeing them from the two-year sentences imposed on them by our competitors, they are choosing the new T-Mobile in unprecedented numbers,” John Legere, the chief executive of T-Mobile US, said in a news release.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: Over the past several years, T-Mobile lost many customers largely because it lacked the iPhone, and customers were unhappy with its service.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: But this year has been jam-packed with change for the company: It finally landed a deal with Apple to sell the iPhone, it began an overhaul of its network and it started offering lower-cost plans to lure customers from competitors.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: The company also has extra muscle from its merger with the smaller carrier MetroPCS, which was completed in May.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: The change is costing T-Mobile.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: The company posted a loss of $16 million for the quarter, compared with a profit of $207 million last year in the same period.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: But it also reported revenue of $6.23 billion, up from $4.9 billion last year.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: The net income was above the expectations of Wall Street analysts.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: They had expected revenue of $6.01 billion, according to a survey by Thomson Reuters.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: In March, T-Mobile discontinued two-year contracts, instead allowing customers to buy a smartphone for a lower upfront cost and adding the cost of the device to their monthly bill.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: It also continued to offer plans with unlimited data, an option that the top two carriers, Verizon Wireless and AT&T, killed years ago.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: In general, T-Mobile’s plans are also cheaper than its competitors’ - for $70 a month, a customer can have unlimited minutes, text messages and data.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: The plans offered by AT&T and Verizon cost upward of roughly $100 a month.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: T-Mobile expects the growth to continue.

column2: T-MOBILE US REPORTS LARGEST CUSTOMER GROWTH IN 4 YEARS
column3: For the full year, it said it expected to add between 1 million and 1.2 million contract subscribers.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: LOS ANGELES - Just six months after declaring that “the prison crisis is over in California,” Gov.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: Jerry Brown is facing dire predictions about the future of the state’s prison system, one of the largest in the nation.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: A widespread inmate hunger strike against California’s policy of solitary confinement was approaching its second week on Sunday.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: The federal courts have demanded the release of nearly 10,000 inmates and the transfer of 2,600 others who are at risk of contracting a deadly disease in the state’s overcrowded prisons.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: State lawmakers have called for an investigation into a new report that nearly 150 women behind bars were coerced into being sterilized over the last decade.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: And last week, a federal judge ruled that prisoners were not receiving adequate medical care

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: “It is like a tinderbox, and all you had to do is light a match,” said Jules Lobel, the president of the Center for Constitutional Rights and the lead lawyer in a federal lawsuit over solitary confinement.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: “They see the state has shown no willingness to change, even when the high court orders it.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: They have decided to circle the wagons and keep the system that exists today as intact as possible.”

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: In many ways California prison system officials have been among the most reluctant to adapt systemic changes, experts say, doing so only when forced to by the federal courts.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: Even then, lawyers and advocates for prisoners say, the changes have come slowly and unevenly.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: Brown, a Democrat, has aggressively fought several federal court orders in the two years since the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that conditions and overcrowding in the system amounted to a violation of the Eighth Amendment - cruel and unusual punishment.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: Since then, federal judges overseeing the case have repeatedly declared that the state was not making changes quickly enough, and that conditions in the prisons remained appalling - that the state had been “deliberately indifferent.”

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: The judges have twice threatened to hold the governor in contempt if he does not comply with their order to release prisoners.

column2: CALIFORNIA IS FACING MORE WOES ON PRISONS
column3: Last week, Brown appealed to the Supreme Court to stop the order, arguing that the system had already improved dramatically and that stopping the release of prisoners was essential for public safety.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: ISTANBUL - Turkish police Saturday used water cannons to scatter thousands of people who had gathered in Taksim Square here to commemorate four people killed during the nationwide anti-government protests that have gripped Turkey for more than two weeks.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: Representatives of the peaceful protesters read a statement of their demands before turning to Gezi Park, the center of a campaign to save the only green patch in Istanbul’s center.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: But that environmental campaign has quickly blossomed into a protest against Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s autocratic and dismissive reaction toward the protesters.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: A few activists, representing Taksim Solidarity, an umbrella group, left red carnations at the entrance to Gezi Park, which has been blocked by the police since last Saturday.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: Some members of the crowd threw carnations at police vehicles or attached them to their wired windows.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: The police warned the crowd to disperse, but the protesters refused to leave Taksim Square and chanted anti-government slogans.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: Dozens of police officers then moved toward the crowd and began spraying the protesters with water cannons.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: For the first time in more than 20 days, the police did not use tear gas to force protesters away from Taksim Square.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: But the police did fire it at protesters on some side streets and at least one entrance to the square.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: “I was not standing on the road, which the police asked us to clear, so I thought I should be fine,” Gonul Duzer, a 24-year-old student, said as she held red carnations in her hand.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: “I wanted to hand these to them, but instead they pushed me away with their shields and said our right to protest was over.”

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: Demonstrators and passers-by sought shelter in nearby cafes that sealed off their windows, in case the police used tear gas, and emptied terraces overlooking the square.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: On Saturday, Erdogan claimed that the protests were carried out “with malicious intentions.”

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: “You became the pawns in a dirty game and were deceived gravely,” he said, according to the semiofficial Anatolian news agency, referring to young activists who have been attending protests in more than 60 cities.

column2: POLICE USE WATER CANNONS ON ISTANBUL PROTESTERS
column3: “Nobody but God will have the power to overthrow our government,” Erdogan said at a rally in Samsun, a town on the Black Sea coast.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: Marc Rich, the former fugitive oil trader and founder of the commodities trading giant Glencore International, died on Wednesday in Lucerne, Switzerland.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: He was 78.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: The cause was a brain stroke at a hospital, according to a statement from his spokesman.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: Rich courted controversy throughout his colorful career, and was indicted by the U.S. in the early 1980s on charges of tax evasion and illegally trading with Iran.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: After being one of the country’s most famous fugitives for the next two decades, Rich eventually received a pardon from President Bill Clinton on his last day in office in early 2001.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: The pardon brought the oil trader back into the headlines after it was revealed that Rich’s former wife, Denise Eisenberg, had given donations to the Democratic Party in 2000, according to official records.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: Despite his notoriety, Rich, whose net worth was estimated at $2.5 billion, continued to work in the commodities industry, and founded Marc Rich & Co., the precursor of Glencore International, the commodities trader, which he later sold to the company’s management team in 1993.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: Rich was born in Antwerp, Belgium, but moved to New York with his family to escape the rise of the Nazis in Germany.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: He began his career as a metals trader in the early 1970s, and gained prominence during the 1973-74 oil crisis when he circumvented the Arab oil embargo to sell oil to U.S. companies in desperate need of supplies at increasingly high prices.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: He continued to buy oil from Iran after the country’s 1979 Islamic revolution despite U.S. sanctions against the country, and remained unapologetic about his activities.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: “They respected the contracts,” Rich told Daniel Ammann, a Swiss journalist, in 2009, in reference to Iran’s national oil company.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: “We performed a service for them.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: We bought the oil, we handled the transport and we sold it.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: They couldn’t do it themselves, so we were able to do it.”

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: His clients also included the apartheid regime of South Africa and the Sandinista government in Nicaragua.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: From 1973, Rich was similarly one of Israel’s most important oil suppliers for more than 20 years, and he held Israeli, Spanish and Belgian citizenship by the end of his life.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: In 1983, he fled from the U.S. to Switzerland after he was indicted on charges of fraud, trading with Iran and evading almost $50 million in taxes.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: All told, the offenses would have led to more than 300 years in prison.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: Over the years, Rich claimed that U.S. authorities had attempted several times to bring him to justice, including a plan, which was never carried out, to use a helicopter in Switzerland to capture him, according to a book published by Ammann in 2009.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78
column3: After leaving the U.S. and renouncing his citizenship, Rich sold many of his domestic business interests, including 20th Century Fox to Rupert Murdoch for $250 million in 1984.

column2: MARC RICH, PARDONED FINANCIER, DIES AT 78

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: SANTIAGO, Chile - The Chilean courts have long been after Ray E. Davis, a former U.S. Navy captain, accusing him of being involved in the murder of two Americans decades ago that inspired the award-winning 1982 film “Missing.”

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: A Chilean judge indicted Davis in 2011 and requested his extradition from the United States, where he was assumed to be living with his wife, Patricia.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: The Chilean Supreme Court then authorized the extradition request in October.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: But it turns out Davis may have been right under their noses all along, living in a nursing home in the Chilean capital.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: Any attempts to haul him into court may now be too late; documents show that he recently died here.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: The death of Davis, former commander of the U.S. Military Group at the embassy in Santiago, would leave many unanswered questions about the possible roles played by U.S. officials in the killings of Americans Charles Horman, 31, and Frank Teruggi, 24, while in military custody shortly after the 1973 military coup led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: It was the Horman case that is depicted in the film “Missing” by the director Costa-Gavras.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: At the time of the indictment, Patricia Davis told The Associated Press that her husband had Alzheimer’s disease and was in a nursing home.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: She did not explain, however, that the nursing home was in Santiago.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: U.S. Embassy officials in Chile said they were unaware that Davis was living in Santiago until early May, when they were informed of his death a few days before.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: Patricia Davis also confirmed her husband’s death in a telephone interview from Niceville, Fla., but declined to say where it had occurred.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: A death certificate issued in Santiago says that a Ray E. Davis died of a “multisystemic failure” on April 30, at age 88.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: Records at the Parque del Recuerdo cemetery in Santiago also show that a Ray E. Davis was cremated there but that his remains were taken elsewhere.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: Charles Horman’s widow, Joyce, is unconvinced that it is the Ray Davis accused of involvement in her husband’s murder, and she has asked the U.S. Embassy to provide proof of the cancellation of the former captain’s pension.

column2: CHILE HUNT FOR JUSTICE WINDS UP AS A DEAD END
column3: “How is it that no one notified the Chilean court system or the U.S. Embassy that Ray Davis was in Chile, when it now looks like he had been in Chile for a year or so?” she said.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: MEXICO CITY - A former colonel in the Salvadoran military accused of planning the killing of six Jesuit priests during that country’s civil war has been sentenced to 21 months in a U.S. prison for immigration violations.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: The sentence, handed down in Boston on Tuesday, could set the stage for his extradition to Spain, where he would be one of the few top-ranking officers to face trial in the 1989 killings.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: Five of the six priests were Spanish, and Spain is seeking his extradition because it is unlikely that El Salvador - where an amnesty law has allowed other suspects in the crime to remain free - will prosecute him.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: If convicted in Spain, he could face up to 30 years in prison.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: The former colonel, Inocente Orlando Montano, 71, was El Salvador’s vice minister of public safety at the time of the killings, which brought international condemnation.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: When he was arrested in 2011, he had been living in a Boston suburb for 10 years.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: He pleaded guilty in September to charges of immigration fraud and perjury related to his application for temporary humanitarian status to remain legally in the United States.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: Almudena Bernabéu, a lawyer with the Center for Justice and Accountability in San Francisco, which has pursued the case, said that the United States had indicated it would be amenable to extraditing Montano once he served his sentence for immigration fraud.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: Extradition proceedings could take more than a year.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: “With the conclusion of this sentencing, the hope is that the United States will, in fact, revise and respond positively to the extradition request,” Bernabéu said.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: Montano had been granted a special immigration status that shielded him from deportation, which he had received after lying about his military service and the date he entered the United States, prosecutors said.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: An assistant U.S. attorney, John A. Capin, argued that Montano came to the United States to avoid criminal prosecution for his role in the killings.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: Montano’s lawyer said that an amnesty was in effect when he left El Salvador, making the former colonel, who he said faced economic hardship at the time, immune to prosecution in his home country.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: Truth Commission report named Montano a participant in the plot to kill the priests, whom military officers suspected of collaborating with left-wing guerrillas.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: They, their housekeeper and her teenage daughter were killed in a raid on the Jesuit-run University of Central America in San Salvador.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: In 2011, a Spanish National Court judge issued arrest warrants for 20 men, including Montano, suspected of participating in the slaying of the priests.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: The judge also requested the extradition of 15 of the 20 - the main suspects - but the Salvadoran Supreme Court denied that request.

column2: SALVADORAN LINKED TO KILLING TO SERVE TIME IN U.S. PRISON
column3: “The sentence of 21 months sends a message to human rights abusers that they cannot seek safe haven in the United States and avoid accountability for their actions,” said a statement from the Center for Justice and Accountability.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: Maps released by Wynn Resorts on Wednesday indicate that all of the company’s proposed Mystic River casino development lies within Everett, bolstering the company’s claim that the City of Boston is not a host community for the project and therefore cannot block it.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: But Mayor Thomas M. Menino’s administration was not ready to give up, saying the Charlestown neighborhood near the proposed development should get to vote on whether to accept the Wynn proposal.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: ''It is easy to draw lines on a map and circumvent the boundaries of the city, but that doesn’t circumvent the impacts to the city,'' said Menino’s spokeswoman Dot Joyce.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: ''The city will continue to fight for the full protection of Charlestown and the people of Charlestown.''

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: Menino and Wynn are in an ongoing dispute over whether part of Wynn’s proposed resort is in Boston.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: If it is, Boston could be designated a host community for the project under state law, giving the city broad power over the development, including the power to kill it.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: Boston’s claim rests with the odd shape of the city line, which darts across the Mystic River into the edge of the former Monsanto chemical site where Wynn intends to build.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: The state gambling commission brought the two sides together Wednesday to present their arguments at a public forum.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: After hearing both sides -- and seeing Wynn’s maps -- the panel gave the combatants until the end of the week to solve the dispute on their own, or the commission would solve it for them at a more formal hearing with witnesses, cross examinations, and documents entered into evidence.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: Commission members did not directly say Wednesday which side they believed to be right, but suggested the documents provided by Wynn should help solve the dispute.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: ''It looks to me the facts are pretty clear,'' said commission chairman Stephen Crosby.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: Wynn is competing for the sole Greater Boston casino Âlicense with Suffolk Downs, the East Boston casino proposal Âfavored by Menino, and a Foxwoods project in Milford.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: The commission is expected to choose the winning applicant in early 2014.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: Wynn’s representatives, including former governor William F. Weld, a partner at Mintz Levin, argued that the City of Boston, while not a host community, probably qualifies as a surrounding community under the law.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: As a surrounding community, the city could negotiate with Wynn for compensation to address the effects of a casino, such as additional traffic on Boston streets.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: Surrounding communities, however, do not hold binding public votes on casino projects, nor can they block a casino development by refusing to negotiate or by asking for too much.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: Failed negotiations would be settled through arbitration.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: ''There is nothing personal here,'' Weld said.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: ''We want the City of Boston to receive fair compensation for any impacts.''

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: In presenting the city’s case, lawyers for Boston displayed Wynn’s own renderings of the project, which appear to show landscaping on a narrow triangle of land on the Boston side of the city line.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: The city also claimed Wynn created confusion over Boston’s status by refusing to provide project plans and documents the city had requested.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: Wynn’s representatives said artistic renderings should not be taken as formal plans.

column2: Wynn, Boston told to end tiff
column3: Lawyers representing the two sides swapped business cards after the hearing, which Crosby took as a positive sign they would be talking about a resolution, without further action from the commission.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: TEHRAN, Iran - On the eve of a visit by Iran’s moderate president to the United States, the Iranian authorities Wednesday unexpectedly freed 11 of Iran’s most prominent political prisoners, including Nasrin Sotoudeh, a human rights lawyer.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Analysts said the prisoner release was a significant step in Hasan Rouhani’s efforts to repair Iran’s relationship with the West, which has been mired in a dispute over Iran’s nuclear program and criticism of its human rights policies.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: His visit to New York to attend the annual session of the U.N. General Assembly is part of a diplomatic offensive he began after his election in June.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Sotoudeh was serving six years in prison for endangering national security and misusing her profession as a lawyer.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: In a telephone interview after her release, she said: “I don’t know why they released me.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: I don’t know under what legal basis they released me.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: But I am free.”

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Her husband, Reza Khandan, said: “I just drove her home.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: My wife is freed.”

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Of the prisoners freed Wednesday, eight are women and three are men.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: They include a journalist, Mahsa Amrabadi, whose husband and fellow journalist, Masoud Bastani, remains in prison.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Some of them were taking part in Iran’s prison leave system, in which some prisoners are allowed to live at home but remain under the threat of imprisonment if they cross the authorities.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: But dozens of people remain in prison, especially those who have been sentenced for their roles in an anti-government protest after the disputed 2009 election results.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Rouhani is scheduled to speak Tuesday before the General Assembly, where is expected to portray an Iran ready to engage with the West.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Analysts said the prisoner release could soften some of the criticisms over Iran’s human rights policies and allow for Rouhani to focus on finding a diplomatic solution to the standoff over Iran’s disputed nuclear program.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: “Clearly these releases are related to Mr. Rouhani’s trip to New York,” said Farshad Ghorbanpour, a political analyst close to the new president.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: “Iran wants to make a good impression on the eve of his trip.”

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: The release of Sotoudeh, 50, is especially significant.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: For a long time, she was the only lawyer in Iran taking on high-profile cases, defending children, activists and minorities.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Unlike some activists, Sotoudeh never chose to leave Iran, despite constant pressure on her by Iran’s intelligence services, which arrested her in 2010.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: In addition to her jail sentence, she had been banned from practicing law for 20 years; it was unclear Wednesday whether the ban had been lifted.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: In his annual message for Iranian New Year in 2011, President Barack Obama specifically singled out Sotoudeh.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: “We have seen Nasrin Sotoudeh jailed for defending human rights,” he said.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Iranian officials deny that there are any political prisoners in Iran, saying that all those behind bars have been tried according to the country’s laws.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: While in Tehran’s notorious Evin prison, Sotoudeh went on two long hunger strikes after her 12-year-old daughter was denied permission to travel outside the country.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: In 2012, the European Union awarded her the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Among the other prisoners released Wednesday was former Commerce Minister Feizollah Arabsorkhi, a member of a reformist political party declared illegal after the 2009 anti-government protests, which were triggered by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s disputed re-election victory.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Arabsorkhi was in a hospital in Tehran undergoing a shoulder operation when he heard that he had been officially freed, his wife, Maryam Sharbatqods, said over the phone.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: “Rouhani’s election victory has forced the authorities to release the political prisoners,” Sharbatqods said.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Two presidential candidates in 2009 - former Prime Minister Mir Hussein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi, a former Parliament speaker - have been under house arrest since 2011, along with Mousavi’s wife, Zahra Rahnavard.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: During his election campaign, Rouhani said he would work to secure their release.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Mehdi, 27, a university student who took part in the 2009 protests and asked that his surname not be published, said: “Today’s prisoner releases show that there are negotiations going on regarding their freedom.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Maybe it will take some time to get them freed from house arrest.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: I am much more hopeful now.”

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: An imprisoned American of Iranian descent, Amir Hekmati, was not among those freed Wednesday.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: Hekmati’s family, who is from Flint, Mich., has been publicly pleading for his release, and U.S. officials, including Secretary of State John Kerry, have been calling on Rouhani’s government to let Hekmati go home.

column2: IRAN FREES POLITICAL PRISONERS ON EVE OF PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
column3: On Tuesday, Hekmati’s congressman, Rep. Daniel T. Kildee, sent a letter to Samantha Power, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, urging her to press the issue when Rouhani visits for the General Assembly session next week.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: Erich Priebke, a former SS captain who was sentenced to life in prison for helping to organize the execution of 335 men and boys at the Ardeatine Caves in Italy in 1944, died Friday under house arrest at his home in Rome.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: He was 100 and the oldest surviving convicted Nazi war criminal.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: Priebke was at the center of one of the most contentious Nazi war-crimes prosecutions of the 1990s, begun after an American television crew tracked him down in Argentina at San Carlos de Bariloche, a resort city in the foothills of the Andes.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: Priebke fled to South America soon after World War II and had been living under his real name, owning a butcher shop and traveling to Europe - and even Italy - with a German passport.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: He was extradited to Italy in November 1995 and ordered to stand trial before an Italian military tribunal the next year.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: The proceedings - described at the time as possibly the last Nazi war-crimes trial in Europe - centered on the massacre at the Ardeatine Caves, just south of Rome, on March 24, 1944.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: The men and boys were rounded up and killed in reprisal for an attack in which Italian partisans killed 33 members of a Nazi security force.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: Herbert Kappler, the Gestapo chief in Rome, ordered the deaths of 10 Italians for every dead policeman.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: Seventy-five of the 335 victims were Jewish.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: By many accounts, the captives were led into the caves with their hands tied behind their backs, forced to kneel - many over the bodies of those already killed - and shot in the neck.

column2: ERICH PRIEBKE, NAZI WHO CARRIED OUT ITALIAN MASSACRE, DIES AT 100
column3: Priebke said he was responsible for exceeding the quota by five.

RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: KIROV, Russia - Alexei A. Navalny, a lawyer who became Russia’s most resonant opposition voice by crusading against rampant public corruption, was found guilty Thursday of stealing money from a state-controlled timber company.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: He was sentenced to five years in prison - a punishment that immediately transformed Navalny, 37, who recently declared his candidacy for mayor of Moscow, from an opposition activist to a political dissident and prisoner.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: Navalny - who became an irritant to President Vladimir Putin by branding his United Russia political machine as the “party of swindlers and thieves,” - was the first to use the Internet and social media as his main weapon against the state.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: Navalny’s co-defendant, Pyotr Ofitserov, a businessman and acquaintance who worked with him on the timber project, was sentenced to four years in prison.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: The two men, who had been accused of embezzling nearly $500,000, were also each fined more than $15,000.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: Much of the judge’s findings was based on the testimony of a third man accused in the scheme, Vyacheslav Opalev, who pleaded guilty and worked with the prosecution.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: In his decision, Judge Sergei Blinov called his testimony trustworthy and reliable.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: But during the trial, Opalev at times gave contradictory evidence, and defense lawyers were not allowed to cross-examine him.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: In addition, Blinov barred the defense from calling 13 witnesses.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: The verdict quickly reverberated throughout the highest levels of Russian government and society and even sparked some calls for boycotts of the Moscow mayoral election and future national ballots.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: Alexei L. Kudrin, a close associate of Putin and former finance minister, described it on Twitter as “looking less like a punishment than an attempt to isolate him from social life and the electoral process.”

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: The crime novelist Boris Akunin, who is also a political opposition leader, said the verdict showed there was little hope to change Russia by democratic means.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER
column3: He was led away in handcuffs.

column2: RUSSIAN COURT CONVICTS OPPOSITION LEADER

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: NEW YORK - Joseph J. Lhota, making his first campaign appearances since winning the Republican nomination for mayor, on Thursday criticized his likely Democratic opponent, Bill de Blasio, accusing him of trying to divide the city by class in order to score votes.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: Lhota, in a series of interviews, portrayed de Blasio as a free-spending liberal who wants to raise taxes, and who would seek to undo the progress made by the current mayor, Michael Bloomberg, and his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: “His approach to things is to tear things down and build them up in the image that he wants, which I think is a failed image,” Lhota said in a television interview.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: He said de Blasio’s approach amounted to “a repudiation of everything great that’s happened over the last 20 years, and we can’t let that happen.”

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: The media tour by Lhota marked the beginning of an effort by the candidate to appeal to a wide audience of voters, after months in which he focused on drumming up support among the Republicans whose support he needed in Tuesday’s primary.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: His remarks came as the Democratic race remained unsettled, with de Blasio hovering slightly above the 40 percent threshold required to avoid a runoff, but thousands of paper ballots still to count.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: De Blasio, trying to create an air of inevitability about his nomination, held a rally in Brooklyn with supporters, many of whom had earlier endorsed his rivals.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: In Lhota’s appearances, which also included radio interviews, he acknowledged that the Democratic primary was still unresolved, but he spoke as if de Blasio were his opponent.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: He mounted a direct attack on de Blasio’s “tale of two cities” campaign theme, saying that de Blasio was trying to “separate classes” as a political strategy.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: “Calling it a tale of two cities, that level of invective has no place in any campaign, at all,” Lhota said.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: “It divides people.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: What we really need to do is to work together and provide a solution, not separating people and then saying that the ends justify the means.”

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
column3: Lhota also visited the Queens burial site of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, who was the revered leader of Lubavitch Hasidim.

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY

column2: LHOTA ACCUSES DE BLASIO OF TRYING TO DIVIDE THE CITY
