column3: For almost two decades, Rancadore lived in England under the assumed name of Marc Skinner, using the maiden name of his wife, Anne, and leading an innocuous life in London’s outer fringes, far from the perennial battle in Sicily between the authorities and the mob.

column2: ALLEGED ITALIAN MOB BOSS IS DENIED BAIL IN BRITAIN
column3: Joan Hills, 76, who lives nearby, told The Independent that Rancadore was “one of the best neighbors you could ever have.”

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: BEIJING – A North Korean envoy visiting China said his country would “accept the proposal” by Chinese officials to open up dialogue, the China News Service reported Thursday, a possible signal that the North would agree to talks on its nuclear program.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: The comments were reported after the envoy, Marshal Choe Ryong-hae, met Liu Yunshan, who is a member of the Communist Party Standing Committee and the politician who heads ideological affairs for the Communist Party.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: Liu was quoted as repeating a frequent appeal by China for a resumption of talks that would result in the removal of nuclear weapons from the Korean Peninsula “as soon as possible.”

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: Few diplomats believe that the North is prepared to be involved in so-called six-party talks that aim to strip North Korea of its nuclear weapons.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: The international six-party talks on the North’s nuclear program – involving the United States, North Korea, South Korea, China, Japan and Russia – collapsed in 2008 after North Korea walked out, but the United States has been pushing in recent weeks for them to be restarted.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: China is North Korea’s biggest benefactor, but relations have been strained in recent months.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: Experts say the North bridles at China’s stiff demands for low-priced natural resources, and that Chinese officials are annoyed by the North’s defiance of entreaties to refrain from missile and nuclear tests, the lastest of which was conducted in February.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: The visit by Choe, a close aide to the North’s new leader, Kim Jong Un, was seen by many analysts as a fence-mending mission.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: Choe, 72, was quoted by the China News Service as being “highly” appreciative of “China’s huge efforts to maintain peace and stability” on the Korean Peninsula.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: There have been no reports so far of Choe meeting with senior Chinese officials involved in foreign policy and military affairs.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: The publicized meetings have been with senior officials of the Communist Party who are the usual interlocutors with North Korea.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: On Wednesday, Choe met with Wang Jiarui, head of the International Department of the Communist Party of China.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: The North Korean news agency said Choe visited an industrial park in Beijing on Thursday.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: China’s basic advice to North Korea has been that it should reform its economy following the path of Deng Xiaoping, with special economic zones and some private enterprise.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: Although North Korea has sometimes embarked on such reforms, the government has later pulled back, perhaps for fear of losing control in one of the world’s most tightly controlled countries.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: North Korean experts in China say they detect little change in China’s underlying policy of supporting North Korea.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: But the Chinese leadership would like North Korea to modify its erratic behavior, stop nuclear tests and halt its missile program, they say.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: How to reach that goal with Kim has not been resolved, some of the analysts said.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: The marshal’s visit came just days after the announcement that President Xi Jingping of China and President Barack Obama intended to meet in California next month, suggesting that the North was concerned that its recent actions had pushed China and the United States closer.

column2: ENVOY SAYS NORTH KOREA OPEN TO DIALOGUE
column3: Wang Gunsheng, an analyst at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, said the visit of Choe could be interpreted as a “kind of apology” by North Korea for its recent behavior.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: PARIS – Five people were convicted Monday in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, in connection with an elaborate organ-trafficking network that lured poor people to the country to sell their kidneys and other organs to wealthy transplant recipients from Israel, the United States, Canada and Germany.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: Organs sold for as much as $130,000 each.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: The defendants, all Kosovars, were tried before a panel of two European Union judges and one Kosovar judge.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: A special prosecutor for the union, Jonathan Ratel, called the case a landmark because doctors had been convicted.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: Dr. Lutfi Dervishi, a urologist and the director of the clinic at the center of the trafficking ring, was sentenced to eight years in prison.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: His son Arban Dervishi was sentenced to seven years and three months, and Dr. Sokol Hajdini, the clinic’s chief anesthesiologist, to three years.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: Two other defendants received one-year suspended sentences.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: In addition to the five who were convicted, two defendants were acquitted of charges of fraud and abuse of authority.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: All had denied any wrongdoing.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: “The sole and driving motive for this exploitation of the poor and the indigent was the opportunity for obscene profit and human greed,” Ratel, the prosecutor, said Monday.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: “In every sense this was a cruel harvest of the poor.”

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: The case has shaken Kosovo, a mostly Muslim country of 2 million that broke away from Serbia in 2008 in the aftermath of the Balkan wars of the 1990s and has been struggling to shed a culture of lawlessness and corruption.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: This month, Kosovo and Serbia reached an agreement that the Kosovo government hopes will accelerate its integration into the international community, including membership in the United Nations.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: According to the indictment in the case, traffickers in the network promised payments of up to $26,000 to poor people in Turkey, Moldova and Russia to persuade them to travel to Kosovo and donate an organ.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: They were asked to sign false documents saying they were donating to a relative for humanitarian reasons.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: Two dozen donors were taken in by the scheme; many were never given any compensation and were released without adequate medical care.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: The wealthy, ailing patients who were to receive the organs flew to Pristina for transplant operations at a clinic called Medicus.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: It was founded by a well-meaning European philanthropist who helped local doctors during the war in Kosovo in 1999, but prosecutors said it was later transformed into an illegal organ transplant hub by Dervishi, a surgeon and professor at Pristina University Hospital.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: Ratel said the Dervishis were aided by Dr. Yusuf Sonmez, whom he called a notorious international organ trafficker.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: Sonmez is a fugitive and may be in South Africa, Ratel said.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: The big breakthrough in the case happened in November 2008, Ratel said, when a young Turkish man was found at the Pristina airport, weak and shaking, with a large surgical scar on his left abdomen.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: The man told the police that his kidney had been stolen.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: When the police raided the clinic, they found a frail elderly Israeli man who had paid $90,000 for the kidney.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: Petrit Selimi, the deputy foreign minister of Kosovo, said the verdict showed that the rule of law was working in the country.

column2: FIVE ARE CONVICTED IN KOSOVO ORGAN-TRAFFICKING RING
column3: “Illegal organ transplants are a scourge of poorer nations from Kamchatka to Kosovo, and we will continue to chase criminals engaged in it,” Selimi said.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: NEW YORK – During the sentencing of the former hedge fund manager Anthony Chiasson on Monday, Judge Richard J. Sullivan marveled at his prodigious wealth, ticking off the annual income listed on his tax returns.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: “$16 million, $10 million, $23 million,” he said.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: “It’s hard to imagine why someone would risk all that to engage in a crime like this,” the judge said.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: The crime is insider trading, and Sullivan of U.S. District Court in Manhattan handed down one of the stiffest sentences yet in the government’s vast campaign to root out wrongdoing on Wall Street trading floors.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: He sentenced Chiasson, a founder of Level Global Investors, to 6 1/2 years in prison after a jury found him guilty in December of illegally trading technology stocks.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: “This kind of conduct can’t go unpunished,” Sullivan said.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: Chiasson, 39, who did not address the court, was ordered to pay a $5 million fine and forfeit illegally obtained proceeds of as much as $2 million.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: He must report to the Federal Bureau of Prisons in 90 days.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: His legal team, led by Reid H. Weingarten of Steptoe & Johnson and Gregory Morvillo of Morvillo Law, is appealing his conviction.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: They have brought on Mark F. Pomerantz, a lawyer at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, to handle the appeal.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: Chiasson was tried last year alongside Todd Newman, a former portfolio manager at Diamondback Capital Management.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: The government accused them of being the two most senior Wall Street traders in an eight-member “criminal club” that made $72 million in profits by trading shares of Dell and Nvidia based on corporate secrets obtained from inside those companies.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: After a six-week trial, a jury convicted Chiasson and Newman.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: Earlier this month, Sullivan sentenced Newman to 4 1/2 years in prison.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: Chiasson’s case is one of several insider-trading prosecutions that have touched SAC Capital Advisors, the giant hedge fund owned by the billionaire stock picker Steven A. Cohen that has become a central target of the government’s investigation.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: Prosecutors charged two former SAC employees with participating in the insider-trading ring involving Chiasson.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: Jon Horvath, a former SAC technology stock analyst, has admitted to being a part of the scheme.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: In March, Horvath’s boss, Michael S. Steinberg, was indicted.

column2: EX-HEDGE FUND MANAGER SENTENCED TO MORE THAN 6 YEARS
column3: He is fighting the charges and is scheduled to go on trial in November before Sullivan.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: DHAKA, Bangladesh - A factory building that collapsed last month outside Dhaka, killing more than 1,000 workers in the deadliest disaster in the history of the garment industry, was constructed with substandard materials and in blatant disregard for building codes, a high-level government report issued Wednesday concluded.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: The 400-page report on the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Savar, an industrial suburb of Dhaka, the capital, found widespread fault for the April 24 disaster, which killed 1,127 people.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: It blamed the mayor for wrongly granting construction approvals and recommended charges for the building’s owner, Sohel Rana, as well for as the owners of the five garment factories in the building, that could result in life sentences if they are convicted.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: The factory owners urged workers to return to their jobs despite evidence that the building was unsafe, the report said.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: “They compelled them to start,” said Main Uddin Khandaker, a high-ranking official in Bangladesh’s Home Ministry, who led the investigation.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: The Rana Plaza disaster has focused global attention on unsafe conditions in the garment industry in Bangladesh, which is now the world’s second-leading exporter of clothing, trailing only China.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: Bangladesh has more than 5,000 garment factories, handling orders for nearly all of the world’s top brands and retailers.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: It has become an export powerhouse largely by delivering lower costs, in part by having the lowest wages in the world for garment workers.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: Rana Plaza was a disaster waiting to happen, the government report suggested.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: Rana illegally constructed upper floors to house garment factories employing several thousand workers, it said.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: Large power generators placed on these upper floors, necessary because of regular power failures, would shake the poorly constructed building whenever they were switched on, according to the report.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: On April 23, cracks had appeared in the building, shaking the structure enough that many workers fled.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: An engineer called to inspect the structure warned that it was unsafe.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: Yet Rana and the factory bosses discounted any concerns and ordered their workers into the building the next morning, the government report concluded.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: A generator soon switched on, and the building buckled and collapsed, in what became a scene of horror.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: Khandaker’s report recommended that Rana and the factory owners be charged with culpable homicide.

column2: REPORT ON BANGLADESH BUILDING COLLAPSE FINDS WIDESPREAD BLAME
column3: He also suggested that Rana had bribed local officials for construction approvals.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: COLTS NECK, N.J. – With 10 children kneeling around the altar for their first communion and the pews at St. Mary’s Church packed with families gathered for Mother’s Day, there was little sign Sunday of the turmoil that has struck the parish, and threatens the Archdiocese of Newark.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: Just two weeks earlier, the parishioners learned that a minister working with their church’s youth groups had been barred from being around children unsupervised – a restriction he accepted to avoid retrial on a sex abuse charge.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: “I think everyone was just shocked; there’s no other way to put it,” Darren Barreiro, a father of three girls, said as he left Mass on Sunday.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: The priest, Michael Fugee, was convicted in 2003 of criminal sexual conduct stemming from allegations that he had groped a boy’s crotch during several wrestling horseplay encounters when he was associate pastor at St. Elizabeth Church in Wyckoff.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: Three years later, an appellate court overturned the conviction, in part because the judge allowed jurors to hear a statement Fugee made to the police saying he was attracted to males, according to The Star-Ledger of Newark.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: Rather than begin another trial, Fugee and the Bergen County prosecutor’s office signed an agreement that he would enter sex-offender treatment and have no unsupervised contact with children as part of his church duties.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: The 2007 agreement was also signed by the Archdiocese of Newark, which was required to ensure that Fugee was not assigned any tasks that would put him in a position to have unsupervised contact with children, including involvement with youth groups, attending youth retreats or hearing confessions of children.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: Fugee’s name came up again in 2009, when he was appointed chaplain at St. Michael’s Medical Center in Newark, a position the Newark Archdiocese said did not put him in contact with children because the hospital did not have a pediatric unit.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: But after inquiries, he was removed from that post.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: Late last year, the Newark archbishop, John J. Myers, assigned Fugee to become co-director of the Office of Continuing Education and Ongoing Formation of Priests, which caused critics of how the church has handled sex abuse issues among its clergy to call for Myers to step down.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: That criticism escalated after The Star-Ledger published an article on April 28 revealing that Fugee had been working with youth groups at St. Mary’s, which falls under the jurisdiction of the Trenton Archdiocese.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: The article said the priest had attended weekend youth retreats, traveled with the church’s youth group to Canada, and heard confessions from minors behind closed doors.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: On Wednesday, Steve Sweeney, president of the New Jersey Senate, released a statement calling the accusations “deeply disturbing.”

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: “Those who are put in a position of trust, whether it be through elected office, as a coach, or as a person of faith, must be held to a higher standard,” the statement said.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: “And when we are talking about children, that need to trust those in charge leaves absolutely no margin for error.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: Archbishop Myers must step down now.”

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: Myers was unaware of Fugee’s work in Colts Neck until the archdiocese was asked about it by a Star-Ledger reporter, his spokesman, James Goodness, said Sunday.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: When he learned of the work, Myers moved to suspend Fugee, who voluntarily left the ministry May 2, Goodness said.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: The archbishop, who will return this week from a previously scheduled trip to Poland, plans to speak publicly about the issue soon after, Goodness said.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: The Diocese of Trenton also said it was unaware of Fugee’s involvement with the Colts Neck church until it was contacted by a reporter.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: The archdiocese said the parish’s two youth group ministers, Michael and Amy Lenehan, had improperly invited Fugee to participate in the youth program without approval from the diocese or the church’s pastor, the Rev.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: Thomas J. Triggs.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: During Masses on the weekend of May 4 and 5, a statement from the Trenton bishop, David M. O’Connell, was read to parishioners in Colts Neck, saying the “troubling events” made clear that a change in leadership was in the best interest of everyone involved.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: The statement said the Lenehans had resigned and that Triggs was being reassigned.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: “There are few things in life as important as protecting our children and young people,” O’Connell said in the statement, adding that he prayed “that this community of faith will move forward together, that any anger or hurt will subside and that the Lord will bless our efforts to serve one another in his name.”

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: A note tucked into the program for Mass on Sunday announced that the Rev.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: Jeffrey Lee, the pastor of Our Lady of Angels Church in Trenton, would be the church’s new pastor.

column2: MINISTER ’ S PAST CAUSES TURMOIL IN NEW JERSEY
column3: In services Sunday, Lee made no mention of the recent troubles.

column2: FOUR BROTHERS DIE IN FIRE AT JORDAN CAMP FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES
column3: JERUSALEM – Four young brothers who had fled the civil war in Syria were killed in a fire that engulfed four tents in the Zaatari refugee camp near Jordan’s northern border, the aid worker who runs the camp said Saturday.

column2: FOUR BROTHERS DIE IN FIRE AT JORDAN CAMP FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES
column3: Kilian Kleinschmidt of the Office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said that there were conflicting reports as to whether the Friday night fire was started by a candle or an electrical short-circuit, but that he believed it was accidental, in contrast to previous fires that officials suspect were deliberately set to protest conditions in the camp.

column2: FOUR BROTHERS DIE IN FIRE AT JORDAN CAMP FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES
column3: “This looks like a genuine fire,” said Kleinschmidt, director of the Zaatari camp.

column2: FOUR BROTHERS DIE IN FIRE AT JORDAN CAMP FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES
column3: “This tragic incident highlights even more so how vulnerable the kids are in displacement and refuge.”

column2: FOUR BROTHERS DIE IN FIRE AT JORDAN CAMP FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES
column3: Zaatari, the largest camp of Syrian refugees in the region, has more than 100,000 residents, nearly 60 percent of them children; more than half live in tents.

column2: FOUR BROTHERS DIE IN FIRE AT JORDAN CAMP FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES
column3: Kleinschmidt said the four brothers from the Mubarak family – Salem, 6; Mahmoud, 5; Yasen, 4; and Mohammad, 3 – had suffered burns over 80 percent of their bodies and died in a local hospital, two Friday night and two Saturday.

column2: FOUR BROTHERS DIE IN FIRE AT JORDAN CAMP FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES
column3: Kleinschmidt said residents from the area of the camp where the fire broke out had stormed the registration compound Saturday morning to demand that their tents be replaced by the prefabricated units known as caravans.

column2: FOUR BROTHERS DIE IN FIRE AT JORDAN CAMP FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES

column3: SANFORD, Fla. - George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who fatally shot Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, igniting a national debate on racial profiling and civil rights, was found not guilty late Saturday of second-degree murder.

column2: ZIMMERMAN IS ACQUITTED IN KILLING OF TRAYVON MARTIN

column2: ZIMMERMAN IS ACQUITTED IN KILLING OF TRAYVON MARTIN

column2: ZIMMERMAN IS ACQUITTED IN KILLING OF TRAYVON MARTIN

column2: ZIMMERMAN IS ACQUITTED IN KILLING OF TRAYVON MARTIN

column2: Obama nominates
column3: Addressing long-term vacancies in the federal court system in Massachusetts, the White House has nominated three lawyers for federal judgeships in the state, including the recommendation of Hampden District Attorney Mark G. Mastroianni to a US District Court post in Springfield.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: In addition to Mastroianni, the White House nominated attorney Indira Talwani to the US District Court in Boston, and tapped Harvard Law School professor David Jeremiah Barron -- a former Department of Justice lawyer -- for appointment to the US Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: The nominations, announced Tuesday, will be sent to the Senate Judiciary Committee for confirmation.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: ''Both nominees .Â .Â .

column2: Obama nominates
column3: are talented and highly respected practitioners with diverse professional backgrounds, strong ties to the community, and impressive legal careers,'' said Senator Elizabeth Warren, who commissioned an advisory committee that recommended Talwani and Mastroianni.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: She also praised the nomination of Barron, saying he ''is a highly respected law professor and former government official with a strong commitment to public service.''

column2: Obama nominates
column3: In nominating Barron, President Obama said in a statement that he ''has displayed exceptional dedication to the legal profession through his work.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: .Â .Â .

column2: Obama nominates
column3: He will be a diligent, judicious, and esteemed addition to the First Circuit bench.''

column2: Obama nominates
column3: Barron is married to former Globe editorial columnist Juliette Kayyem, a candidate for Massachusetts governor.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: In addition to teaching at Harvard, he served for 18 months in the Obama administration as acting assistant attorney general in the Department of Justice.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: Barron came under criticism in October 2011 for drafting the Obama administration’s secret legal memorandum that justified the controversial killing, without a trial, of the American-born Anwar al-Awlaki, the radical Muslim cleric hiding in Yemen.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: He was killed in spite of an executive order banning assassinations.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: The White House defended the memorandum and the killing.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: Barron’s nomination was supported by lifelong Republican John F. Manning, a colleague at Harvard Law School, as well as Charles Fried, also a Harvard professor and solicitor general to President Reagan.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: If his nomination is approved, Barron would replace Court of Appeals Judge Michael Boudin, who assumed senior status, or semiretired status, in June.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: Boudin, who has sat on the court since 1992, was the author of the First Circuit’s historic decision that struck down the federal Defense of Marriage Act in 2012.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: The Supreme Court, in a separate case, later ruled the law unconstitutional.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: Mastroianni, a former state prosecutor and private lawyer who became district attorney in 2011, was nominated to replace US District Court Michael Ponsor, the Springfield sitting federal judge who took senior status in August 2011.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: And Talwani, a private lawyer who focuses on civil litigation, was tapped to replace US District Court Judge Mark L. Wolf, who took senior status in January.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: ''These individuals have demonstrated the talent, expertise, and fair-mindedness Americans expect and deserve from their judicial system,'' Obama said.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: ''I am grateful for their willingness to serve and confident that they will apply the law with the utmost impartiality and integrity.''

column2: Obama nominates
column3: According to campaign finance reports, Barron and Talwani have donated to federal political candidates: Barron gave $4,000 to Obama and $1,500 to Warren.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: He has also given to Representative Joseph Kennedy III and Senator Edward J. Markey.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: Talwani gave $200 to Warren in 2011 and $1,000 to Secretary of State John F. Kerry’s presidential campaign in 2004.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: Retired US District Court Judge Nancy Gertner, who teaches at Harvard Law and headed Warren’s advisory committee that made the recommendations to Obama, said the panel worked quickly so that the positions would be filled.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: But, she said, the committee also took caution to follow Warren’s call for nominations with diverse backgrounds: not only in race and gender, but also in their legal backgrounds.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: Gertner said a priority was to find potential judges who did not have the typical background of being a federal prosecutor or coming from a large law firm.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: ''The senator very much wanted to improve the diversity of the bench, not just racial and gender, but with economic diversity, and people who had different histories,'' Gertner said.

column2: Obama nominates
column3: ''There’s a perspective that is missing on the bench, so we were charged with trying to do something about background diversity, and I’m very proud of my senator and very proud of my committee.''

column2: Obama nominates
column3: The federal court in Boston has a vacancy following US District Court Judge Joseph Tauro’s announcement in August that he will go on senior status.

column3: LOS ANGELES - The police here were preparing for another night of protests on Tuesday, and community activists were working to maintain the peace after anger over the acquittal of George Zimmerman in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin turned violent in South Los Angeles on Monday night.

column2: CALL FOR CALM AS LOS ANGELES GIRDS FOR MORE UNREST

ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: JERUSALEM - President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Sunday accepted the resignation of his prime minister, Rami Hamdallah, who had asked to quit two weeks after being sworn into office.

column2: ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: The latest power struggles in the West Bank, where the Palestinian Authority exercises limited self-rule, deepened the image of political disarray, days before Secretary of State John Kerry was expected back in the region to try to revive peace talks with Israel.

column2: ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: But in what appeared to be an effort to project a minimal level of stability, a spokesman for Abbas told the official Palestinian news agency Wafa that Abbas asked Hamdallah to stay on in a caretaker role until a replacement could be found.

column2: ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: Hamdallah had replaced Salam Fayyad, an internationally respected economist who served as prime minister for six years.

column2: ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: Fayyad quit in April, partly because of a dispute over his powers, but he stayed on as a caretaker until Hamdallah’s appointment.

column2: ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: Palestinian officials said that Hamdallah had resigned because of a conflict over his authority and responsibilities, and they suggested that his primary problem was with his two deputy prime ministers.

column2: ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: A university dean and professor of linguistics, Hamdallah took office with no experience in politics or government, but he was known to be close to Fatah, Abbas’ mainstream party.

column2: ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: When Hamdallah was tapped for the post of prime minister, some Palestinian analysts said they expected him to be compliant and not clash with Abbas, an assumption that made Hamdallah’s swift resignation all the more surprising.

column2: ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: Mahdi Abdul Hadi, the director of the Palestinian Academic Society for the Study of International Affairs, an independent research institute in East Jerusalem, said the Palestinian Authority was at “a real impasse,” stuck between the Israeli occupation and halfhearted efforts to reconcile with Hamas, the rival Islamic group that controls the coastal Palestinian territory of Gaza.

column2: ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: “It is not a question of who the prime minister is,” Abdul Hadi said, “but of where the Palestinian Authority is heading.”

column2: ABBAS ACCEPTS PRIME MINISTER'S RESIGNATION
column3: The Palestinian public, which reacted largely with apathy to the political disarray, found some unifying cheer this weekend after a singer from Gaza, Muhammad Assaf, 23, won the title of “Arab Idol” in a popular, pan-Arab singing contest fashioned on the British and U.S. versions.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: GENEVA - The U.N. human rights chief, Navi Pillay, on Friday condemned Iraq’s execution of 42 prisoners over two days this week, denouncing such mass executions as “obscene and inhuman” and warning that they undermined efforts to reduce violence and achieve a more stable society.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: Iraq’s justice system is “too deeply flawed to warrant even a limited use of the death penalty, let alone dozens of executions at a time,” Pillay said in a statement released in Geneva, repeating a view she has expressed on several occasions.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: At least some of the latest executions, which were carried out Wednesday and Thursday, breached international law because Iraq is unable to hold fair trials, Pillay’s spokesman, Rupert Colville, told reporters.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: And Iraq’s decision to proceed with executions Thursday, which was World Day Against the Death Penalty, was “particularly perverse,” Pillay said.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: Iraq’s Justice Ministry said the executed prisoners had been convicted of “terrorist crimes, killing dozens of innocents in addition to other crimes aimed at destabilizing the country, causing chaos and spreading horror.”

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: Pillay also expressed concern about the “dramatic and shocking increase” in Iraq’s resort to the death penalty.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: This week’s executions brought to 140 the number of people executed so far this year, compared with 123 in 2012 and 18 in 2010, the United Nations reported.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: Pillay will be in direct contact with Iraqi authorities in the coming days, Colville said, but in the meantime she urged the government to immediately halt executions and to commute the sentences of about 900 prisoners now held on death row.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: U.N. human rights officials say the integrity of the judicial system has been tainted, citing the numerous reports of confessions obtained through torture and ill-treatment, the weakness of the judiciary and trial procedures that fall far short of international standards.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: They also said some of the offenses for which prisoners are executed did not meet the threshold of “most serious crimes,” which international law sets for the use of the death penalty.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: Iraq’s justification for using the death penalty as a deterrent to terrorism was “clearly exposed as a fallacy” by the sharp rise in civilian casualties over the same period, Pillay noted.

column2: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHIEF CONDEMNS MASS EXECUTIONS IN IRAQ
column3: The rash of recent bombings in the capital, Baghdad, and other parts of the country had driven up civilian casualties to the highest level since 2008, Pillay observed.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: Kodak said Monday that it would spin off its document and personal imaging units to its British pension plan for $650 million in cash and noncash considerations, a move that paves the way for Kodak’s exit from bankruptcy protection.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: Kodak had been seeking to sell off the two imaging operations.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: Two weeks ago, Eastman Kodak announced a plan to sell its document imaging business to Brother of Japan for $210 million, with the provision that it could revisit the deal if it could sell both units together.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: Now the bankrupt film pioneer has struck an even more advantageous deal after a protracted sales process.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: More important, the pension plan will settle its bankruptcy claim of $2.8 billion, paving the way for the company to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the United States.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: On Tuesday, Kodak plans to file a draft plan to emerge from bankruptcy.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: “In one comprehensive transaction, Kodak will realize its previously announced intention to divest its personalized imaging and document imaging businesses and settle its largest legacy liability,” Antonio M. Perez, Kodak’s chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: The company had filed for bankruptcy protection in January 2012 and has been selling off various assets since then.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: In December, Kodak reached an agreement to sell 1,100 digital imaging patents to a consortium of technology companies for $525 million, far less than expected.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: But as part of that sale, Kodak retained a license to use the digital imaging portfolio patents in its future businesses, and for those businesses that it is selling.

column2: KODAK SPINOFFS CLEAR PATH FOR EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
column3: Kodak is being advised by Lazard and the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: Newsweek, the struggling weekly magazine that ceased print publication last year, plans to turn the presses back on.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: The magazine will begin a 64-page, weekly edition in January or February, said Jim Impoco, Newsweek’s editor in chief.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: He said in an interview that Newsweek would depend more heavily on subscribers than advertisers to pay its bills and that readers would pay more for Newsweek than in the past.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: “It’s going to be a more subscription-based model, closer to what The Economist is, compared to what Time magazine is,” Impoco said.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: “We see it as a premium product, a boutique product.”

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: Newsweek’s return to print is a positive sign for a magazine that struggled mightily in the digital age.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: At its height in 1991, the magazine had 3.3 million readers.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: In 2010, Newsweek’s owner, The Washington Post, sold it to billionaire investor Sidney Harman for $1.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: Harman, who also assumed $40 million in liabilities, then merged it with The Daily Beast, the website owned by IAC/InterActiveCorp.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: Editor Tina Brown took control of the combined titles, but the venture failed.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: The traditional Newsweek never properly blended with The Daily Beast.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: Brown announced in October 2012 that Newsweek would no longer publish a magazine, saving $40 million a year, and would continue as an online-only magazine called Newsweek Global.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: Still, removing those print costs did not mean Newsweek had found a solution.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: In May, Brown announced that IAC/InterActiveCorp planned to sell Newsweek, so that the company could focus its attention on The Daily Beast.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: IBT Media - a small, digital media company - bought Newsweek in August.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: In September, Brown stepped down from The Daily Beast and said she was leaving publishing entirely.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: Impoco, who became Newsweek’s editor in September, said that the magazine’s new owner would not have to spend as much money publishing it as the previous owner.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: Impoco said that IBT was negotiating with printers and distributors and hoped to build Newsweek’s circulation to 100,000 in the first year.

column2: NEWSWEEK PLANS RETURN TO FAMILIAR PLATFORM
column3: Since taking the helm, Impoco, a former editor at The New York Times, has made more than two dozen new hires and is looking to expand Newsweek’s international coverage.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: DAKAR, Senegal - Charles Blé Goudé, a crucial ally of Laurent Gbagbo, the Ivory Coast strongman indicted on charges of crimes against humanity, is being sought on similar charges, the International Criminal Court said Tuesday.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: Blé Goudé played a central role in Gbagbo’s efforts to stay in power by force after his defeat in presidential elections in November 2010, recruiting and arming youths who went on to beat and sometimes murder opponents in the economic capital, Abidjan.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: He was known as the “general of the streets,” and the youth militia he founded, the Jeunes Patriotes, or Young Patriots, was notorious for its brutality, extortionate checkpoints and frenzied rallies presided over by Blé Goudé.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: An indictment against him, unsealed Tuesday by the International Criminal Court in The Hague, Netherlands, has been pending since December 2011, eight months after he fled Ivory Coast when Gbagbo, the former president, was ousted by the French military.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: Blé Goudé was subsequently arrested in Ghana and extradited to Ivory Coast in January of this year.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: The indictment accuses him of crimes of humanity including murder and rape and calls him a member of Gbagbo’s inner circle who met with him to receive instructions and formulate plans, playing “a key role in recruiting, enlisting, arming, training and integrating thousands of volunteers” into the army.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: The wounds of the brief but bloody 2010-11 civil war - more than 3,000 people died - in Ivory Coast, in which Blé Goudé participated actively, are not healed.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: Rural warlords who helped bring Gbagbo’s presidential opponent, Alassane Ouattara, to power still play important military and economic roles, notably in smuggling and in other “predatory economic activities,” according to a report by a United Nations group of experts in April that underlined the country’s political fragility.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: Gbagbo’s partisans remain armed; about $400 million in cocoa beans - Ivory Coast is the world’s leading producer and was once West Africa’s economic powerhouse - was lost to smuggling in 2011-12, according to the report.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: Long before the civil war, the Jeunes Patriotes had several times been mobilized against forces perceived to be threatening Gbagbo’s power, including the French and the United Nations, with violent results.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: Blé Goudé is now being held by the authorities in Ivory Coast, and it is not clear whether they will release him to The Hague.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: Eleven days ago they announced that they would not be sending Gbagbo’s wife, Simone, also under indictment, to The Hague, but instead would try her at home.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: Human rights activists in Ivory Coast said they doubted that Blé Goudé could receive a fair trial in that country, pointing out, for instance, that his lawyer there has no access to him.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: In addition, some of the very rebel leaders who helped Ouattara gain power are accused of crimes similar to those Gbagbo and his associates are accused of.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: But so far they have not been arrested.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: “We think justice in Ivory Coast is victors’ justice,” said Hervé Gouamene, Blé Goudé’s lawyer in Abidjan.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: “Everyone knows crimes were committed on the other side, too.

column2: ALLY OF IVORY COAST STRONGMAN SOUGHT BY INTERNATIONAL COURT
column3: There is no impartiality.”

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: SEOUL, South Korea – North Korea said Thursday that its Supreme Court had sentenced a U.S. citizen to 15 years of hard labor for committing hostile acts against its government.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: Kenneth Bae, 44, a Korean-American from Washington state who ran a tour business out of China, was arrested in the special economic zone of Rason in northeastern North Korea in November after leading a group of businessmen there from Yanji, China.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: On Saturday, the North said it was indicting him on charges that he tried to overthrow Pyongyang’s government.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: On Thursday, the North’s official Korean Central News Agency said the Supreme Court had sentenced Bae during a hearing Tuesday.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: The court convicted him of “hostile acts,” a charge less grave than the original charge that prosecutors pressed.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: The crime of trying to overthrow the government could have resulted in the death penalty.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: Under North Korean law, Bae should be transferred to a labor camp within 10 days of the ruling.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: The ruling came amid high tensions between Pyongyang and Washington and could complicate Washington’s diplomatic balancing act as it tries to hold a tough line with North Korea over its nuclear program.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: South Korean human rights advocates have said Bae not only ran tours to North Korea but also was interested in helping orphans there.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: They said security officials in the North might have been offended by pictures of orphans that Bae had taken and stored in his computer.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: North Korea has often used the plight of detained Americans as a bargaining chip in its dealings with Washington.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: Some were freed only after former U.S. presidents traveled to the North to seek their release.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: In 2009, North Korea arrested two U.S. journalists, Laura Ling and Euna Lee, who it said had entered illegally and committed “hostile acts.” They were sentenced to 12 years of hard labor, but were released five months later, after former President Bill Clinton visited Pyongyang, the North’s capital, and met with Kim Jong Il, the leader at the time.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: The North has been locked in a standoff with the United States and South Korea since detonating a nuclear bomb in February.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: Some analysts say the nation’s leader, Kim Jong Un, might be chafing at his inability to shift those two countries, which have refused to offer the North aid in order to relieve tensions, from their tough stance.

column2: NORTH KOREA SENTENCES AMERICAN TO 15 YEARS OF HARD LABOR
column3: In January, Bill Richardson, a former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, tried to see Bae during a private trip to the North, but he said the government had rebuffed him.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: This article is part of TIMES EXPRESS.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: It is a condensed version of a story that will appear in tomorrow’s New York Times.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: MEXICO CITY - A former Mexican governor was sentenced Friday to nearly 11 years in prison in the United States after pleading guilty in New York to a federal charge of conspiring to launder millions of dollars in drug cartel bribes to allow cocaine to move freely through his state.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: Shortly after becoming the governor of Quintana Roo state - popular for its vacation resort Cancún - in 1993, Mario Villanueva Madrid, 65, made the kind of deal U.S. law-enforcement officials have suspected local officials of making more often than they are able to prove.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: Prosecutors said Villanueva had agreed to let the Juárez cartel, then one of the largest and most powerful, to transport cocaine from Colombia through Quintana Roo and on to the United States in exchange for up to $500,000 per shipment.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: Traffickers were free to unload drug shipments at a state government hangar of a local airport, Mexican authorities have said.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: Villanueva - nicknamed El Chueco, or “the Crooked One” - spread his capital through banks in the United States, Switzerland and the Bahamas.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: Mexican authorities first began investigating Villanueva while he was governor.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: Days before his term ended in 1999, he disappeared, but was caught two years later in Cancún, where he was convicted on organized crime and corruption offenses, imprisoned and then extradited in 2010 to the United States, which had indicted him in 2001.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said he had more than $17 million in a number of U.S. accounts that had been seized, including one at Lehman Bros.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: Villanueva pleaded guilty to the federal count in August.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: “With his sentence today, Villanueva Madrid completes his descent from elected government official to corrupted official to incarcerated felon,” said Preet Bharara, the U.S. attorney in Manhattan.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: Villanueva is the latest in a growing list of former Mexican governors making headlines over corruption allegations.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: Andrés Granier, who until December was the governor of Tabasco state, was arrested this week on suspicion of embezzling millions of dollars in state funds.

column2: FORMER MEXICAN GOVERNOR GETS 11 YEARS FOR TAKING DRUG BRIBES
column3: A former governor of Aguascalientes state, Luis Armando Reynoso Femat, is being investigated for malfeasance.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: Kathryn Wasserman Davis, who contributed tens of millions of dollars to cleaning the Hudson River and promoting peace through an organization she founded when she was 100, died Tuesday at her home in Hobe Sound, Fla. She was 106.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: Her death was confirmed by her grandson Christopher Davis.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: Davis donated millions to Scenic Hudson, a group that works to clean the river and its environs, after taking up kayaking in her 90s near her home in Tarrytown, N.Y.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: In 2007, when she turned 100, she founded Davis Projects for Peace, which awards $10,000 grants to humanitarian endeavors around the world initiated by college students.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: About 600 proposals from students of the 90 schools associated with the Davis United World College Scholars Program have been financed so far.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: This year’s projects include an attempt to provide solar-powered lamps to an impoverished county in China.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: For her efforts Davis was awarded the Woodrow Wilson Award for Public Service.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: Davis was also a benefactor of higher education, giving to Ivy League universities such as Harvard and Columbia and particularly to Wellesley College, her undergraduate alma mater, where she created the Davis Museum and Cultural Center.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: Kathryn Stix Wasserman was born in Philadelphia on Feb. 25, 1907.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: She received a bachelor’s degree from Wellesley, in Massachusetts, a master’s in international relations from Columbia University and a doctorate from the University of Geneva in Switzerland.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: A lifelong globetrotter and a Russophile since her first visit to the Caucasus Mountains in 1929, she met the insurance investment magnate Shelby Cullom Davis on a train to Geneva in 1930.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: They were married on Jan. 4, 1932.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: Shelby Davis died in 1994.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: Davis is survived by a daughter, Diana Davis Spencer; a son, Shelby; eight grandchildren; and 11 great-grandchildren.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: She also owned a home in Northeast Harbor, Maine, and supported environmental charities there including the Maine Coast Heritage Trust.

column2: KATHRYN W. DAVIS, HUDSON RIVER BENEFACTOR, DIES AT 106
column3: Her grandson Christopher said that virtually all of the Davis fortune would be left to charity.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: MOSCOW – Aleksei A. Navalny, the opposition leader and one of the most prominent politicians to go on trial in modern Russia, used his first full day in court Wednesday to say that the trial would prove his innocence, even if the judge convicted him.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: The trial, streamed on the Internet, has promised to be an important touchstone in President Vladimir V. Putin’s long career, as prosecutors have not previously indicted a high-profile politician, but it has gotten off to a languid start.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: It began last week in the provincial city of Kirov, east of Moscow.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: Within an hour of opening, however, Judge Sergei A. Blinov granted a request by the defense lawyers for an adjournment so they could better prepare for trial.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: They requested a month, he gave them a week and they appealed.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: A higher court rejected that appeal Tuesday, clearing the way for opening statements to begin Wednesday.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: Navalny, who is a lawyer, spoke at times in his own defense.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: “I am certain my innocence will be clear to everybody who is present in this chamber and everybody watching,” Navalny told the court, according to a transcript posted by the Rapsi legal news agency.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: “To all those involved in the illegal investigation, sooner or later you will face a severe but just punishment.”

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: Others who have challenged Putin have faced prosecution, most notably the Yukos oil tycoon, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, who remains in prison, but the case against Navalny is the first in post-Soviet Russia against a high-profile political figure.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: Navalny is charged with embezzling $500,000 from a state-controlled timber company in Kirov while working as an adviser to the regional governor in 2009.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: Prosecutors initially dismissed the case, but federal officials revived it after Navalny became the most prominent leader of the street protests in Moscow last year.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: He used his first day in court for a flurry of motions seemingly intended to highlight the apparent absurdity of a 4-year-old case in a provincial city far from Moscow surfacing in the wake of last winter’s protests, but ostensibly unrelated to the street protests.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: A spokesman for the Investigative Committee, a branch of the prosecutor’s office, said in an interview in Izvestia newspaper that investigators had focused on Navalny because he was accusing state officials of corruption while claiming to be “clean” himself.

column2: RUSSIAN OPPOSITION LEADER ASSERTS INNOCENCE AT TRIAL
column3: The trial will resume Thursday.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: MEXICO CITY – Guatemala’s highest court on Monday threw out the genocide conviction and prison sentence of the former dictator Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, ruling to rewind the trial to its final days.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: The decision by Guatemala’s Constitutional Court is a dramatic legal victory for Rios Montt, 86, and a blow to human rights advocates who called his conviction a sign that Guatemala’s courts would no longer allow impunity for the country’s powerful.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: Rios Montt was sent to prison immediately after the verdict on May 10 but was transferred to a military hospital three days later for medical tests.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: The decision means that he will return to house arrest, where he had been held since the case against him began in January 2012.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: A three-panel tribunal found him guilty of genocide and crimes against humanity, and he was sentenced to 80 years in prison.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: But Monday’s ruling did not throw out the entire trial.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: Instead, it rolled back the proceedings to April 19, when a complex decision by a pretrial judge sent the trial into disarray.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: The Constitutional Court issued several confusing rulings that the trial judges interpreted to allow them to continue the proceedings.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: Legal experts said it was unlikely that the final days of the trial would be repeated because that would amount to a form of double jeopardy for the former dictator.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: Rios Montt was found to be responsible for a series of massacres and rapes and the forced displacement of the Maya-Ixil ethnic group during his 17-month rule in 1982 and 1983.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: During a month of prosecution testimony, the court heard wrenching descriptions by survivors of the army’s scorched-earth policy through the hamlets of the Mayan highlands.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: His co-defendant, Gen. Jose Mauricio Rodriguez Sanchez, was acquitted.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: The constitutional court’s ruling effectively throws out his acquittal, and it is unclear whether he will be rearrested.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: The attorney general’s office is expected to appeal the court’s 3-2 ruling on Tuesday.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: Although the verdict was celebrated by international human rights organizations, it was controversial in Guatemala.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: The Constitutional Court was the target of a lobbying campaign by opponents of the verdict as it considered several defense injunctions it had failed to rule on during the trial.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: Perhaps the most important campaign was by Guatemala’s powerful business federation, known as Cacif for the initials of its Spanish name.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: Representing the country’s deeply conservative oligarchy, Cacif urged the court to overturn the verdict.

column2: RULING THROWS OUT GENOCIDE CONVICTION OF EX-DICTATOR
column3: The court “has the power in its hands to contribute to the governability and assure an effective rule of law,” the business group said.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: A 21-year-old college student was shot and killed early Friday on Long Island after an armed man broke into the home she shared with her twin sister, held her hostage and then engaged in a gunbattle with police, authorities said.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: The man who forced his way into the home was also killed.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: It was not immediately clear who fired the fatal shots, police said.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: The violence played out in the middle of the night on an ordinarily quiet residential street, only blocks from Hofstra University, where the victim went to school.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: Students who were preparing for their last day of exams awoke to the news that one of their own had been killed.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: The victim, Andrea Rebello, was a junior from Tarrytown, N.Y., and was studying public relations.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: She shared the home with her twin, Jessica, and another young woman, according to the police.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: A young man was also staying at the house at the time.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: The suspect, who was not identified, knocked on the door of the home around 2:15 a.m., and when one of the residents looked to see who was there, he burst in, according to police.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: He was wearing a ski mask and carrying a pistol, police said.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: He held the twin sisters and the young man hostage but let the other woman leave, police said.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: That woman took the opportunity to call 911.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA
column3: “Shortly after our arrival, a shooting took place where the suspect is killed and one of the female victims are killed,” said Deputy Inspector Kenneth Lack of the Nassau County Police Department.

column2: STUDENT FATALLY SHOT DURING HOME INVASION NEAR HOFSTRA

column3: LAGOS (Reuters) - Coca-Cola (KO.N) is moving ahead with plans to take over Nigeria’s leading juice company Chi Ltd and aims to complete the deal early next year, a senior executive told Reuters.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: Coca-Cola crates are pictured in Abuja, Nigeria September 19, 2018.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: REUTERS/Afolabi Sotunde

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: The acquisition for an undisclosed price is one of several steps the U.S. company is taking in a global strategy to diversify from its core business of sugary sodas.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: Last month it agreed to buy Costa coffee for $5.1 billion, and sources familiar with the matter say it is also bidding for GlaxoSmithKline’s (GSK.L) Indian Horlicks nutrition business.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice

column3: Coca-Cola bought a 40 percent stake in the Nigerian juice and snack producer in January 2016, and said at the time it aimed to increase ownership within three years.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: Juice sales form a central plank of the U.S. company’s attempt to offer drinks at a range of price points in Nigeria to improve affordability in a country where Njonjo sees high inflation and modest economic growth in the coming year.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: Focusing on smaller bottles and cans is another way the company is trying to woo cash-strapped consumers in Nigeria, which emerged from its first recession in 25 years in 2017 but continues to suffer from sluggish growth and high inflation.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: “Affordability will start becoming a bigger issue in this market than it was in the past.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: As a company, that is what we need to factor in as we are thinking about the future of our business in Nigeria,” Njonjo said in an interview.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: He pointed to the introduction of a 30 centilitre bottle of Coke Zero for 60 naira ($0.20), compared with the standard 50 centilitre bottle for 80 naira, as just one example.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: Njonjo said the company’s drive to diversify its product range could also give it more flexibility in a market where unemployment is high and the United Nations estimates most of the population of 190 million lives on less than $2 a day.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: “We realize that in certain pack formats you can only go down so low,” he said in an interview at his office in the commercial capital Lagos.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: “But once you start looking at pouches and still products, like juice and drinking yoghurts, that allows you to start accessing much lower price points.”

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice

column3: Njonjo said the purchase of Costa could present a “significant opportunity” in Nigeria, despite the absence of a culture of hot-coffee drinking there.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: “There definitely could be opportunity around ready-to-drink coffee here in Nigeria ... Having iced coffee, blends of dairy and coffee, packaged in different formats,” he said.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: Njonjo said Horlicks, a malt-based hot beverage, was an “interesting proposition” that could be “a significant opportunity on the (African) continent”.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
column3: But while the company was researching drinks from locally relevant ingredients, such as ginger, he said he could not see a market for marijuana drinks - something the company has said it was closely watching in the past.

column3: A memorandum of understanding was being formalized and would be signed in the next few weeks, he said, adding that implementation would begin in the last quarter of this year.

column2: Coca-Cola moving ahead with takeover of Nigeria's Chi juice
