Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: NEW YORK (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - A new investment fund for green businesses and a tool to measure emissions were among the pledges to help governments curb global warming at a summit on climate financing convened by the French president on Wednesday.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: French President Emmanuel Macron speaks at the One Planet Summit in New York, U.S., September 26, 2018.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: Emmanuel Macron called on government and business leaders to invest more in slowing down climate change as he opened the second annual “One Planet” summit in New York.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: “We have to shift one third of the global financing to financing of climate change and new climate action,” he said.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: “So governments, the World Bank, all the development banks, business leaders and investors, it is our job.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: Everybody is waiting for us and everybody today wants us just to accelerate.”

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, said it would help structure a climate fund for investment in green sectors such as renewable energy and low-carbon transportation across Latin America, Asia, and Africa.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: The French and German governments and large philanthropic organizations including The Hewlett Foundation have pledged initial funds to the Climate Finance Partnership, which organizers said would be set up next year.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: The one-day gathering in New York, where world leaders were gathered for the United Nations General Assembly, drew the leaders of global companies as well as more than two dozen heads of state and government.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: The World Bank, which lends to developing countries, announced a platform to pledge $1 billion toward developing battery-storage technology.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: Energy storage is becoming increasingly important as production of renewable energy rises, because the wind might not blow or the sun shine during the peak hours when most consumers turns on their lights and appliances.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: Tech giant Google announced the launch of a tool to generate data on greenhouse gas emissions from road traffic and on the solar capacity of cities, which it captures through its popular mapping service Google Earth.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: “If you cannot measure it you can’t manage it,” said Michael Bloomberg, the former New York mayor who is now the U.N. Secretary General’s special envoy for Cities and Climate Change.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: Cities worldwide account for more than 70 percent of carbon dioxide emissions.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: Climate change is causing more frequent and severe flooding, droughts, storms and heatwaves as average global temperatures rise to new records, sea ice melts in the Arctic and sea levels rise.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: The second “One Planet” summit took place nearly three years after almost 200 governments agreed the Paris accord to end the fossil-fuel era this century and limit further global warming to well below 2 degrees above pre-industrial times.

column2: Businesses pledge climate change action at New York summit
column3: U.S. President Donald Trump weakened the pact last year when he said the United States, the world’s second biggest greenhouse gas polluter after China, would pull out.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: SOMETIMES it feels as if there is a red state-blue state divide when it comes to hedge funds.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Some people believe that if permitted to remain free from the shackles of dangerous government oversight, hedge funds can help solve problems from underfunded pensions to inept corporate management.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: This group tends to include hedge fund employees and hedge fund investors.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Others believe that hedge funds are sinister forces that capitalize on superior information -- possibly obtained illegally -- and are hell-bent on pillaging the financial system to corner the market on luxury cars and palatial real estate.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: This group includes much of the news media and the Connecticut attorney general.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Yet hedge funds are neither saviors nor Satan.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: There are more than 9,000 funds that vary greatly in the kinds of investments they make, returns they seek and strategies they employ.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: One of the few things they have in common -- other than gigantic paychecks when their returns are good -- is that the funds have become a more accepted fixture in the financial landscape.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: A number of recent studies show that hedge fund investors are satisfied with the performance of their investments, even if that performance appears on paper to be less than stellar.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Widespread demand for risk-adjusted returns of 8 to 10 percent ensures that the money spigot will stay turned on.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: (Risk adjusted means that the portfolio is hedged.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: If the market slumps, the fund's returns should not.)

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: For example, the top performers of the 2007 Commonfund Benchmarks Study of Educational Endowments, a survey of college, university and other educational endowments and foundations in the United States, were almost 50 percent invested in ''alternatives'' -- hedge funds, private equity, real estate, distressed debt, energy and natural resources and venture capital.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Hedge funds constituted the largest portion -- 44 to 70 percent -- of the alternatives category.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Average returns for the foundations and endowments that responded to the survey were 10.6 percent, while the leaders posted returns of more than 16.8 percent.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: The top 10 percent of performers among the endowments allocated 49 percent of their money to alternatives, compared with 11 percent for fixed income, 18 percent for domestic equity and 21 percent for international equity.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: The top quartile of performers also show a heavy weighting to alternatives: 46 percent, compared with 11 percent for fixed income, 20 percent for international equity and 21 percent for domestic equity.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Even though hedge funds represented the bulk of investment dollars, their returns were lackluster.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: In 2006, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had a total return, when dividends were reinvested, of 15.8 percent.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Overall returns for alternatives averaged 14.6 percent.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Energy and natural resources produced a stunning return of 40 percent; distressed debt, 26 percent; and private equity, 19 percent.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Hedge funds turned out only 10.6 percent.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: But investors did not seem to be bothered.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: ''It was nice to see hedge funds were doing what they are supposed to do,'' said John S. Griswold Jr. executive director of the Commonfund Institute, a research organization dedicated to educating the nonprofit community about investing.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: ''They should lag a rapidly rising stock market,'' he explained, ''because hedging has a cost.''

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: The money continues to flow into hedge funds.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Hedge Fund Research, a Chicago-based research firm, estimates that $110 billion flowed into new funds through November.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: A study released by Deutsche Bank yesterday surveyed investors who represent $900 billion of the total $1.4 trillion in the industry and predicted that $110 billion will flow into the sector in 2007.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: ''I don't think demand will slow down anytime soon unless we see a lot of disasters,'' Mr. Griswold said.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: ''There's a bit of a herd mentality here.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: If you are not in hedge funds, people look funny at you, like, 'Why aren't you?'

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Heavy investments in alternatives and hedge funds in particular have paid off for endowments.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: More than 79 percent of the growth in endowments with assets of $500 million to $1 billion resulted from investment returns (as opposed to gifts, for example).

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Institutions with more than $1 billion derived more than 75 percent of their returns from their investments, according to the Commonfund survey.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: A separate study conducted by Casey, Quirk & Associates last fall also showed satisfied customers.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: About 72 percent of respondents said that hedge fund returns came within 1 percentage point of their target.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: A surprising 25 percent of investors said they did better than expected: 19 percent exceeded their target by 1 to 5 percentage point.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Only 3 percent said their investment underperformed.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: There are other reasons to expect robust growth.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Pension funds are wading in, raising their investments in alternatives in general and hedge funds in particular.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: The Casey, Quirk study estimated that institutions globally will add $1 trillion in money by 2010, compared with $360 billion today.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: The growing role of institutions has tempered expectations about returns: 80 percent of those surveyed by Casey, Quick said they expected returns below 10 percent, with the bulk anticipating 8 to 9 percent.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Only 20 percent expected more than 10 percent.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: Megabucks compensation, meanwhile, still draws talent to hedge funds.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: ''Hedge funds are here to stay because of the compensation,'' Mr. Griswold said.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: ''This is where the best and brightest managers are gravitating to.''

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: The unforgiving nature of the industry means that those who do not perform will be booted out.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: According to Hedge Fund Research, since the beginning of 2005 almost 1,300 hedge funds have closed.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: During that time, more than 3,000 have been started.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: There will be more Amaranth Advisors (which was based in Greenwich, Conn.) -- funds that blow up because of bad and greedy bets.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: There will be frauds and there may be a market meltdown.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
column3: But alternative investing -- in private companies, with hedge fund managers who more aggressively try to time the markets, and in forests and wineries, is thriving.

column2: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: NASHVILLE, the United States, Sept. 26 (Xinhua) -- "They should put a 'federal tariff tax' on receipts, so people can understand that they are ultimately paying for the price of trade wars," Glenn Anderson, who runs the Tennessee Medical Cannabis Trade Association, said at a recent gathering here.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: The gathering, held at the Tennessee Brew Works last Thursday, was aimed at voicing concerns and raising awareness over recent tariff measures from Washington.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: During the event, speakers as well as members of the audience shared personal experiences, observations, and at times satire regarding how the tariffs negatively impacted their lives.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: One speaker on the podium was 38-year-old farmer Brandon Whitt, who manages a 200-year-old farm, Batey Farms, not far from Nashville.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: Whitt, an eighth-generation farmer, said the abrupt imposition of tariffs this year made him fear that he might have to give up his farm.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: Batey Farms produces a variety of crops, such as soybeans, corn and wheat, and raises a large number of pigs.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: A large part of the farm's produce ends up in overseas markets.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: But due to the trade frictions the United States has initiated with other countries, overseas demand for U.S. agricultural products has tanked, driving down the prices for soybeans and pork, among others.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: "I'm making 50 bushels an acre of soybeans, but that's 50 bushels per acre at a two-dollar decrease," Whitt said.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: "I've done absolutely nothing wrong and lost 100 dollars an acre in profit."

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: "I'd like to carry our administration with me when I go to cash my grain checks and watch me deposit those checks and then immediately turn around and drive across town to my lender, whom I have to pay off except I'm missing 20, 30, 40 percent of that money to be able to pay off that operating loan," Whitt lamented.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: Aside from damages, the uncertainties that come with the tariffs are also making farmers very uncomfortable.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: "Nobody has a crystal ball.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: I don't think our officials in Washington have a crystal ball at all at this point right now.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: I think we're just kind of flying by the seat of our pants," Whitt said, in an apparent jab at the U.S. government.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: The situation is almost like before the 2008 recession, Whitt said, adding that now people are just as discouraged to invest and hire as they were 10 years ago.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: Whitt said that as a farmer, he shouldn't be diverting his energy to learn about foreign policy or trade, but the status quo has left him with no choice.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: "I don't like politics, but I have to get into politics," Whitt said, adding that Washington's ever-changing positions and frequent threats have made the situation more challenging.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: Whitt also rejected the idea of subsidies, calling them a "band-aid handout."

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: Accompanying Whitt on stage was Steven Livingston, a professor of political science at Middle Tennessee State University, who said farms are not the only ones hit by the tariffs in the state.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: All the leading industries in the state, such as the automotive, chemicals, paper, plastic and boat manufacturing industries will all be negatively impacted by higher trade barriers, Livingston said, estimating a 1-billion-dollar loss for the state in foreign trade.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: The message resonated with those off stage.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: Josh Beatty, who owns a real estate company, said he came to the event to learn more about the potential damage of tariffs.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: "A lot of the lumber and steel I use in construction are imported, so I want to be prepared for any potential changes," Beatty said, who was on his first visit to Nashville from Minneapolis.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: The gathering, one in a series of town hall meetings under the banner "Tariffs hurt the Heartland," was organized by the activist groups Americans for Free Trade and Farmers for Free Trade.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: Brian Kuehl, executive director of Farmers for Free Trade, told Xinhua that the purpose of the meetings was to raise awareness of the impacts of tariffs and trade frictions and provide a platform for people to share their opinions and stories.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: "The reason we are focusing on the heartland is because the heartland is hurt by the trade war and in the 2016 elections the heartland supported President (Donald) Trump.

column2: Feature: Tennessee farmers, business owners, trade advocates lament Trump’s tariffs - Xinhua
column3: We hope President Trump will also support the heartland," Kuehl said.

column3: Adjusting supply chains is "not that simple in a global economy.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: Businesses make production or sourcing decisions months and years in advance, and they rely on very complex supply chains," she said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "Retailers and other importers could not easily or quickly switch to domestic sources because they do not exist on the scale that would be needed," she said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "Even if there were to be an eventual switch to U.S. sourcing, it would take years to build up a base to support it.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: And for many products subject to tariffs, China is the sole source of U.S. imports.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: No alternative sources exist," she said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: WHAT ARE CHINA'S ADVANTAGES?

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: As the new wave of tariffs which came on top of the 50 billion dollars' worth already taxed earlier this year begins to make China look more expensive, few other places around the world could match China's advantages -- its highly skilled labor and the reliability of the supply chains.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: Before the tariffs, some labor-intensive manufacturers have already started leaving China as the country's wages have risen for the past 10 to 15 years in a row, Mary Lovely, an American professor of economics and an expert on trade with China, told Xinhua in an interview.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: They have already seen apparel, footwear, toys, sporting goods and some electronics moving elsewhere in Asia.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "These are things that we would expect because as China develops, the rest of East Asia or the poorer countries of East Asia also expect to be pulled along with that train," said Lovely, who is a professor of economics at Syracuse University and a nonresident senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "China is an engine of growth for the region, so none of that is surprising," she said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "The tariffs will likely accelerate that," she said, adding that firms that are thinking about moving will probably go ahead because these additional 25 percent tariffs will make it very tough for them to compete with subcontractors in other countries that won't face these tariffs.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "And that puts competitive pressure on China so it will accelerate changes in global value chains," she said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: But not all firms can do that, she said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: For one thing, companies produce or purchase higher value items from China, which are made by more highly skilled labor and are reflecting relationships that have developed, she said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "Many of those supply chains are certified by the FDA (Food and Drug Administration) in the United States or other regulatory bodies and moving them is difficult," she said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "So there's a great deal of uncertainty and firms are really in doubt as to what they should do because moving the supply chain is costly.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: Before you want to do that, you want to make sure that it's something that you really need to do," she said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: She warned that "the uncertainty causes a kind of paralysis on investment and we are already seeing some slowdown in investment flows."

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: According to data from the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis released in July, net foreign direct investment dropped to 51.3 billion dollars in the first quarter, a 37 percent fall from the same quarter in 2017 and a 65 percent decline from the first quarter of 2016.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: UNINTENDED CONSEQUENCES FOR U.S.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: The Texas-based arts and crafts retail chain, Michaels, has warned in early September that retail prices could be hit by the U.S. administration's new round of tariffs on Chinese imports.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: An estimated 400 million dollars of its product costs would be subject to the new round of tariffs, Chief Executive Officer Chuck Rubin told a Goldman Sachs Group Inc. retail conference in New York on Sept. 5.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: But the cost of goods to fill its shelves is not what annoys the largest American arts and crafts retail chain most as Michaels has "a lot of levers" it can pull to mitigate the impact, Rubin said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: While the company with a large bulk of its goods coming from China is looking into shifting manufacturing to other countries, he said, "There is virtually no possibility of moving manufacturing into the U.S."

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: Companies that are forced to rethink their sourcing may find their hands tied as "supply chains are built by companies with great care and substantial analysis," said Professor Robert Sicina, executive in residence of Kogod School of Business at the Washington-based American University.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "To disrupt them is to negatively impact the confidence firms have in the U.S. having a consistent policy," Sicina told Xinhua in an interview.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "Without consistency, firms will move their supply chains away from the U.S., not towards it.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: This is just one example of the unintended consequences of President (Donald) Trump's actions," said Sicina, who has 30 years of experience in senior executive positions at big banks and various entrepreneurial endeavors.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "The supply chain is always going to move to where the economics are best," he said, adding that "the economics are overwhelmingly in favor of China."

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: Another major, long-term unintended consequence, Sicina said, is that "foreign investment in the U.S. will also be disrupted because of the tariffs."

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: When investment flows into the United States, foreign investors have to consider its trade policies, as extra tariffs will impact investors' ability to import raw materials and export their products, Sicina said.

column2: Xinhua Headlines: Trump's tariffs disruptive to supply chains, but shifting them away from China won't be easy - Xinhua
column3: "Trump's trade war is to curb foreign investment in the future, because they're going to lack confidence that the U.S. will play by the rules, because it's now breaking the rules of fair trade in expectation of cutting a better deal with China," he said.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: MANILA, Sept. 4 (Xinhua) -- The Asian Development Bank (ADB) launched on Tuesday its first Trade Finance Scorecard, a new tool to address market gaps stemming from the unintended consequences of global measures to fight money-laundering and terrorism.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: "Preventing criminals and terrorists from exploiting the global financial system is critically important," said ADB's Head of Trade and Supply Chain Finance Steven Beck.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: "But these regulations can also undermine jobs and growth at small businesses and developing countries.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: This new scorecard will open a channel of dialogue among stakeholders to help prevent crime and terrorism while financing growth and job creation," Beck said.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: The ADB said the Trade Finance Scorecard focuses on issues related to the interpretation, implementation, and compliance with regulations designed to curb money laundering and the financing of terrorism in the context of correspondent banking and trade financing.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: "The scores are assigned on two levels.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: Firstly, at a macro level, to identify characteristics of effective regulation that could be strengthened.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: Secondly, at a micro transactional level, to highlight specific challenges that can be addressed in the shorter term," the ADB said.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: The ADB added "Elements of effective regulation outlined in the first level are scored out of 10 on seven criteria: consistency (4), risk alignment (3), design (2), stakeholder communication (5), technology and data (5), enforcement (4), and quality control (3).

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: These criteria are used to assess five working-level issues in the second level."

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: The ADB said the scorecard is based on feedback from industry leaders and regulators and will complement existing tools such as the Financial Action Task Force's recommendations against money laundering and terrorist financing.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: "The scores are illustrative and directional," said Beck, stressing the need to have "better ways of addressing these issues, and we see the scorecard as the start of a process of engagement on this difficult subject."

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: ADB's Trade Finance Program (TFP) closes market gaps by providing guarantees and loans to over 200 partner banks to support trade, helping companies across Asia to engage in import and export activities.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: In 2017, TFP supported 4.5 billion U.S. dollars in trade through 3,505 transactions.

column2: ADB unveils new tool to boost access to trade finance - Xinhua
column3: Its financial support is complemented by regular workshops and seminars to increase knowledge and expertise in trade finance products, anti-money laundering, and risk management.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: ROME, Sept. 28 (Xinhua) -- Financial markets were on their heels Friday, a day after Italy's populist, anti-establishment government announced it would widen its budget deficit in order to finance costly electoral promises.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Thursday's blueprint says the government would widen the 2019 budget deficit to an estimated 2.4 percent of the gross domestic product, almost surely putting the country on a collision course with the European Union (EU).

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: The EU has called for Italy to focus on paying down the government's deficit, the highest in the bloc in absolute terms and the second highest when measured as a percentage of gross domestic product.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: The 2.4-percent figure is around three times higher than the estimates put forward by the previous government, which ended its term May 31.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: It is also far above the 1.6-perfect figure promised by Minister of Finance Giovanni Tria.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Still, it is below the more than 3.0-percent deficit the government said it wanted in August.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Tria, a political independent not associated with either of the political parties backing the Giuseppe Conte government, reportedly vowed to resign if he lost the battle over the budget.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: There were no immediate signs Tria would follow through with his threat on Friday, but the Italian media reported it could still happen.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: In absolute terms, the difference between Tria's 1.6-perfect deficit promise and the 2.4-percent target announced Thursday is around 175 billion euros (205 billion U.S. dollars) in extra spending.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: That figure is more than the gross domestic products of 15 of the 28 EU member states, including Greece, the only EU country more indebted than Italy.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Italy has the third largest economy in the 19-nation euro currency union.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Luigi Di Maio, Italy's minister of labor and the head of the Five-Star Movement, said the extra spending would pay for itself through higher economic growth.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: "We must explain to markets that there are so many smart investments inside this 2.4-percent figures that we will be able to grow the economy as much as we want to," Di Maio said in a press conference.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: But analysts were less convinced.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: "Before the figure was announced I thought that Tria's 1.6-percent figure was not likely, but that 2.4 or above would mean outright war with the European Union," Riccardo Puglisi, a political economist with the University of Pavia, told Xinhua.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: "At close to 2.0-percent, it would have been a skirmish.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: But 2.4 percent is bad news."

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Ugo Arrigo, an economics and statistics professor with Bicocca University in Milan, said the decision was likely based on politics and not economics.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: "Really, the deficit should have been 1.6 or 1.7 percent," Arrigo said in an interview.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: "Above 2 is trouble because it means the government is putting electoral promises above sustainability."

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Among the costly promises put forth by the four-month-old government: a universal basic income for all Italian citizens, an earlier retirement age for workers, and a flat tax for Italian companies.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: The spending measures alone are expected to add at least 100 billion euros to the deficit.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Financial markets responded badly to the news: both because of the fiscal implications of the 2019 budget and the likelihood it could ultimately destabilize the government, especially if Tria stepped down.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: In trading Friday, the first session after the latest developments, bond yields surged as much as 12 percent higher, reaching a yield of 3.35 percent in midday trading for the benchmark ten-year bonds.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: That is approaching their highest yield since 2014.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Higher yields for bonds reflect investor nervousness, and they increase the government's costs when it borrows money.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: The MIB-30 index of blue chip stocks also took a hit, falling 3.8 percent, with 27 of 30 issues losing ground.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Even the euro currency took a step back, losing around 1.5 percent of its value against the U.S. dollar, its weakest level in three weeks.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: The full budget, including details for the spending plans, will be submitted to the EU next month.

column2: News Analysis: Italy 2019 budget plan unnerves markets, ignores EU austerity calls - Xinhua
column3: Brussels could reject the measure, which would send the government back to the drawing board to restart negotiations.

column3: BEIJING, Sept. 12 (Xinhua) -- China will roll out the decoupling of business licenses and operation permits as a nationwide program starting this November, and further cut production permits for industrial goods by over one third in an effort to ease corporate burdens, the State Council's executive meeting chaired by Premier Li Keqiang decided on Wednesday.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: It was later implemented in all of Shanghai.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: It was pointed out at the Wednesday meeting that introducing the decoupling nationwide constitutes a key step in implementing the broader reform of government functions.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: The reform will help improve the business environment, energize the market and catalyze stronger development.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: "Decoupling business licenses and operation permits is the right way to go, as it meets both corporate and public needs.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: It is a necessary part of the reform of our market economy system, and a step we must take," Li said.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: The Wednesday meeting announced that starting from November 10 this year, an approach of reduced number of required permits and certificates after receiving business licenses will be applied nationwide to the first batch of some 100 business-related government approval items.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: Items that are no longer necessary for administrative approval or are eligible for self-improvement through market forces will become approval-free or require registration only.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: The practice of notification commitment shall be applied to those government review items that need to stay, yet any non-compliance with the permitting requirements can be redressed by government oversight.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: Under such practice, a market entity shall be approved for business activities when it commits to complying with all the permitting requirements.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: A company violating this commitment shall see its license revoked and face heavy penalties.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: Improved access services will be applied to the government review items concerning public security and public health where notification commitment does not fit.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: However, efforts will be made to reduce the required materials, streamline procedures, and cut the reviewing time to keep the permitting process transparent and make market access easier for start-up and innovative businesses.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: The Wednesday meeting also decided to cancel the required production permits for 14 types of industrial goods.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: Production permits for goods relating to public security, public health and environmental protection shall be replaced by mandatory certification.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: A list of these products will be compiled and released to the public, and certification charges shall be funded by public finance.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: "This reform of decoupling business licenses and operation permits should be well-paced as realities differ across the country.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua
column3: The reform may move faster in places where conditions are fully in place, yet no one-size-fits-all approach should be applied," Li stressed.

column2: Decoupling of business licenses, operation permits to go nationwide - Xinhua

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: WANTED: Central banker who can curb ''irrational exuberance'' among stock market investors.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Statesmen with international credibility preferred.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Availability soon.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Too bad Alan Greenspan, who does not speak Chinese, can't apply.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: One of the biggest challenges for Chinese leaders these days lies in when and how to rein in the country's soaring stock market and, just as important, whom to pick as the next governor of the central bank.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: The challenges are closely intertwined.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Like Mr. Greenspan nearly a decade ago, Zhou Xiaochuan, the current governor of the People's Bank of China, faces the knotty question of what to do about a speculative mania that has drawn millions of people with limited investing experience into betting their savings on the stock market.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Mr. Greenspan, now 81, struggled to contain the tech stock boom, issuing his famous ''irrational exuberance'' warning in December 1996 only to watch the American market keep rising and finally collapse in early 2000.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: He tried his hand at forecasting Chinese stocks on Wednesday, telling an audience in Madrid by satellite that the Chinese market was ''clearly unsustainable'' and could undergo a ''dramatic contraction.''

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: After setting records on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, the A shares, those traded in yuan, fell 0.47 percent in Shanghai and 0.6 percent in Shenzhen on Thursday as investors responded to the warning.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: But the warning was not news to Mr. Zhou and other Chinese officials.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: The central bank, securities regulators and prominent business executives have all been cautioning investors that buying stocks is not a guaranteed path to riches -- all with less apparent effect than Mr. Greenspan.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: ''Will the Shanghai market correct at some stage?

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Yes, that's inevitable,'' said Michael R. P. Smith, the chief executive of HSBC's extensive Asian operations.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: ''Valuations are too high, I think; you can't sustain P/E multiples of 40, 50 times.''

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: The economy is booming, but fairly low inflation, 3 percent, also makes for a conundrum similar to what Mr. Greenspan faced as Federal Reserve chairman: it is harder for Mr. Zhou to justify raising interest rates significantly.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: For Mr. Zhou, there is a further complication in that he faces considerable uncertainty about his personal future.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Five years into his current job, he turns 60 next year, and so by Chinese standards is due for a transfer or promotion.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: ''It could come at any time; I tend to think it will happen before the 17th Party Congress,'' expected in October or November, said Victor Shih, a Chinese banking specialist at Northwestern.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Whoever succeeds Mr. Zhou confronts one of the toughest challenges of any financial policy maker.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Chinese families eager to make money are opening brokerage accounts around the country, with the number of new accounts rocketing from several thousand a day two years ago to nearly 300,000 a day this month.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Investors leaving a Shanghai brokerage firm on Wednesday were exuberant, as the Shanghai A share index closed at 4,354.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Chen Zhiwei, a restaurant chef, said, ''With more new stocks listed, the bullish trend will keep going until the index hits 15,000.''

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Like Mr. Greenspan in the heat of the Internet frenzy, Mr. Zhou and his colleagues in the Chinese government have been cautious about trying to pop the bubble themselves.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: The Chinese government chose administrative measures, instead of market forces like higher interest rates, to prevent the economy from overheating in 2004 and to curb real estate speculation over the last two years.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: The government has taken a few such measures this year, like investigating fund managers to make sure that they do not engage in self-dealing at the expense of their clients, and requiring this week that new brokerage customers sign forms acknowledging that they understand the risks of stocks.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: But stocks sailed higher on Wednesday after an announcement by the finance ministry and State Administration of Taxation that the government had no plans to raise taxes on share transactions, an approach the government has sometimes taken in the past to curb speculation.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Cash is pouring into the stock market partly because money is pouring into China in general.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: With the Chinese government intervening heavily in currency markets to hold down the value of the yuan against the dollar, China is on course for a surplus this year of up to $400 billion in the current account, the broadest measure of trade.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: The Chinese leadership has shown considerable caution in allowing the currency to appreciate.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Mr. Zhou declared Wednesday morning that gradualism would remain China's policy as it pursues a long-term strategy of making the yuan more ''flexible.''

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Chinese officials frequently refer to flexibility in describing a willingness to see more intraday volatility in the yuan, which remains tightly linked to the dollar.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: But that does not necessarily mean faster appreciation of the yuan.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Raising interest rates, a conventional cure for asset speculation, runs the risk of attracting even more foreign investment to China.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: The People's Bank of China has raised interest rates only four times in the last 13 months, while also raising eight times the percentage of assets that commercial banks must keep as reserves at the central bank.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Partly because the People's Bank of China does not have nearly the same independence as the Federal Reserve and partly because Chinese economic policy makers have shunned the celebrity surrounding many of their overseas counterparts, Mr. Zhou has not attracted as much attention as Mr. Greenspan.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: But now he is the subject of a guessing game about possible successors -- and about the extent to which career jockeying may make public officials leery of unpopular decisions.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: The most commonly cited potential governors are Shang Fulin, the chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission; Guo Shuqing, Communist Party secretary of the China Construction Bank; and Wu Xiaoling, who is the central bank's senior deputy governor but at 60 may already be deemed too old to succeed Mr. Zhou.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Mr. Zhou was president of China Construction Bank and then chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission before taking over leadership of the central bank, so Mr. Shang and Mr. Guo could each be viewed as possibly following in his footsteps.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: As for Mr. Zhou himself, he is cited by some experts as a contender to rise as high as deputy prime minister of China -- if he can stay popular a few more months.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: But a possible slump in the stock market could hurt Mr. Zhou's future prospects -- even if damage to the broader economy may be limited.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Some experts, like Jonathan Anderson, the chief Asia economist at UBS, suggest that because the rising stock market seems to have had little effect on the rate of economic growth over the last year and a half, it may not have much effect going down.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: ''It's very hard indeed to see where the negative growth impact would come from,'' he said in a research report on Thursday, noting that equities form a tenth of total household and business wealth in China.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: As he left a Shanghai brokerage firm on Wednesday, Wang Jianping, a 52-year-old driver, said that he invested only his own savings in the stock market and never borrowed to buy shares.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: ''If I make money, that's great -- if I lose money, it won't hurt my quality of life and it will be O.K.,'' he said.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: ''If I don't make money on the investment in my lifetime, I'll leave it to my children and grandchildren.''

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: The bigger worry, but much harder to calculate, lies in whether the country's banks have unintentionally or secretly lent heavily to stock market speculators who would not be able to repay their loans if the market collapsed.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: Chinese banking regulations bar banks from issuing margin loans directly to stock market investors.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: But banks are allowed to lend to securities firms, which in turn provide margin financing.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: State-controlled media have also reported this year that regulators are looking into whether stock speculators are misrepresenting their intentions to banks, claiming that they need loans for real estate or other purposes.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: For lack of data, credit analysts have been unable to assess the scale of bank exposure to the stock market.

column2: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
column3: ''We can't see it,'' said Charlene Chu, an analyst in the Beijing office of Fitch Ratings, ''on the balance sheets.''

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: MILAN (Reuters) - Italy’s political crisis risks undoing years spent rebuilding the country’s banks, undermining the value of their assets, choking off access to funding and rekindling euro exit fears.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Renewed doubts over the single currency have chilled Italy’s bond markets and reawakened the spectre of capital flight that shook Italian banks during the 2011-2012 sovereign crisis.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: As a result, Italy’s lenders .FTIT8300 have lost more than a fifth of their market value in just two weeks, tracking a fall in its bonds as an anti-establishment coalition sought, and failed, to form a government.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Before the political storm, Italy’s banks had been outperforming euro zone rivals after reducing a bad loan burden that had threatened to cripple them.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: And encouraged by Italy’s economic upturn, hedge funds had even piled into the country’s mid-tier lenders, betting on them as the last European recovery play.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: But the prospect of snap elections after Italy’s president on Sunday vetoed the coalition’s eurosceptic economy minister has deepened a sell-off on fears of a de facto referendum on the euro and a further boost to anti-establishment parties.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: “Risks perceived by investors have risen sharply and that is why they are knocking down the value of Italian banks, which even before the latest turmoil traded below their book values,” said Andrea Resti, a professor at Milan’s Bocconi University and an adviser on banking supervision to the European Parliament.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: A 2.3 trillion euro public debt pile, the world’s third-largest, poses a direct threat to the banks, which face steep losses on 352 billion euros of domestic bond holdings after Italy’s benchmark yield hit a four-year high.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Despite a 75 billion euro drop from their post-recession peak of 360 billion euros, problem loans in Italy still account for around 14 percent of total bank lending.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Claudio Scardovi a managing director at Alix Partners said a lagging property rebound was still likely to draw investors to Italy in the face of real estate bubbles in Britain, the Nordics and to some degree in France.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: “A property investment has an at least five-year horizon: just as the economy was growing again there are doubts about its mid-term prospects,” Castelli said.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: MID-MARKET MAYHEM

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Mid-sized lenders, such as Banco BPM (BAMI.MI), UBI Banca (UBI.MI) and BPER Banca (EMII.MI), are seen as more vulnerable to the turmoil because they lag big players like Intesa Sanpaolo (ISP.MI) and UniCredit (CRDI.MI) in cutting bad loans.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Italy’s 10th-largest bank Credito Valtellinese (PCVI.MI) has been among the worst hit, even though just ahead of the March election it managed to raise eight times its market value in a share sale and gain 35 percent in value in its aftermath.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Shares in Creval, which has one of the highest sovereign exposures relative to its capital and a high bad loan burden, are 11 percent below the 0.10 euros at which it sold new shares.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Analysts warn that smaller Italian lenders are also the most at risk from rising financing costs.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Wholesale funding markets have effectively shut down for Italian banks and traders say they will take a long while to reopen.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Italy’s strongest bank Intesa SanPaolo (ISP.MI) placed a 10-year bond IT178534017= after the election at 77 basis points over the swap rate.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: This now trades with a 200 basis point spread, showing how conditions have worsened.

column2: Political storm threatens Italian bank recovery
column3: Although tight funding markets are not an immediate concern because most banks are awash with liquidity, they do raise a question mark over plans by state-owned Monte dei Paschi di Siena (BMPS.MI) and smaller rival Banca Carige (CRGI.MI) to rebuild their Tier 2 capital buffers with hybrid debt.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: MANY investors have been heeding market strategists' advice to reduce portfolio risk by putting more money into stable, high-quality, dividend-paying stocks.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: But instead of plowing this money into large-capitalization companies based in the United States, investors have redirected much of it into shares of blue-chip foreign companies based largely in Western Europe and Japan.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: Indeed, foreign large-cap blend funds -- which primarily invest in blue-chip growth and value stocks in developed markets -- were the most popular category of funds through the first 11 months of 2006, according to the Financial Research Corporation in Boston.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: Foreign large-blend funds attracted $43.8 billion of net new money during this stretch.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: By comparison, highflying diversified emerging-market stock funds attracted $6.6 billion and domestic large-blend funds drew $4 billion, according to Financial Research.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: But does investing in blue chips abroad achieve the same results for a portfolio as investing in big, high-quality domestic stocks?

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: The answer is still no, given the currency risks that you inevitably take on when investing abroad.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: Yet a growing number of people argue that foreign and domestic stocks are becoming more alike, given the increased correlation among the world's markets.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: Since 1970, for example, the Morgan Stanley Capital International EAFE index, for European, Australian and Far Eastern stocks, has returned 11.6 percent a year, on average.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: That is nearly identical to the annualized gain of 11.2 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index of domestic blue chips.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: But keep in mind that those slightly higher gains came with slightly higher risk, as foreign stocks on their own are still more volatile than domestic equities.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: Sometimes, a modest dose of a risky asset can make an entire portfolio less volatile.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: From 1970 to 2005, a 100 percent stock portfolio invested in the S.& P. 500 would have earned 11.1 percent, annualized, according to S.& P. And that is with a so-called standard deviation -- a popular measure of volatility -- of 16.8.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: But by moving 25 percent of that money from the S.& P. 500 to the EAFE index, the portfolio would have earned 11.4 percent a year, on average, with a slightly lower standard deviation of 16.4.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: Add too much, however, and more volatility enters the mix.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: In this case, had 75 percent of the equity stake been invested in the EAFE index and 25 percent in the S.& P. 500, the portfolio would have earned the same 11.4 percent, annualized, from 1970 to 2005.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: But the portfolio's volatility would have shot up to 19.1.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: This shows that while the global markets may be moving more in sync, ''the world markets aren't completely integrated yet,'' said James D. Peterson, vice president of the Schwab Center for Investment Research in San Francisco.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: Consider the recent performance of foreign and domestic blue chips.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: Over the last five years, the average foreign large-blend fund returned 13.8 percent a year, on average, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund tracker, as many foreign economies have grown faster than that of the United States and as the dollar has weakened of late.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: By comparison, domestic large-cap blend funds advanced only 6.3 percent a year, on average, during this stretch.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: And last year, foreign blue-chip funds soared 25.1 percent, beating the returns of domestic blue-chip funds by more than 10 percentage points.

column2: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
column3: Arguably, much of the investor interest in foreign blue chips can be attributed to their outperformance, not to their similarities to their domestic counterparts.

From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: As the court-appointed guardian and self-described fixer of some of America's most wayward companies, Richard C. Breeden, the former top securities regulator, is considered a pillar of corporate ethics and governance.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Now he trying to become another paragon -- that of savvy investor in troubled companies.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: And in the coming months he will face his first major test: taking on the Applebee's International restaurant chain in a proxy fight.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Breeden's fledgling advocacy hedge fund, Breeden Partners, which owns a 5.2 percent stake in Applebee's, began its battle last month, when Mr. Breeden nominated four close friends to its board.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Hedge funds, the lucrative private investment pools for institutions like endowments and pensions, and for the wealthy, are nearly always managed by former Wall Street traders or money managers.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Breeden -- a Harvard-trained securities lawyer -- has no investing experience.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: But he is seeking to bring his knowledge of securities laws and corporate governance into investing in underperforming companies.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Some in the business are skeptical.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: ''I guess I wonder, how does a guy with no investment management experience run a hedge fund?''

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: asked Philip Goldstein of Bulldog Investors, which runs hedge funds similar in style and intent to that of Mr. Breeden.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: ''You get the guys leaving Goldman Sachs and raising $2 billion, but this is even more astonishing -- he doesn't have a track record.''

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Goldstein added that ''it's kind of like starting at the top -- you'd think you'd want to work at a hedge fund for a while.''

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: But what Mr. Breeden may lack in investing experience, he makes up for in other ways, according to his friends, who cite his hard-driving nature, his intellect, his attention to detail and his decisiveness, if marred at times by a divalike attitude.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: ''If it's a bad idea, Richard will kick it down the toilet and flush,'' said Laurence E. Harris, a lawyer in Washington who is one of four close friends that Mr. Breeden nominated last month to the board of directors at Applebee's, with a view to gaining a say in how the company is run.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Breeden ''knows what to look for,'' Mr. Harris said.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: ''He's a lot less likely to be fooled than a lot of people who are pure investors, because he understands the mechanics of corporate governance and securities laws.''

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Breeden, 57, declined to comment for this article.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: He has not only has a new professional life, but a new personal one as well.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Last year, Mr. Breeden married a trust administrator of the Bennett Funding Group, which he had overseen as the court-appointed monitor.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: (He and his first wife, Holly, were divorced in 2005 after 27 years of marriage.)

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Breeden is now perhaps the most senior former government official ever to run a hedge fund.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Breeden oversaw the Securities and Exchange Commission from 1989 to 1993.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: He then ran one of the world's largest accounting firms, Coopers & Lybrand, before establishing his private firm, Richard C. Breeden & Company, in Greenwich, Conn., to advise companies hobbled by ethics and governance problems.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: In recent years, he has served as the high-profile outside monitor for scandal-plagued firms like WorldCom, which filed for bankruptcy in 2002 and Conrad Black's former company, Hollinger International.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: It was when he was overseeing the bankruptcy of WorldCom, later MCI, that Mr. Breeden first began thinking about starting a hedge fund, according to friends and associates.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Seeing the roles played by the Mexican tycoon Carlos Slim Helú and Mark Neporent of the hedge fund Cerberus Capital as investors in MCI, he asked Mr. Harris, ''I'm thinking of starting a hedge fund -- what do you think?''

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Harris, who recalled the conversation, said Mr. Breeden told him, ''The one thing I don't want to do is fail.''

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Breeden's right-hand man at Breeden Partners is his friend Steven J. Quamme, a one-time mergers-and-acquisitions lawyer with whom Mr. Breeden once worked at Baker Botts, the Washington law firm.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: When asked who was running the hedge fund -- in other words, picking companies in which to invest, Mr. Harris replied, ''I don't think you can actually separate Richard and Steve -- they're joined at the hip.''

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Quamme did not return calls requesting comment.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: An entrepreneur as well as an investor, Mr. Quamme has picked some winners in his past jobs, including a chain of video stores that was sold to Blockbuster Video early last decade and a chunk of the Einstein Brothers Bagels franchises.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Quamme, whom Mr. Breeden also nominated to serve on the Applebee's board, has also endured some setbacks.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: His 50 percent stake in Boston Chicken, through Mayfair Partners, an investing partnership that he ran in the mid-1990s, went stale in 1998 when the restaurant and the partnership both filed for bankruptcy.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: It is, of course, far too early to tell whether Mr. Breeden's knowledge and experience will make his hedge fund, whose philosophy is to invest in American companies with fixable problems in policy and governance, a winner.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Some analysts do not see his fund making an impact on Applebee's.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: ''We do not see a dramatic shift near-term in the company's strategic direction that would lead to the 'value creating' programs proposed by the activist,'' Andrew Barish, an analyst with Banc of America Securities wrote earlier this month.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Applebee's declined to comment on Mr. Breeden's proposals.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: The fund sought to raise $1.25 billion but has so far brought in only around $500 million, including $400 million from Calpers, the California pension fund.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: The hedge fund earned 7.73 percent in the third quarter of 2006, according to the most recent available data from Calpers.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: To some, Mr. Breeden's leap into the hedge fund business on the heels of serving as a court-appointed monitor for so many large companies raises questions.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: ''It's an appearances problem, and it bothers me,'' said Michael Feiner, an ethics professor at Columbia Business School, adding that he thought government officials should be required to wait two years before working at hedge funds or lobbying groups.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: ''I'm disappointed that he is doing this.''

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Mr. Breeden's spokesmen declined to answer questions on whether Breeden Partners would prohibit itself from investing in companies for which Mr. Breeden had served as a court-appointed monitor.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: And the transparency that Mr. Breeden championed at the troubled companies he has overseen may go by the wayside with his new venture.

column2: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
column3: Like many hedge funds, Breeden Partners has affiliated entities registered in the Cayman Islands, to take advantage of generous offshore tax benefits.
