column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: The occasional activist has stirred up a revolt at an annual general meeting, led a no-confidence vote against management and even taken executives to court.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Those have been the extreme cases.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: But in Europe, shareholder activism -- a term that brings to mind Carl C. Icahn or Kirk Kerkorian, unseating directors and forcing spinoffs with elbows-out tactics -- now seems to be moving toward Main Street and into the hands of ordinary investors.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: These no-frills activists are changing the dynamics at the top, their measured but pointed agitation pitting previously passive shareholders, who are used to expressing displeasure by simply selling their shares, against senior management.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: In many cases, the shareholders are gaining the upper hand, nudging up share prices and sometimes forcing out an executive or forcing the sale of the company.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Most recently, the Children's Investment Fund turned dissatisfaction into deal-making at ABN Amro, leading to rival bids for the bank, the largest in the Netherlands.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Then Peter Paul de Vries, the feisty head of the Dutch shareholder association VEB, successfully took ABN Amro's management to court, accusing it of bypassing shareholders when selling one of the bank's most attractive assets.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: ''What we have seen so far may only be the beginning,'' said Antonio Borges, chairman of the European Corporate Governance Institute and a vice chairman at Goldman Sachs in London.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: ''There are many more opportunities as there are many more underperforming companies.''

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Prudential, one of Britain's largest insurers, on May 17 faced calls from Hermes, a London-based hedge fund, and other shareholders to break itself up.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Deutsche Börse, the operator of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, this month removed from the agenda of its annual shareholder meeting a motion that would have made it easier to issue new shares without asking shareholders -- mainly to appease rebellious Atticus Capital, a New York-based hedge fund.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: A number of recent cases have shown that shareholder activism can pay: the UK Focus Fund of Hermes, which has taken an activist tack, had annual returns of 4.9 percentage points above the FTSE All-Share Index from 1998 to 2004, according to a 2006 study by the London Business School and the European Corporate Governance Institute.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Yet, activism does not come cheap.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: The Children's Investment Fund hired its own press relations specialist to send out almost daily updates to journalists about its ABN Amro campaign.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Knight Vinke Asset Management, the Monaco-based activist investor, last year ran advertisements in French and British newspapers to campaign for a breakup of Suez, the French utility.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Small shareholder associations, whose membership fees do not cover such large campaigns, are happy to jump on the bandwagon, said Jean-Pierre Paelinck, secretary general of Euroshareholders in Brussels.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: The efforts seem to be persuading executives that they need to listen to shareholders or risk their jobs and control over their company.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Rijkman W. J. Groenink, ABN Amro's chief executive, in an emotional outburst on April 28, complained to a Dutch court that his company had become ''a toy for hedge funds.''

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Werner G. Seifert, who was ousted as chief executive of Deutsche Börse after an activist investor campaign, last year disclosed his frustration in a memoir called ''Invasion of the Locusts.''

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Those who have not yet had contact with activist investors are seeking advice.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Calls from executives asking what to do in case an activist hedge fund buys into the company are definitely on the rise, said Philip Keevil, a senior partner at Compass Advisers, a merger advisory firm, in London.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Shareholder activism does not need to be confrontational, he said.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Managers sometimes welcome active shareholders because it gives them an opportunity to push for changes.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: But senior executives are also being pressured to deliver shareholder returns as the investment base of companies shifts from passive institutional investors with longer-term horizons to hedge funds focused on the short term, sometimes holding as little as a 1 percent stake in a company.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Activism was further fueled by a realization among shareholders that selling shares, often at a loss, to protest unsuccessful management did not really change anything.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: It simply meant the investment was now weighing on someone else's portfolio as the company continued to underperform.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: ''Activist shareholders are giving more confidence to those who felt in the past that they had no say and remind managers of their duties to account for shareholders' interest,'' said David Brooks, head of mergers at the advisory firm Grant Thornton in London.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: The recent explosion of private equity wealth and the rising appetite for takeovers are adding to the pressure on management to listen to shareholders.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Analysts say shareholder activism is also focusing on a growing distrust of senior management that can be traced back to corporate scandals like those at Enron and Parmalat.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: There is a general tendency that ''if there is a problem with the company, shareholders will say, 'Let's do something about it ourselves and don't trust the directors to do so,' '' said Roger Lawson, communications director for the UK Shareholders' Association.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Encouraged by the success of activist investors, traditional asset management firms like Fidelity Investments, the largest mutual fund company in the world, and Templeton, which never made public statements about their investments in the past, also became more vocal and in some instances publicly threw their weight behind an activist hedge fund.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Henderson Global Investors, a 73-year-old British asset management firm, is planning later this year to set up an ''active engagement fund'' to look for undervalued companies, buy a stake in them and work together with the management to improve performance and enhance shareholder value.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Even though shareholder activism is generally considered to be positive because it makes companies more efficient and increases shareholder returns, some analysts said that the focus on short-term returns can mean important long-term goals were neglected.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Under pressure to perform, managers may feel forced to come up with short-term fixes for problems that would otherwise require more time to solve, said Mr. Brooks of Grant Thornton.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: But Mr. Borges at the European Corporate Governance Institute said these would remain exceptions because it was in the interest of short-term investors to sell their shares at a profit, and they could do so only if they found new investors who believed in the long-term potential of the revamped company.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Despite the possible high returns, shareholder activism remains hard work.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Just how hard is illustrated by the retirement plans of Mr. de Vries, who after 18 years of fighting for shareholders' rights decided to leave the Dutch shareholder group in October.

column2: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
column3: Until then, he said, he will fight on and wonder who will be around longer: he or Mr. Groenink of ABN Amro.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: When Institutional Investor's Alpha magazine released its annual list of the highest paid hedge fund managers last month, it allowed the rest of us to play an entertaining little parlor game: what could you buy if you made as much money as those guys?

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: James Simons, a 69-year-old mathematician who was at the top of the list, earned $1.7 billion, which equaled the amount of money that the federal government spent last year running its vast network of national parks.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Down at No.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: 3 on the list, Edward S. Lampert of Greenwich, Conn., the investor who owns a large chunk of Sears, made $1.3 billion, which, if you forget about taxes, would have allowed him to buy the entire economic output of Sierra Leone.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: We're talking about real money here.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Today, Alpha magazine will release another big list, and this one offers a chance to answer another, arguably more important, question: Are these billionaire hedge fund managers really worth it?

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: The reason hedge funds are a license to print money is their fee structure.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: A typical fund charges a 2 percent management fee, which means that it keeps 2 cents of every dollar that it manages, regardless of performance.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Mutual funds, on average, charge about 1 percent.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: On top of the management fee, hedge funds also take a big cut -- usually at least 20 percent -- of any profits that exceed a predetermined benchmark.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: So in a good year, a fund's managers bring in stunning amounts of money, and in a bad year, they still do very well.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Some quick math shows why: 2 percent of a $5 billion portfolio, which was roughly the cutoff for making Alpha's list of the 100 largest funds, equals $100 million.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: A fund's managers get to take that fee every single year.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Last year was actually a pretty tough year for the industry.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Because hedge funds tend to make a lot of countercyclical bets -- thus the name -- they can often turn a profit even when the stock market falls.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: When it's rising broadly, though, many struggle to keep up.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Last year, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 14 percent, while the average hedge fund returned less than 13 percent, after investment fees, according to Hedge Fund Research in Chicago.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: But the men -- and they are all men -- who appear on Alpha's list of top earners don't manage average hedge funds.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: They manage the biggest funds in the world, the ones that are winning the Darwinian competition for capital, and many of them aren't having any trouble beating the market.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: One of the funds at Mr. Simons's firm, Renaissance Technologies, delivered a net return of 21 percent last year.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: The other returned 44 percent after fees.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: And Mr. Simons, who relies on a fantastically complex set of algorithms, doesn't charge ''2 and 20'' -- as the typical industry fees are called.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: He charges ''5 and 44'' -- a 5 percent management fee and 44 percent of profits -- yet he has still been doing very well by his investors for almost two decades.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: I realize that a lot of people find 9- and 10-figure incomes to be inherently excessive.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Or even immoral.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: From a strictly economic point of view, however, they are also perfectly rational.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: You cannot find anyone else who is providing the same returns as the best hedge fund managers at a lower price.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: If you don't like it, you don't have to give them your money.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: (Even if you do like it, they probably won't take your money.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: In exchange for being lightly regulated, hedge funds are open only to wealthy investors and big institutions.)

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Thanks to their incredible performance, the biggest funds have grown far bigger in recent years.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: The 100 largest firms in the world managed $1 trillion at the end of last year, or 69 percent of all the assets in hedge funds, according to Alpha.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: At the end of 2003, the top 100 had less than $500 billion, or only 54 percent of total hedge fund investments.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: ''The best performance is coming from the largest funds,'' said Christy Wood, who oversees equities investments for the California Public Employees' Retirement System, which, like a lot of pension funds, is moving more money into hedge funds.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: But there is an irony to this influx of money.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: It all but guarantees that hedge fund pay over the next few years won't be as closely tied to performance as it has been.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: The hundreds of millions of dollars that have flowed into hedge funds have made it all the harder for fund managers to find truly undervalued investments.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: The world is awash in capital.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: All that capital, of course, also translates into ever-greater management fees, regardless of a fund's performance.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: The flagship hedge fund at Goldman Sachs lost 6 percent last year, but it still brought in a nice stream of fees.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Bridgewater Associates, which is based in Greenwich, has earned a net return of less than 4 percent in each of the last two years.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Yet its founder, Raymond T. Dalio, made $350 million in 2006.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: ''When we have a bad year, we're essentially flat,'' Parag Shah, a Bridgewater executive, told me.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: ''And when we have a good year, we have a great year.''

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Goldman and Bridgewater may well bounce back, but the combination of extraordinary pay and ordinary performance is going to occur more and more in the coming years.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Outside of the highfliers on the Alpha list, it's already the norm.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Since 2000, the average hedge fund hasn't done any better, after fees, than the market as a whole, according to research by David A. Hsieh, a finance professor at Duke.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Still, even mediocre managers, after a lucky year or two, are able to attract gobs of capital and charge ''2 and 20.''

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: So are today's hedge fund managers really worth it?

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: Sure, but only if they deliver the sort of performance that Mr. Simons has, and very few will in the years ahead.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: More to the point, it's extremely difficult to know who the stars will be.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: In all sorts of walks of life, people tend to think that the past is a better predictor of the future than it really is.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: That's why journeyman baseball players -- a Yankees pitcher named Carl Pavano comes to mind -- are able to sign huge contracts based on a single good season.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: It's also why so many investors chase returns.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: The genius of the world's hedge fund managers isn't only in how they invest their money.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
column3: It also lies in having set up an industry that takes advantage of a timeless human trait.

column2: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: DUBAI/ABU DHABI, Aug 6 (Reuters) - Creditors of Stanford Marine Group (SMG), which has links to troubled private equity firm Abraaj, are in talks with three potential buyers, sources familiar with the matter say.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: Banks are overseeing control of Dubai-based SMG after it failed to meet the terms of its debt obligations due to financial stress linked to a steep fall in chartering rates, the sources said.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: SMG, which operates offshore supply vessels that service the oil and gas industry, is 51 percent owned by a fund managed by Abraaj.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: Dubai-based Abraaj filed for provisional liquidation in June after a row with investors over the use of their money in a $1 billion healthcare fund.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: Abraaj denies any wrongdoing.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: With Abraaj’s future uncertain, SMG’s creditors are likely to remain in the driving seat for the time being, the sources said.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: A source close to Abu Dhabi-based Waha Capital, which owns the remaining 49 percent share in SMG, said Waha was “maintaining a dialogue with the banks.”

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: “SMG, like many other companies in the industry, is in discussion with its financiers with respect to its existing financing facilities,” SMG said in a statement to Reuters.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: “SMG’s financiers and shareholders continue to be supportive of the business and its management and look forward to continued future success.”

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: Abraaj’s joint provisional liquidators did not respond to a request for comment.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: Waha also did not reply to a request for comment.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: With SMG in negative equity, any sale of the company would leave banks with a haircut of at least 40 percent, two of the sources said.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: Reuters was unable to verify the names of the potential buyers.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: One of the sources said London-based funds were among the interested buyers, while another source said they included private equity firms and “strategic” investors.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: From 2013 Abraaj was considering listing SMG on the stock market or selling it but the firm’s fortunes changed with the collapse in oil prices in 2015, which led to a dramatic fall in chartering rates and a drying up of projects.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: SMG’s statement said it had demonstrated “resilient performance in the face of continued global downturn in the offshore marine industry with healthy demand for its fleet, leading to robust utilisation rates.”

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: The firm’s debt problems stem from a $325 million Islamic loan restructuring signed in June 2015 and provided by a group of banks including Noor Bank, Barwa Bank, Ajman Bank, United Arab Bank, Qatar Islamic Bank, and First Gulf Bank - now part of First Abu Dhabi Bank.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: United States-based Fulcrum Capital, which has an office in Dubai, was among the companies that had looked at buying part of SMG’s bank debt, said two sources.

column2: UAE's Stanford Marine creditors in talks about sale of business -sources
column3: Fulcrum didn’t respond to a request for comment.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: THOMASVILLE, N.C. (Reuters) - In a town where a 30-feet tall chair is the chief landmark, and which is synonymous with a U.S. furniture industry decimated over the years by imports from China, many greet the possibility of tariffs on Chinese goods with a shrug.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: No wonder.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: Of three once bustling Thomasville furniture plants in the city limits, one is being demolished and cleared for parkland, another may become the site of a new police station, and a third is being converted into apartments.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: President Donald Trump is threatening to levy tariffs of up to 25 percent on $500 billion of goods imported from China each year, including roughly $20 billion of furniture, as a way to bring back hundreds of thousands of manufacturing jobs lost to China and other low-cost competitors.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: Yet, the transformation of U.S. industries since China’s emergence as the world’s low-cost producer almost two decades ago means many no longer directly compete with Chinese imports, so tariffs may not translate so easily into more U.S. jobs.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: At family-owned Bernhardt Furniture in Lenoir, some 90 miles west of Thomasville, executives say it would take about $30 million in capital investment - some 10 percent of annual sales - to resurrect standard wood furniture lines now mainly made in countries like China and Vietnam.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: That is too much to commit based on a policy that a future administration could reverse.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: “The theory is you turn (imports) off, the jobs come back.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: That’s not really true...

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: The buildings don’t exist.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: The people don’t exist.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: The machinery does not exist,” to make the sorts of furniture that now gets imported, said Alex Bernhardt Jr., chief executive and the company founder’s great grandson.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: What the company needs now, executives say, is the open markets and steady economy that have allowed it to grow its workforce from below 800 at the end of the 2007-2009 recession to almost 1,500 today - partly on the basis of exports to China.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: DIFFERENT COMPANY

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: That growth has been largely driven by demand for more customized, higher end furniture.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: In expanding, the 129-year-old company has been hiring not only factory workers, but also designers, marketing experts and other professionals.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: In all, it is a different firm from what it was three decades ago when it first began dividing product lines between the United States and Asia.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: The sewing lines at Bernhard Furniture Company which where skilled craft jobs are growing without the help of tariffs, and company officials say they are pressed to fill open positions is shown in Lenoir, North Carolina, U.S., August 15, 2018.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: REUTERS/Howard Schneider

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: Economists say the same is true across much of U.S. manufacturing.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: To invest and hire more workers, executives would need certainty, for example, that consumers would prefer U.S.-made products at a potentially higher price.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: They would need confidence that tariffs would last beyond the Trump administration and that production could not be shifted to other more cost-competitive countries.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: Even then, there may be little incentive to go back to old product lines for industries that have changed dramatically because of globalization.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: Across the Rust Belt and the former factory towns of the south, the transformation is apparent.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: In Buffalo, an old steel mill is now a solar panel factory, and a retail goods manufacturer now houses an office and restaurant park.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: Near Dayton, Ohio, a shuttered GM plant has reopened as a Chinese-owned auto glass company.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: Abandoned factories throughout North Carolina have landed on the Environmental Protection Agency’s list of “brownfield” sites that need cleanup.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: Some companies are considering moving production from China as a result of the tariffs, but the jobs are unlikely to head home.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: Illinois-based CCTY Bearing, for example, said it planned to move U.S.-bound production from Zhenjiang, China, to a new plant near Mumbai in India to keep labor costs down.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs
column3: JLab Audio’s China-made Bluetooth products are not being taxed yet, but its chief executive Win Cramer had been scouting for suppliers in Vietnam and Mexico.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs

column3: “They make decisions based on the cost.”

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs

column3: STEADY RECOVERY

column3: The responses to Trump’s tariffs on steel and aluminum show how such steps create both winners and losers.

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs

column2: In a U.S. manufacturing hub, no illusions about tariffs and jobs

column3: In Thomasville, few expect that tariffs will bring furniture manufacturing back to its heyday, nor does the community need it, says city manager Kelly Craver, whose parents worked in the furniture and textile industries.

column3: WUXI, China/LONDON (Reuters) - With smart cancer diagnostics, one-stop-shop diabetes kits and AI systems to improve ambulance pick-ups for patients with chest pain, AstraZeneca (AZN.L) aims to move from simply supplying drugs to become a broad healthcare provider in China.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: The logo of the British pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca is seen at the company's China Commercial Innovation Centre (CCIC) in Wuxi, Jiangsu province, China, September 15, 2018.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: REUTERS/Adam Jourdan

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: Tech tie-ups with the likes of Alibaba (BABA.N) and Tencent (0700.HK) will not directly lift the British group’s drug sales, since they are not specific for any one company’s products and in many cases will be low-cost or free.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: But it will expand the overall market and represents a soft power play that dovetails neatly with Beijing’s support for Internet-based healthcare systems to alleviate a lack of doctors, overcrowding and poor grassroots healthcare.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: “Down the line we benefit, our products benefit, because we have better relationships with doctors and hospital managers and also because we diagnose more patients and they get better treated,” Chief Executive Pascal Soriot told Reuters.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: Surrounded by the latest gizmos at the World Internet of Things Exposition in Wuxi, eastern China, Soriot says he wants to use the power of artificial intelligence, robots and apps to help transform diagnosis and disease management.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: AstraZeneca has been on a tear in China, more than doubling its sales since 2012, helped by regulatory reforms to fast-track new drugs, and today generates 18 percent of revenue in the country — a far higher proportion than rivals.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: Yet Soriot is anxious to do more to keep doctors and government officials on-side in the world’s second-biggest drugs market, as soaring demand strains the state insurance system and squeezes medicine prices.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: The company’s underlying conviction is that it has the right medicines across chronic diseases like cancer, diabetes and respiratory disorders to win in China.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: Soriot believes that can keep AstraZeneca growing in a pivotal market in the coming years, even though annual growth is likely to slow to nearer 15 percent from the breakneck 33 percent seen in the first half of 2018.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: The company has moved quickly to exploit China’s new-found willingness to use innovative Western drugs.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: Last year it won a record-fast approval for lung cancer pill Tagrisso, which is designed for patients with a genetic mutation that is particularly common in China.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: China-first approvals for drugs like roxadustat and Elunate, a colorectal cancer treatment from Eli Lilly (LLY.N) and Hutchison China MediTech (HCM.L), mark a reversal of the historical pattern of Chinese patients getting new drugs years after their launch in the West.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: Slideshow (2 Images)

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: There is, however, a trade-off.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: “To some extent the economy is growing so there is more money to do that, but there is not enough money ...

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: They have to make room in the budget for innovation.”

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: “UNMET NEEDS”

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: With 1.4 billion people, around 18 percent of the world’s population, China has more cases of cancer and diabetes than any other nation, fueled by fast food, smoking and pollution, global health data show.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: “There are enormous unmet medical needs in China, particularly in oncology, and 30 percent of the world’s cancer patients are in China,” Christian Hogg, Chief Executive of Hutchison China MediTech, told Reuters.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: “There is almost an inevitability that the Chinese pharmaceutical industry is going to grow to be the largest in the world in due course.”

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: The firm, also known as Chi-Med, is working with AstraZeneca on a novel oncology drug targeting kidney, lung and stomach tumors.

column3: AstraZeneca is bolstering its sales force to meet this growing demand.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: It has around 7,500 sales staff in China and is looking to push into smaller cities — boosting volume and helping offset lower prices.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: The list was most recently updated last year after an eight-year hiatus.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: A drug joint venture, Dizal Pharmaceutical, backed by the China State Development & Investment Corporation, will promote Chinese-discovered drugs — another priority for Beijing.

column2: AstraZeneca plots China robot offensive to counter price cuts
column3: “It’s the first time a government fund works with a foreign company in researching new drugs for Chinese patients,” Leon Wang, AstraZeneca’s China head, said in an interview at the firm’s Shanghai headquarters.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: THE dollar fell against many currencies in 2006, and many Wall Street analysts are predicting more of the same this year.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: That needn't worry investors, who could profit from a continued decline in many ways.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: But some strategists caution that it may be wiser to try to benefit indirectly from a weaker dollar -- by holding stocks or stock funds focused on certain industries and countries -- than by betting directly on foreign currencies.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: ''You've got to know your limitations,'' said Sam Stovall, the chief investment strategist at Standard & Poor's.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: ''Unless you make millions of dollars on Wall Street, you probably shouldn't be speculating in currencies.''

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: In 2006, the dollar fell 10.2 percent against the euro and 12 percent against the British pound, although it rose 1.1 percent against the Japanese yen.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: Mr. Stovall said the best move for most individual investors would be to stock up on the shares of American multinational corporations that earn a lot of their revenues abroad, as well as on foreign stocks.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: ''We feel that many foreign economies are not as far along in their economic cycle, and they have good growth potential now,'' he said.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: He recommended that individual investors allocate 40 percent of their total portfolios to domestic stocks, 20 percent to foreign stocks, 25 percent to domestic bonds and 15 percent to cash instruments like money market accounts and certificates of deposit.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: In terms of domestic stocks, he favors large stocks like those in the S.& P. 500- stock index.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: On average, the companies in this index earn 41 percent of their revenue in foreign countries.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: ''If you believe that international economies are going to do fairly well, and the dollar is likely to weaken,'' Mr. Stovall said, ''then you could get a good bit of tailwind if you transfer those foreign profits back to U.S.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: dollars.''

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: But averages can hide wide variances.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: Some industries represented in the S.& P. 500 draw much more of their revenue abroad than others.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: Companies in the energy and technology sectors, for example, generate well over half of their sales outside the United States, while the utilities and telecommunications companies in the index produce a vast majority of their revenue at home.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: For example, the handful of telecommunications providers in the index get just 3 percent of their revenue, on average, in foreign countries.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: ''You have to be a little bit concerned that emerging-markets debt and equity may have gotten a bit ahead of themselves,'' he said.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: Mr. Schweitzer said that any further appreciation of the euro could be modest this year.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: Still, he added, European stocks were appealing investments for a host of other reasons.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: For Americans investing in Britain or on the continent, a further slide by the dollar against the pound or the euro could bolster those dividend advantages.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
column3: ''Meanwhile, European companies are cutting costs and restructuring, and that's starting to show up in their earnings growth,'' Mr. Schweitzer said.

column2: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)

column3: BERLIN, Sept. 19 (Xinhua) -- German intelligence chief Hans-Georg Maasen will be promoted to a more senior post in the interior ministry, the country's federal government announced on Tuesday night.

column2: German intelligence chief promoted after controversial Chemnitz comments - Xinhua

column2: German intelligence chief promoted after controversial Chemnitz comments - Xinhua

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq
column3: The White House is planning an aggressive effort to sell Congress and the American public on President Bush's new strategy for Iraq, beginning with a prime-time address to the nation on Wednesday night, followed Thursday by a presidential trip to Fort Benning, Ga., and appearances on Capitol Hill by the secretaries of state and defense.

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq
column3: By Monday, though, he made his intentions clear.

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq
column3: ''It was clear that he has thought long and hard about this change in strategy,'' said Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, who supports the troop increase.

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq
column3: That's just one small component of it.

column3: It's a change in economic, military and political strategy.''

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq
column3: White House officials were still planning details of the speech on Monday.

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq
column3: The president's aides were contemplating having Mr. Bush deliver it from the White House Map Room, a site replete with the history and imagery of World War II -- imagery that Mr. Bush has invoked as he has sought to compare the campaign against terrorism to the struggle against totalitarianism and the Nazis.

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq
column3: But the Oval Office, a more traditional setting, was also being considered.

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq

column2: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq

column3: The hope is that Mr. Bush can win over the public, and bring Congress along.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: LONDON, Dec. 12 (Xinhua) -- British Prime Minister Theresa May will face a vote of no confidence Wednesday from Members of Parliament (MPs) in her own Conservative Party that could see her kicked out of her role as prime minister and the Party leader.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: If that were to happen, May would still remain as prime minister until her successor had been chosen.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: That could see May remaining in Downing Street into January, with important government business effectively put on hold, and most significantly no progress being made on any Brexit deal.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: The vote of no confidence in May will be carried out by the so-called 1922 Committee, the representative group for Conservative MPs.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: The vote was triggered early on Wednesday morning when the necessary quota of 48 letters from MPs asking for a leadership vote was reached, which represents 15 percent of Tory MPs.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: If May can win the support of 158 Tory MPs, 50 percent of MPs plus one, then she can stay as leader and as prime minister.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: "May only has to win a simple majority in this no confidence vote in order to stay as leader," constitutional expert Tim Bale, professor of politics at Queen Mary University London (QMUL), told Xinhua.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: The rules of the leadership process state that the leader can face just one confidence vote in a year, so if May wins on Wednesday evening she will be immune from challenges until next December.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: However, if the vote is a close one May could feel that she is too politically damaged to continue, and she would step down as leader and prime minister.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: "You can win a confidence vote by one vote and stay in place, but I would suggest that that kind of majority would not be sufficient," Bale said.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: "It might be a technical win, but it would mean the Conservative Party leader is fatally wounded," he added.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: If May is defeated, or if she steps down as a result of the vote, then the Conservative Party will immediately begin the process of choosing a leader, who will become the new prime minister.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: The head of the 1922 Committee Graham Brady will agree a date for the first round of the leadership election with the prime minister.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: Then, candidates for leader will come forward from among Conservative MPs.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: Each candidate needs just two other MPs to nominate them for the election.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: This could see an initially large field of candidates running for leadership, and a series of votes will be held among Conservative MPs.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: In each round of the vote, the lowest polling leadership candidate will fall out of the race until there are just two left.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: Both those candidates will then be put to a postal ballot by the entire membership of the Conservative Party across the whole of Great Britain.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: Figures from March this year show that this electorate is about 124,000 strong.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: May went through the initial parts of this process in the summer of 2016 when she was eventually chosen to replace outgoing David Cameron, who quit the morning after the June referendum set Britain on a path to leave the European Union (EU).

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: At that time, the initial rounds of voting among Conservative MPs to reduce the field to two candidates took 10 days, and a postal ballot of party members was not necessary as the other candidate in the election with May withdrew from the race.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: The first part of the process, the voting rounds for MPs, could take the process up until just before Christmas.

column2: News Analysis: What's to expect following UK PM no confidence vote? - Xinhua
column3: With the disruption of holidays and to the postal system, it would not be possible to hold a ballot of the full party membership until the New Year.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: The parallels are striking: bold new Congressional majorities swept into power by public dissatisfaction with White House policies.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: The administration and Congress digging in for a test of wills over federal spending.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: A watershed presidential election looming.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Memories of the rancorous 1995 budget fight between President Clinton and leaders of the Republican revolution are casting a distinct shadow over the current impasse between President Bush and Congressional Democrats on Iraq.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Each side believes it can apply lessons learned from that earlier battle to its strategy in the current showdown.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: The 1995 budget fight grew out of the push by Republicans -- riding their historic House takeover the year before -- for cuts in federal spending, with Medicare as their poster child for a bloated federal program.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: When Mr. Clinton refused to go along with trimming the program, budget talks collapsed, and the resulting 21-day shutdown put nearly 300,000 federal workers on furlough and disrupted public services.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Republicans were outmaneuvered in that battle, and found that the public blamed them for a shutdown of federal agencies.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Today, they stand behind the executive branch, with 150 Republican House members promising Mr. Bush they would sustain his veto of a war spending measure that sets a timeline for leaving Iraq.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Democrats, who sided with the president in 1995, are the ones challenging the White House now, bolstered by public sentiment against the war.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Even as those in the middle of the current clash strategize about the next move, some figures central to the past fight say the differences are more pronounced than the similarities.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''There were no Americans risking their lives at the Washington monument in 1995,'' said Newt Gingrich, the Republican speaker at the time whom critics accused of badly overplaying his hand.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''There were no Americans being shot at the Interior Department in 1995,'' he said.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''We were engaged in a domestic political debate over being serious over a balanced budget.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: The Democrats risk sending signals to our enemies that kidnapping British sailors and killing young Americans is acceptable.''

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Tom Daschle, the Senate minority leader in 1995, sees differences as well, but believes they play to Democratic strengths, with Mr. Bush defending an unpopular war and Democrats treading more carefully than did Mr. Gingrich and his coterie.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''Newt Gingrich boasted of shutting the government down,'' recalled Mr. Daschle.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''He was proud of the fact he was doing that just to show his will.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Republicans felt they had a mandate and could do what they wanted.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: I don't think you could find a Democrat who thinks they have a mandate, but we do have a chance.''

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Almost from the beginning of the budget fight in 1995, Mr. Clinton's poll numbers edged up and those of Mr. Gingrich, the Republican speaker of the House, dipped as the public perceived the president as the one trying to resolve the problem and Republicans as inflexible.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: One difference with 1995 was that in that episode, there was tangible fallout for Americans as parks and museums closed, benefit checks were delayed and an array of federal assistance was suspended.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Today, the administration is making the case that the military will be denied resources, and some tours in Iraq might have to be extended if no bill is approved.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: But the Pentagon appears to have the flexibility to pay for operations at least through May and possibly longer with substantial juggling.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Nevertheless, any event detrimental to the troops that could be tied to the impasse could cause a backlash for Democrats.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Republicans say they continue to believe that much of the public still regards the president as the nation's pre-eminent leader and that Congress should not meddle in White House business too deeply.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''With us it was a bridge too far,'' said Representative Jack Kingston, Republican of Georgia, recalling the duel with Mr. Clinton.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''Tactically, we made a mistake and found the American people still liked the office of the presidency having some dominance.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: This is the Democrats' government shutdown.''

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: But Democrats say that Mr. Bush is operating in an atmosphere of deep skepticism and that he must fight his own low poll numbers as well as public frustration with the war -- even though a recent survey showed a slight gain in optimism about Iraq.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''We have had a chance to study 1995, and Democrats are bound and determined to make sure it won't happen to them,'' said Jim Manley, a spokesman for Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''Here we have a president seriously at odds with the American people.''

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Representative Rahm Emanuel of Illinois, the current chairman of the House Democratic Caucus and a senior aide in the Clinton administration, said Mr. Bush was retracing the missteps of Mr. Gingrich, courting conflict, while Mr. Clinton displayed a willingness to compromise.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''President Clinton started off with, 'Come on, let's talk, let's negotiate,' '' said Mr. Emanuel.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''President Bush has started off with confrontation.''

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Indeed, the White House has drawn a hard line, saying it will not legitimize a Democratic withdrawal plan of any sort by accepting it as part of legislation.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Two Democrats said that Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker, urged Mr. Bush to work with Democrats on the war while the two mingled in her office before a Capitol Rotunda ceremony last week; the Democrats said that Mr. Bush's reply was essentially, ''I am where I am.''

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Both sides are trying to exploit openings.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Republicans, aware of Mr. Bush's low standing, point to the added domestic spending in the House and Senate bills, trying to build resentment to pork-barrel projects.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: The White House is employing its presidential megaphone, particularly with Congress out of town for Easter.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Mr. Bush took to the Rose Garden on Tuesday to warn of ''significant consequences for our men and women in the armed forces.''

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: Democrats immediately fired back, accusing the president of being out of touch with the public and calling on him to negotiate.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''I saw a lot of what happened when my husband had a Republican Congress,'' said Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, as she toured Iowa as part of her presidential campaign.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: ''We would stake out one position, they would stake out one position.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: And then people would begin to try to figure out how to narrow the difference.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: That's what should be happening here.''

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: It is difficult to predict who will prevail.

column2: Tussle Over Iraq Bill Reminds Many of Bitter 1995
column3: After all, no one foresaw in the fall of 1995 that a simple legislative dispute would end up stalling the momentum of a determined new majority and enhancing the standing of an embattled president.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: BANGKOK (Reuters) - The last time most Thais saw politician Suthep Thaugsuban was in 2015 when he entered the Buddhist monkhood and announced his retirement after spearheading protests that culminated in a military coup against a government he detested.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: Politician Suthep Thaugsuban gestures during an interview with Reuters in Bangkok, Thailand, June 10, 2018.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: REUTERS/Panu Wongcha-um

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: The military, after taking power, clamped a tight lid on politics, and the rivalry between the military-royalist establishment and new upstart political forces that had roiled the country for a decade was stifled.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: But now a long-promised general election is on the horizon - due sometime between February and May - and old animosities are stirring and veteran political brawler Suthep, 68, is back.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: Suthep, a one-time deputy prime minister in a pro-establishment government, has said he will contest the election under the banner of a new party he set up to sustain the work of the military government and to campaign for its leader, Prayuth Chan-ocha, to be prime minister of a civilian administration.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: The return of Suthep, who has a record of mobilizing crowds on the streets in support of the establishment, could be a big asset for the military which has made no secret of its aim to retain a grip over politics after the election.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: The military and Suthep have common cause in their burning desire to rid the country of the influence of former premier Thaksin Shinawatra and his family, whose supporters have been biding their time and pinning their hopes on the election.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: Suthep makes no secret of his support for former army chief Prayuth and his wish to see him return as prime minister after the vote, but says he must defer to his new party, the Action Coalition for Thailand, which has yet to spell out its position.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: “He’s a good guy, not corrupt, determined, and he has the trust of his people and is loyal to the monarchy,” Suthep told Reuters in a recent interview.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: “So I cheer him on, the more he can succeed, the better for the country,” Suthep said, while adding he had no desire to take on any leadership role in a new government.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: Suthep, for years known as a pugnacious deal-maker, has been a central figure in well over a decade of turmoil that began in 2000, when former telecommunications tycoon Thaksin became prime minister for the first time.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: Thaksin fired up support in the provinces with pro-poor policies, and shook up politics with his brash, election-winning ways.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: In the process, he made enemies in the Bangkok-based, military-dominated establishment, which accused him of corruption and buying election victories.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: Suthep, a former shrimp and palm-oil magnate from Thailand’s south, served as deputy prime minister in a pro-establishment government after Thaksin was ousted in a 2006 coup, and which oversaw a bloody crackdown on Thaksin’s “red-shirt” supporters occupying Bangkok streets in 2010.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: Suthep expects his party’s support to come from Thaksin’s main enemies, the Bangkok middle class, and he’s keen to see that the party sets an example with transparent funding and the inclusion of women, to bolster that support.

column3: ‘LEADERS GONE’

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: Suthep lead protests against a government formed in 2011 by Thaksin’s sister, Yingluck Shinawatra, rallying pro-establishment crowds who tried to march on the government’s offices to shut it down.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: The turmoil eventually triggered the coup by then army chief Prayuth.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: Suthep and his allies celebrated the fall of another government loyal to their enemy, Thaksin.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: But the people were slowly seeing the truth about them, he said.

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears

column2: Thailand's political tough-guy back in the fray to support military as vote nears
column3: “This will be Suthep’s last role,” said Nattawut Saikua, a deputy prime minister in Yingluck’s cabinet, who, like Suthep, is known as a fiery orator, though for the opposite side in Thailand’s drawn-out political battle.

column3: Hun Sen’s Cambodian People’s Party (CPP) swept all parliamentary seats in last month’s largely unopposed election.

column2: Cambodia frees 14 government critics

column2: Cambodia frees 14 government critics

column2: As Philippines' Duterte starts to flag, his daughter reaches out to a Marcos
column3: MANILA (Reuters) - Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte thinks political dynasties are bad.

column2: As Philippines' Duterte starts to flag, his daughter reaches out to a Marcos
column3: But the way the prevailing political winds are blowing, it looks like a dynasty of his own might be taking shape.

column2: As Philippines' Duterte starts to flag, his daughter reaches out to a Marcos
column3: Nine months away from mid-term elections that could determine the success or failure of his presidency, his daughter, Sara Duterte, is fast emerging as a power-broker who is aiming to shore up support for his ambitious policy agenda, and, say some experts and insiders, his eventual succession.

column2: As Philippines' Duterte starts to flag, his daughter reaches out to a Marcos
column3: By his own admission, the 73-year-old president is flagging.

column2: As Philippines' Duterte starts to flag, his daughter reaches out to a Marcos

column2: As Philippines' Duterte starts to flag, his daughter reaches out to a Marcos
column3: That contrasts sharply from his 40-year-old daughter, who has started maneuvering to build alliances and expand her small party in the southern Davao region into a new political juggernaut, as fissures appear in her father’s ruling PDP-Laban party.

column2: As Philippines' Duterte starts to flag, his daughter reaches out to a Marcos

column2: As Philippines' Duterte starts to flag, his daughter reaches out to a Marcos
column3: The move was helped by a relationship developing between Sara Duterte and Imee Marcos, 62, a provincial governor and key figure in the still influential family of late dictator Ferdinand Marcos, who ruled the Philippines for two decades before being ousted in a 1986 uprising.

column2: As Philippines' Duterte starts to flag, his daughter reaches out to a Marcos

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: WINNIPEG, Manitoba (Reuters) - With one surprise court ruling, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau faces the risk of contesting next year’s election with key pieces of his economic and environmental plans in ruins.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: The Federal Court of Appeal overturned on Thursday the Liberal government’s 2016 approval to expand Trans Mountain, a critical pipeline to link Canadian crude with foreign markets, followed hours later by Alberta’s tit-for-tat withdrawal from Trudeau’s climate plan.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: The day’s events amplified criticism that Trudeau has failed to produce a regulatory system in which oil pipelines stand a chance of approval and undermined the PM’s ambitions to reduce emissions.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: “A lot was riding on the energy file,” Thomas said.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: “There is no spin you can put on this that would be positive.”

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: At the heart of the centrist Trudeau’s plans for the economy and environment was a bargain with Alberta, Canada’s energy province.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: The Liberal government approval of Trans Mountain would provide Alberta oil producers with a larger export outlet to the British Columbia coast, and secure Alberta’s support of Trudeau’s national emissions plan.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: Trudeau doubled down in May, agreeing to buy the faltering pipeline project for C$4.5 billion from Kinder Morgan Canada.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: But Trudeau’s bargain collapsed with the court’s rejection and Alberta Premier Rachel Notley’s exit from the carbon plan.

column3: Buying a pipeline was always unpopular with progressive voters, said Nik Nanos, head of polling firm Nanos Research.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: “Now they run into double jeopardy politically because they have an issue of whether they can deliver.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: And it’s having a knock-on effect on other issues, like carbon pricing.”

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: The party, which won a huge 2015 majority, is running close with the opposition Conservatives according to polls, and faces another risk in tough U.S. trade talks.

column3: Trudeau on Friday said he could proceed with a national environment plan without Alberta’s support.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: To be sure, opposition leaders have struggled to connect with voters, making it harder to capitalize, Thomas said.

column3: But there is no quick path either to resolving Trudeau’s pipeline-centered problems.

column3: The court flagged regulatory agency the National Energy Board (NEB) for wrongly excluding a review of tanker traffic, and criticized Ottawa for failing to meaningfully consider indigenous concerns.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril
column3: Appealing to Canada’s Supreme Court may be faster, said Robin Junger, a lawyer at McMillan Vantage dealing with environmental and aboriginal issues.

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril

column2: Pipeline politics leave Canada's prime minister in peril

column2: Helping refugees proves labor of love in Germany as politics pivots

column3: “I was very afraid for my children.
