column3: Thousands of Peruvians have taken to the streets in recent weeks to protest systemic graft, with many calling for fresh elections.

column2: Peru president proposes referendum on political, judicial reform
column3: A majority of Peruvians now disapprove of Congress, the government, the judiciary and prosecutors, according to a recent Ipsos poll.

column2: Peru president proposes referendum on political, judicial reform
column3: “This crisis has reached a breaking point,” Vizcarra said.

column2: Peru president proposes referendum on political, judicial reform
column3: “That’s why, as president of the republic, I’ve decided, with the support of the citizenry, to lead a change long sought by honest Peruvians.”

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Source: Xinhua| 2018-12-08 04:50:26|Editor: yan

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Video Player Close

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 7 (Xinhua) -- UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres on Friday asked the international community to prevent rather than react to genocide as the crime does not happen overnight.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: "Genocide is deliberate and premeditated and requires serious preparations that take time.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Those preparations should give the world time to act," Guterres told an event to mark the 70th anniversary of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide and the international day to commemorate genocide victims.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: The Genocide Convention is preventive at its core, and punishes specific acts that are committed with the intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnic, racial or religious group, he said.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: These acts include killing members of the group; causing serious bodily or mental harm to members of the group; deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part; imposing measures intended to prevent births within the group; and forcibly transferring children of the group to another group.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Preventing genocide means paying close attention to these provisions, said Guterres.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: "Tragically, the international community has sometimes failed to heed the warning signs and take early and decisive action.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Rather than preventing genocide, we are still reacting to it, often too late."

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Since the end of World War II, the international community has failed to prevent genocide in Cambodia, Rwanda, and Srebrenica in the former Yugoslavia, he noted.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: In the past two decades, the world has at least started to hold perpetrators to account, he said.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: The International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, and the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia have all convicted perpetrators for the crime of genocide.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: The work of these courts reflects a welcome resolve to punish perpetrators of genocide, he said.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: The UN General Assembly in September 2015 designated Dec. 9 as the International Day of Commemoration and Dignity of the Victims of the Crime of Genocide and of the Prevention of this Crime.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Dec. 9 is the anniversary of the adoption of the 1948 Genocide Convention.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: The Genocide Convention was the first human rights treaty adopted by the United Nations.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: It embodies a collective determination to protect people from brutality and to prevent the repetition of the horrors witnessed by the world during World War II, said Guterres.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: The convention has been ratified or acceded to by 149 states; 45 member states have not become party to it, noted Guterres.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: "I urge those 45 states to consider becoming party as an urgent priority.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Universal participation will send a unifying signal of resolve in this 70th anniversary year."

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: He also called on those states that are already parties to the convention to back their commitments with action.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: "Preventing and punishing genocide is the duty, the responsibility and the obligation of the entire international community."

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Guterres deplored the fact that 70 years after the adoption of the Genocide Convention, people are still being killed, raped, their homes torched, their lands confiscated -- just because of who they are.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: In Iraq, the violent extremists of the Islamic State brutally targeted the Yazidi people for murder, sexual slavery and trafficking.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar were systematically killed, tortured, raped and burnt alive, victims of what has rightly been called ethnic cleansing, said Guterres.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Elsewhere around the world, racism, hate speech, violent misogyny, anti-semitism, Islamophobia and all forms of xenophobia are on the rise, he said.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: "We now know that dehumanizing language is not only evil in itself.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: It may also sow the seeds for far more evil acts, including genocide."

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: It is incumbent on all people, individually and collectively, to reject every single attempt to target people because of their nationality, ethnicity, religion or race, or any other form of identity, he said.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: The UN chief encouraged people to speak out and help nurture the courage and the political will to act decisively, at the right time, and to support others when they take action.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: "My generation believed that after the Holocaust, we would never see genocide again.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: We were wrong," said Guterres.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: "Modernity does not protect us from genocide.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: The digital age does not protect us from genocide.

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: Nothing but our own actions, based on our values and principles, can protect us from genocide."

column2: UN chief asks world to prevent rather than react to genocide - Xinhua
column3: The Genocide Convention offers an essential legal framework for efforts to fight this crime, he said.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: BRASILIA (Reuters) - Steadfast support for jailed former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in Brazil’s poor northeast may give a former governor from the region an edge in the search for the leftist icon’s substitute, three Workers Party officials told Reuters this week.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: FILE PHOTO: Former Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva speaks at his book launch event in Sao Paulo, Brazil March 16, 2018.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: REUTERS/Paulo Whitaker/File Photo

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Jaques Wagner, a former governor of Bahia state and a minister under Lula and his successor Dilma Rousseff, is gaining ground and could displace former São Paulo Mayor Fernando Haddad as the party’s likely presidential candidate in the October election, the sources said.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: They requested anonymity to speak freely about internal deliberations.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: The evolving debate in the Workers Party suggests that Lula, the most influential Brazilian politician of the past two decades, and allies may be coming around to the idea of transferring his support rather than having him mount his own campaign from jail.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Lula, whose eight years in office saw millions of Brazilians lifted from poverty, is still Brazil’s most popular politician despite several corruption indictments and a conviction that will most likely bar him from running.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Lula’s spokesman Jose Crispiniano denied that the Workers Party was moving on.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: “Ex-president Lula da Silva is the candidate and there is no discussion of a substitute,” he said.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: “The party is not evaluating any hypothesis other than Lula’s candidacy,” said a Workers Party spokesman.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Wagner and Haddad declined to comment.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: While Lula, 72, started his political career as a union leader in São Paulo’s industrial belt, his greatest support today is in his native northeast, where his policies contributed to dramatic improvements in social conditions since the turn of the century.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Behind bars since April, serving a prison sentence for his bribery conviction, Lula has insisted he will run in October.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Yet the party insiders said the reality is setting in that his candidacy may soon be struck down by the electoral court.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: “His priority today is more Jaques.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Not to deny Haddad’s merits, but Wagner has more political experience and, being from the northeast, he could start out with considerably more voter support,” said one of the party officials.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: The 67-year-old Wagner, whose parents were Jewish immigrants from Poland, is a founding member of Lula’s Workers Party and was Rousseff’s defense minister before her 2016 impeachment for breaking budget rules.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Wagner is under investigation for allegedly taking bribes in the building of the World Cup soccer stadium in Bahia’s capital of Salvador during his time as governor from 2007 to 2015.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: He has denied any wrongdoing.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Haddad, 55, of Lebanese Christian descent, lost his 2016 bid for re-election to São Paulo’s city hall in a stunning first-round defeat to rising conservative star João Doria, who is now running for governor of São Paulo state.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Haddad’s relative youth and distance from the major corruption scandals roiling Brazilian politics bolstered expectations that he could be the most likely stand-in for Lula.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Still, his resounding 2016 defeat and lack of a connection with the party’s northeastern base has raised concerns.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: Wagner was slapped down by party leaders earlier this year for proposing that they find a candidate outside their ranks to avoid disaster in the October general election.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: He has since insisted that Lula should run.

column2: Lula's party weighs Brazil northeast vote in search for stand-in: sources
column3: One of the sources said Wagner may now give in to inside pressure to be the party’s candidate.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: Democratic leaders said Tuesday that they intended to hold symbolic votes in the House and Senate on President Bush's plan to send more troops to Baghdad, forcing Republicans to take a stand on the proposal and seeking to isolate the president politically over his handling of the war.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: Senate Democrats decided to schedule a vote on the resolution after a closed-door meeting on a day when Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts introduced legislation to require Mr. Bush to gain Congressional approval before sending more troops to Iraq.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: The Senate vote is expected as early as next week, after an initial round of committee hearings on the plan Mr. Bush will lay out for the nation Wednesday night in a televised address delivered from the White House library, a setting chosen because it will provide a fresh backdrop for a presidential message.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: The office of Nancy Pelosi, speaker of the House, followed with an announcement that the House would also take up a resolution in opposition to a troop increase.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: House Democrats were scheduled to meet Wednesday morning to consider whether to interrupt their carefully choreographed 100-hour, two-week-long rollout of their domestic agenda this month to address the Iraq war.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: In both chambers, Democrats made clear that the resolutions -- which would do nothing in practical terms to block Mr. Bush's intention to increase the United States military presence in Iraq -- would be the minimum steps they would pursue.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: They did not rule out eventually considering more muscular responses, like seeking to cap the number of troops being deployed to Iraq or limiting financing for the war -- steps that could provoke a Constitutional and political showdown over the president's power to wage war.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: The resolutions would represent the most significant reconsideration of Congressional support for the war since it began, and mark the first big clash between the White House and Congress since the November election, which put the Senate and House under the control of the Democrats.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: The decision to pursue a confrontation with the White House was a turning point for Democrats, who have struggled with how to take on Mr. Bush's war policy without being perceived as undermining the military or risking criticism as defeatists.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''If you really want to change the situation on the ground, demonstrate to the president he's on his own,'' said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''That will spark real change.''

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: The administration continued Tuesday to press its case with members of Congress from both parties.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: By the time Mr. Bush delivers his speech, 148 lawmakers will have come to the White House in the past week to discuss the war, White House aides said Tuesday night, adding that most met with the president himself.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: While Mr. Kennedy and a relatively small number of other Democrats were pushing for immediate, concrete steps to challenge Mr. Bush through legislation, Democratic leaders said that for now they favored the less-divisive approach of simply asking senators to cast a vote on a nonbinding resolution for or against the plan.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: They also sought to frame the clash with the White House on their terms, using language reminiscent of the Vietnam War era to suggest that increasing the United States military presence in Iraq would be a mistake.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''We believe that there is a number of Republicans who will join with us to say no to escalation,'' said the Senate mority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''I really believe that if we can come up with a bipartisan approach to this escalation, we will do more to change the direction of that war in Iraq than any other thing that we can do.''

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: On the eve of the president's Iraq speech, the White House sent Frederick W. Kagan, a military analyst who helped develop the troop increase plan, to meet with the Senate Republican Policy Committee.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: But Republican officials conceded that at least 10 of their own senators were likely to oppose the plan to increase troops levels in Iraq.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: And Democrats were proposing their resolution with that in mind, hoping to send a forceful message that as many as 60 senators believed strengthening American forces in Baghdad was the wrong approach.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: Democratic leaders said they expect all but a few of their senators to back the resolution.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: In an interview on Tuesday, Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, said he was becoming increasingly skeptical that a troop increase was in the best interest of the United States.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''I'm particularly concerned about the greater injection of our troops into the middle of sectarian violence.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: Whom do you shoot at, the Sunni or the Shia?''

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: Mr. Warner said.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''Our American G.I.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: 's should not be subjected to that type of risk.''

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: But the Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, said Congress could not supplant the authority of the president.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''You can't run a war by a committee of 435 in the House and 100 in the Senate,'' he said.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: The White House press secretary, Tony Snow, criticized the Democrats' plans.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''We understand that the resolution is purely symbolic, but the war -- and the necessity of succeeding in Iraq -- are very real,'' he said Tuesday night.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: On Thursday, Democrats in the House and Senate will open a series of hearings on the Iraq war.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice are among those who have agreed to testify.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: Senator Carl Levin, the Michigan Democrat who is the new chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said that if he was not satisfied that Mr. Bush's plan has sufficient incentives and penalties for the Iraqis, he might support a resolution or amendment to cap the number of American troops in Iraq.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''We have got to force the Iraqis to take charge of their own country,'' Mr. Levin said at a breakfast meeting with reporters.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''We can't save them from themselves.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: It is a political solution.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: It is no longer a military solution.''

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: Lawmakers said Senate Democrats appeared broadly united in opposition to Mr. Bush's approach during their private luncheon on Tuesday.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: While there were a few senators who favored cutting off money for any troop increase, a handful of others expressed uncertainty about challenging the president on a potential war-powers issue.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''We have to be very careful about blocking funding for any troops because we don't want to leave our troops short-changed,'' said Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: Yet a large share of the House Democratic caucus supports a stronger stance against the plan.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: It remained unclear whether a resolution would satisfy constituents.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''Twice in the past 12 months the president has increased troop levels in a last-ditch effort to control the rapidly deteriorating security situation in Iraq,'' said Representative Martin T. Meehan, Democrat of Massachusetts, who proposed a resolution opposing a troop increase.

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: ''Rather than cooling tensions in Baghdad, the situation has descended further into chaos.''

column2: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
column3: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ

column3: Source: Xinhua| 2018-09-20 22:34:19|Editor: Liangyu

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: Video Player Close

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: TOKYO, Sept. 20 (Xinhua) -- Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, winning the ruling party's leadership election Thursday, will likely to become Japan's longest-serving leader, but underwhelming support shown by rank-and-file party members may spell difficulties ahead for both party and president, political analysts said.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: In the leadership race, Abe's only opponent was former Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba who in the run-up to the election voiced different views to Abe on constitutional reform and economic policies and ended up mounting a far-bigger challenge to the incumbent than expected.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: Local political observers pointed out that while Abe has secured the top party post for a third-consecutive term, effectively ensuring his position as the nation's next prime minister owing to the ruling coalition's majorities in both chambers of parliament, Ishiba garnering far more support than expected from rank-and-file members has certainly raised some red flags looking ahead.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: While Abe won 329 out of ballots cast by Diet members, and 224 by rank-and-file members, Ishiba secured 73 votes from legislators but an unexpected 181 votes from ordinary members, who closely reflect public opinion.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: This, political analysts said, was to a certain extent down to increasing opposition to the prime minister's long reign amid ongoing cronyism allegations, ineffectual economic policies and the railroading through parliament of contentious legislation, including those related to security, to push forward his constitutional reform agenda.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: The underwhelming support in the leadership election, described by political watchers here as a "backlash" by the LDP's rank-and-file members, is "most certainly" reflected in public opinion, specialists in politics and national ideology have maintained.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: "People have begun to feel weary of slogan-only and deceptive politics and Abe's style of the privatized use of public power and hawkish stance toward diplomacy and East Asian international relations," Dr. Shin Chiba, professor with Special Appointment, who specializes in political theory, said.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: Abe, following his victory, was quick to reiterate his plans to forge ahead with his career goal of revising the nation's Supreme Law for the first time since World War II, having controversially and against public and constitutional experts' opinions redefined the role of the Self-Defense Forces (SDF) three years ago, to allow it to take part in collective-self defense and come to the aid of an ally under attack, even if its own territory is not threatened.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: Henceforth, Abe will thus seek to secure the two-thirds majority needed in both houses of parliament and a majority in a national referendum to bring about his legacy-led revisions to the constitution, which will specifically make reference to the SDF and "purportedly" clear up its current constitutional ambiguity.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: However, as recent polls have suggested, the Japanese public are far more concerned about the dire fiscal health of the nation, rather than the prime minister's singular goal of revising the Supreme Law for the first time since it took effect in 1947.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: Abe's reasons for constitutional reform are both personal and political.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: He is a long-time devotee of constitutional reform and has used geopolitical pretexts to push forward his reforms, noted Tina Burrett, Associate Professor of Political Science at Sophia University.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: "The public are split on the issue of reform... for most voters, however, the economy and public services are far more important issues," she said.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: Her sentiments have been echoed by other experts on the matter, with Yu Uchiyama, a political scientist at the University of Tokyo, believing Abe's constitutional agenda is far from a straightforward one, with a public mandate on the issue possibly going awry.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: "Even if Abe manages to force a revision through parliament, he would face a referendum, raising the prospect of a Brexit-style political meltdown if the people vote against him," Uchiyama said.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: With public support for the premier and his Cabinet tepid at best amid myriad cronyism scandals and economic malaise perpetrated by a vastly unclear blueprint as to how to deal with the nation's ballooning social welfare costs related to its rapidly aging and shrinking society, security issues are currently not a public priority, political experts have attested.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: Christian Collet, from International Christian University's Politics and International Relations faculty maintained that the Japanese populace believe that Article 9 of Japan's pacifist charter, that states that Japanese people forever renounce war and that land, sea, and air forces, as well as other war potential, will never be maintained, despite Abe's aspirations, should remain as is.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: "Significant segments of the public will continue to resist the efforts to revise Article 9 and there is near unanimous opposition to Japan becoming a nuclear power," the expert said.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: With Abe only gaining about 55 percent of all votes at the local level in the leadership election, members in the ruling camp have been quoted as saying the figures were "shocking," particularly as they closely reflect public opinion.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: LDP party members have also said that the worse-than-expected voting numbers could suggest that victory in the upper house election slated for the summer of 2019 might not be a shoo-in for the ruling camp, with an LDP executive describing the outcome of the leadership vote as "a revolt from the local regions."

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: Criticism is now swirling within the ruling party following Thursday's presidential election, reflecting rising dissent from factions within the party based on the lack of support for Abe staying at the helm from the party's own rank-and-file members, sources close to the matter said.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: People both support and don't support him (Abe) at the same time, said Masao Matsumoto, professor in the Social Survey Research Center at Saitama University, highlighting the political and public divide.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: And, Abe's sole rival in the leadership race was of the same opinion, in terms of both the ruling party and its leader and a growing lack of cohesion.

column2: News Analysis: Bumpy road ahead for Japan's Abe following rank-and-file backlash in LDP leadership vote - Xinhua
column3: "The presidential election demonstrated the LDP is not of one color," Ishiba told a press briefing after the vote, underscoring the fact that the road ahead for the party and its president is, indeed, a bumpy one.

column2: Establishing ties with China good to Panama, says president - Xinhua
column3: PANAMA CITY, Jan. 2 (Xinhua) -- Establishing diplomatic relations with China in 2017 is a great benefit to Panama, President Juan Carlos Varela said Wednesday.

column2: Establishing ties with China good to Panama, says president - Xinhua

column3: “Now the excitement will really start,” said Ulf Bjereld, political scientist at Gothenburg University.

column3: CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (Xinhua) -- Political bias and partisan news reporting influence whether people indicate experiencing certain extreme weather events, a new U.S. study showed.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: The researchers surveyed 3,057 people in the U.S. to ask them about the extreme weather they had experienced over a five-year period.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: The experts then compared these answers to official weather reports for that region for the same time period.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: Data about the weather was taken from the Storm Events Database compiled by National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Weather Service.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: The data included droughts, floods, tornadoes and hurricanes.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: Nearly 22 percent of respondents reported experiencing a polar vortex; 41 percent a drought; 20 percent a tornado; 29 percent a flood and 17 percent a hurricane in the past five years.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: However the data shows that 21 percent lived in a county where a flood was recorded over the time period; 25 percent a tornado; 4 percent a hurricane and 4 percent drought.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: About 59 percent of respondents agreed that "there is solid evidence that the average temperature on Earth has been getting warmer over the past few decades."

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: Of respondents who agreed with this statement, 74 percent agreed that Earth was warming mostly due to "human activity such as burning fossil fuels."

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: "This research shows people's perception of extreme weather can be processed through partisan lenses," said Ben Lyons, a researcher at the University of Exeter and the study's lead author.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: The study found that Republicans are less likely to report experiencing a polar vortex, while those exposed to liberal media are more likely.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: Nevertheless, the weather sometimes can be so extreme that it overshadows personal views, the researchers say.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: Those who favored liberal news sources reported experiencing drought more often than national weather data would suggest they actually did.

column2: Perception of extreme weather processed through partisan lens: study - Xinhua
column3: The study has been published in the journal Environmental Communication.

column3: MABI, Japan - (Reuters) - When Isao Akutagawa moved to the sleepy riverside town of Mabi in western Japan 45 years ago, it seemed like the perfect suburb to raise his children.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Land was cheap and he could drive to his job in nearby Kurashiki City.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: As he built his home next to rice paddies 2 kilometers from the Odagawa river bank, he heard stories about a flood the year before, but didn’t pay much notice until local politicians began warning residents it could happen again.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “They told us years ago that the Odagawa river levees might break,” said Akutagawa, 79, as he mopped muddy water out of his living room.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: His home was submerged in a sudden flood earlier this month when heavy rain caused multiple levees to break.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Torrential rains across western Japan this month triggered floods and landslides that killed more than 200 people and left over a dozen missing in Japan’s worst weather disaster in 36 years.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Mabi, which merged with Kurashiki in 2005, was one of the hardest hit, accounting for most of the 51 killed in Kurashiki.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: More than a quarter of it was inundated, with floodwaters reaching as high as 4.8 meters (16 feet) in some neighborhoods.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Interviews with more than a dozen residents, officials and experts show how multiple failures increased Mabi’s death toll: flood-control plans were delayed for decades; residents often didn’t understand warnings about the risks; and an evacuation order for the worst-hit area came just minutes before confirmation that a levee had failed.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “We had our local politicians working for years to change the flow of that river,” Akutagawa said.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: A flood control project finally won approval in 2010 and construction was set to start this autumn.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “If they had started earlier, even four or five years earlier, we wouldn’t have this,” he added.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Kurashiki City officials said they had asked Japan’s land ministry to start work on the project every year since at least 2005.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: But it was not deemed high enough priority.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: However, officials in the city’s emergency management office said they did not blame the central government for the delay.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “The land ministry has to make their decision after seeing all the requests sent in from around the country.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Every area, not just ours, make these requests hoping that our river gets picked,” said Hiroshi Kono, an emergency management officer at Kurashiki City.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “Of course, it would have made us very happy if ours had been selected sooner.”

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Hiroshi Yamauchi, an official at the land ministry’s Chugoku Regional Development Bureau in Hiroshima, told Reuters his agency had “followed proper procedures,” but that it was common for large-scale river projects to take years to complete.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Competition for a dwindling budget was partly behind the delay, as was an environmental impact study, said Kairyu Takahashi, head of the prefectural legislature, and a member of a committee that discusses regional public works projects.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “I feel powerless that I wasn’t able to make the government take action,” he said, choking up with emotion.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “If we had somehow completed it in time, this may not have happened.”

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: At a news conference on Friday, Keiichi Ishii, who heads the ministry of land, infrastructure and transport, which oversees flood prevention projects, declined to address whether the high death toll in Mabi was a preventable “human disaster” or who was responsible.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “We recognize that there’s a need to look into steps we can take to reduce the damage from disasters like this even a little bit,” Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said at a separate news conference last week as the regional death toll mounted.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: DECADES OF DELAY

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Many people moved to Mabi after the floods of 1972 and 1976 as flatlands next to two main rivers were developed into a bedroom town.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Mabi grew to be a quiet district of about 23,000 people.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Elderly residents said they knew about flood risks, but had never seen waters rise much higher than knee-level.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Still, calls to improve flood control date back decades.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Early proposals, dating as far back as 1968, called for a river bypass and a weir, or small dam, to supply water to farms and reduce flood risks.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Resistance from residents on the southern side of the Odagawa river over being cut off from groundwater stalled the plans, Takahashi said.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: And in the last 20 years, public works spending has declined sharply, falling about 60 percent nationwide from a peak of 14.9 trillion yen in the fiscal year ending in March 1999 to about 6 trillion yen in the current fiscal year, government data show.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: In 2014, 28 billion yen was allocated for a 30-year plan that included a bypass between the Odagawa and Takahashi rivers.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Work on that 10-year project was scheduled to get under way later this year.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: MAPPING DISASTER

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Kurashiki City, like all municipalities across Japan, was required under a 2005 law to create “hazard maps” outlining areas at high risk of flooding, landslides and other disasters, and the locations of evacuation centers.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Two years ago, Kurashiki City drafted its own colorful hazard maps.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: The maps were accurate; large swathes of Mabi marked as risky areas on the maps almost perfectly match the areas overrun by gushing floodwaters.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: But there were two problems: the city assumed a pattern of prolonged rain over a wide area rather than an intense concentrated downpour as actually occurred, according to online planning documents, and residents say they paid little attention to the maps.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: A near-record 138.5 millimeters of rain fell on July 6 in Kurashiki, second only to the 183.5 millimeters recorded on Sept. 3, 2011, according to weather agency data.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Early the next morning, waters broke through levees on the Odagawa and Takamagawa rivers, unleashing flood waters.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Some residents said they had simply ignored the hazard maps; after all, rainfall is relatively rare in Okayama Prefecture, which is known as the “Land of Sunshine.”

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “To me, it was just another routine document from the public office,” said Shigezo Kaneko, 80, who was rescued by boat after waters came close to the first-floor ceiling of his two-story house.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “I guess I wasn’t really vigilant.”

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: ‘NOT IN TIME’

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: In 2015, Japan’s Central Land Ministry came up with a policy to better cope with disasters, which included training local authorities on when to issue warnings.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: But advisories and orders to evacuate are left up to local authorities.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Kurashiki Mayor Kaori Ito announced the first evacuation order, for the area south of the Odagawa river, at 11:45 p.m. At 1:30 a.m. the next day, using loudspeakers, mobile phone alerts, and television and radio messages, the city ordered residents in the heavily populated area north of the river to seek shelter.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: That order came just four minutes before confirmation of the first levee failure, on a small Takamagawa river.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Ito, asked about the timing at a news conference, expressed regret but said she had gone by the book.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Slideshow (23 Images)

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “It (the order) was issued based on the condition of the river and in line with standards (for issuance),” she was quoted as saying by domestic media.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Reuters was unable to reach Ito last week for further comment about the decision.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: Although his family escaped, Atsushi Yamashita, 63, could not persuade one of his neighbors, a man in his 90s, to leave his house just 30 meters from the Odagawa river.

column3: The man was later found dead.

column2: In Japan's flood-ravaged Mabi, delays and lack of awareness magnified death toll
column3: “Something similar might happen again in a few years,” said Yamashita as workers slowly cleared a mound of rubble in front of his home.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Louisiana on Friday picked one of the nation's most prominent education reformers to run the troubled school district of New Orleans, as schools here continue to grapple with physical and administrative damage from Hurricane Katrina.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: The new superintendent, Paul G. Vallas, who is credited with changes in school systems in Chicago and, most recently, in Philadelphia, was chosen to take on what is seen as one of the more singular challenges in American education: creating a working school district where many of the buildings are ruined, many of the teachers are missing and thousands of students might return suddenly.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: When they do, they will be among the neediest -- the poorest and lowest-achieving -- in the nation.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: As a superintendent in Philadelphia and Chicago, Mr. Vallas raised test scores with the help of after-school programs, new schools and revised curricula.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: He is generally regarded by schools experts as one of the more energetic practitioners in the field.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: But speaking Friday in a shuttered school in the Lower Ninth Ward, he seemed to recognize the special difficulty of this task.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: ''I've got to start delivering right away,'' Mr. Vallas told reporters and state officials, including Gov.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Kathleen Babineaux Blanco.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: ''We've got to get qualified people in the classrooms.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: We not only have the problem of deep poverty; we have the problem of children who have been traumatized.''

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: In his remarks, he made it clear that the challenge posed by the New Orleans district was irresistible to a seasoned school professional.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: ''Why this job at this time?''

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Mr. Vallas said.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: ''You've got an opportunity to create a new school system.''

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Asked what his biggest immediate challenge would be, Mr. Vallas said: ''Facilities.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Fixing schools.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: From what I've heard, it's facilities, facilities, facilities.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Clearly the hurricane has done damage, but there has been neglect'' even before the storm.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Mr. Vallas comes to a school district that has followed a tortuous path because of the hurricane and a storm of academic, financial and administrative problems it had before that: a revolving door of superintendents, millions in misspent federal money and test scores that were the lowest in the state.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Because of those difficulties, the state took over the district after the hurricane in 2005.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: The district now consists of only 22 schools out of the original 128, with loose jurisdiction over an additional 17 charter schools.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Another 17 schools are run or chartered by the Orleans Parish School Board, which once ran the entire district.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: The rest are closed.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Mr. Vallas was chief executive for the school district in Philadelphia and earned generally high marks for his academic achievements, though a budget shortfall of $73 million cast a cloud over his tenure.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: He more than doubled fifth-grade math proficiency after arriving there in 2002, though gains in reading and in high school measures were smaller.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: In Chicago, where he was in charge of the schools from 1995 to 2001, similar gains were made.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: The success or failure of the school district in New Orleans is widely seen as an important symbol of the city's recovery.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: The challenge will be different from those Mr. Vallas has faced previously: more than half of fourth graders at nine schools in the district recently surveyed by Louisiana State University were below grade level in reading.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: At two schools, every fourth grader was below grade level in math.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: In one fourth-grade class, only 22 percent read at grade level.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: These difficulties were in addition to widely reported shortcomings the schools faced as they moved unsteadily through their first months last fall: lack of teachers, lack of textbooks, missing supplies and fighting.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Robin Jarvis, the Baton Rouge official Governor Blanco chose to run the district, often seemed overwhelmed.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: Ms. Jarvis announced her resignation a few days ago.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: The Times-Picayune of New Orleans reported this week that the district had spent barely a tenth of the $241 million allocated by the federal government to rebuild schools, and as a result was facing a shortage of classroom space to handle the influx of students expected later in the year.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: To accommodate up to 10,000 new students by the fall, said the state education superintendent, Paul G. Pastorek, the district needs to hire about 600 teachers, rebuild 10 schools and get prefabricated classrooms into shape.

column2: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
column3: The challenge is sizable, he said: ''It is hard to get teachers to come to a hurricane-ravaged city.''

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: By Jon Herskovitz

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: AUSTIN, Texas (Reuters) - A Texas man who survived a deadly domestic attack hatched by his son is pushing the state to grant clemency to the condemned man, although it has never spared a death row inmate solely at the formal request of the victim’s family.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: Thomas “Bart” Whitaker is set to be put to death by lethal injection on Feb. 22 for masterminding a 2003 plot near Houston that left his mother Tricia, 51, and brother Kevin, 19, dead and his father Kent with a bullet wound near his heart.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: In the 31 states with capital punishment, district attorneys make the decision whether to seek death, balancing the punishment that they consider best serves society with the wishes of the victim’s family.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: In this case, the local Texas prosecutors pursued death and jurors decided Bart Whitaker, 38, deserved to be executed.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: His father, a 69-year-old devout Christian and retired executive, says if that penalty is implemented, it will only intensify his pain.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: “I am going to be thrown into a deeper grief at the hands of the state of Texas, in the name of justice,” Kent Whitaker said last week, after a 30-minute meeting with the chairman of the Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles in Austin.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: Whitaker says his son has been a model inmate and has provided letters from death row prison guards to back him up.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: According to the clemency petition, Kent Whitaker, his relatives and his wife’s family do not want Texas to execute Bart.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: The panel’s decision is due on Tuesday, two days before the execution.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: If it recommends commuting the death sentence to life in prison, Governor Greg Abbott, a Republican, would make the final decision.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: Tim Cole, an assistant professor of law at the University of North Texas Dallas College of Law and a former Texas district attorney, said the case points to a major flaw in the U.S. capital punishment system.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: With no consistent criteria for prosecutors on whether they should seek execution, he said, the system is arbitrary.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: “It is completely up to that one person, the district attorney, to seek death or not,” he said.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: The Whitaker case is an outlier, however.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: In many cases, family members want the district attorney to seek the maximum punishment, Cole said.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: Since the U.S. Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty in 1976, clemency at the request of a forgiving victim’s family has been almost unheard of, according to the non-profit Death Penalty Information Center, which monitors U.S. capital punishment.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: It did happen in Georgia in 1990, the group said.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: It is far more common for courts to halt executions for reasons ranging from doubts over guilt to procedural problems with prosecutions than it is for a governor to grant clemency.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: Money may have motivated Bart Whitaker to plan to murder his family with the help of two other men, court documents showed.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: One of those men, his roommate Chris Brashear, shot the father, mother and brother after the family returned from a dinner out.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: He shot Bart in the bicep to make it look he had also been attacked, court documents said.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: The two other men helped prosecutors pin the crime on Whitaker and were not sentenced to death.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: Local prosecutors said they considered the family’s views but stood by Whitaker’s sentence as appropriate for such a brutal crime.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: “We represent all of the community.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: It is not just one person we represent,” said Fred Felcman, first assistant district attorney for the Fort Bend County District Attorney’s Office.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: “Legally, justice says that he should be executed.”

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: Thomas Whitaker appears in a booking photo by the Texas Department of Criminal Justice in Huntsville, Texas, U.S., obtained by Reuters on February 16, 2018.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: Texas Department of Criminal Justice/Handout via REUTERS

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: Felcman believes Bart Whitaker is a sociopath and a master manipulator.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: In the clemency petition, Kent Whitaker recalled lying in his hospital bed and facing the choice of slipping into despair or offering his son forgiveness.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: He said his faith led him to the latter option, which he hopes will sway Texas officials.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life
column3: “We are not asking them to forgive him, or to let him go,” he added.

column2: Father who forgave son for family's murder asks Texas to spare his life

column2: S. African police bust rhino poaching syndicate - Xinhua
