column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: WHILE Hurricane Wilma was ravaging this plutocrats' playground with sustained winds of 110 miles an hour on Oct. 24, 2005, Mario Nievera, Palm Beach's leading landscape architect, was in Pennsylvania, putting on a brave face as he delivered a lecture about his work to the Philadelphia Garden Club.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: As Mr. Nievera showed slides of his more exquisite creations -- purple bougainvillea wrapped around coconut palms and allées of guava trees -- the plants themselves were being ripped to shreds by Wilma, which would ultimately cause $12.2 billion worth of property damage to Florida.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Having struggled for more than a year to revive gardens destroyed in September 2004 by Hurricane Frances -- the most destructive storm to hit the town since 1947 -- Mr. Nievera was daunted at having to start all over again.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Although he stood to profit mightily, he dreaded the added stress.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: In the wake of Wilma, he said in mid-January, ''there's twice as much work, on top of all our ongoing projects.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''And there are only so many hours in the day,'' he added, particularly in Palm Beach, where a job like his requires ceaseless socializing with fretful clients.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: After Frances and then, just three weeks later, Jeanne, ''nobody believed we'd get another hurricane'' Mr. Nievera said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Many of his clients rushed to restore their gardens to manicured perfection in late 2004 and in 2005, only to have them ripped out again by Wilma.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Mr. Nievera said most of his clients are growing more cautious about how they spend their garden budgets and asking for plants and trees that are more likely to survive another hurricane.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: They appear to be heeding warnings from meteorologists that the area could face more major hurricanes in coming years.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Before Wilma ''the sky was the limit,'' he said, referring in particular to the sums spent on recreating his tropical but tailored designs after the 2004 hurricanes.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: A client who approached him for the first time after those storms commissioned a garden with $1 million worth of plants, which was installed just in time for Wilma's arrival.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''My client lost $500,000 worth of plants,'' Mr. Nievera said, adding, ''there's no such thing as hurricane insurance.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Wilma struck as Mr. Nievera was scurrying to get his clients' gardens ready for Thanksgiving, which some regard as the start of the winter season in Palm Beach.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: As a result of the devastation, he is still working to finish several of the projects two months into the season -- a delay that few clients would have tolerated in years past.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: The follies of the 2004-05 winter season have proven useful in one way, enabling Mr. Nievera to tailor his advice to clients based on his own observations of which plants can withstand extreme winds.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: When he advised Tom Quick, a Palm Beach resident whose fortune derives from Quick & Reilly, the former discount brokerage firm, to buy a pair of 30-foot date palms to replace a couple of coconut palms that had succumbed to Frances, it was for aesthetic reasons: they were large enough to hide a view of the house next door that had been opened up by Frances.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: But the date palms, which cost roughly $10,000 apiece and cost $20,000 more to transport and install by crane, proved a practical investment.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''I can't complain: they survived Wilma,'' said Mr. Quick, surveying his backyard.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: A large clusia tree at the back of his house was less fortunate, and is now in dire shape.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''We're planning to replace it,'' Mr. Nievera said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''We just can't find the tree.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Despite an abundance of nurseries in South Florida, plants have been irksomely scarce.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''There are 10 times the number of people looking for plants,'' Mr. Nievera said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''People wanted to replant their annuals, but there were none to be had.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: And when that happens, everyone gets really mad.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Huge price increases have also caused some ire.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''Palm trees used to cost $600,'' said Terry Allen Kramer, a perennially tanned banking heiress who is also a Nievera client.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''Now one lousy palm tree is three thousand.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: And these are just plain old coconut palms.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Not royal palms.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Ms. Kramer was startled when she and her husband, Nick Simunek, flew to Palm Beach the day after Wilma.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Her palatial estate on South Ocean Boulevard ''looked like the Sahara,'' Ms. Kramer said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''I had four feet of sand on my oceanfront lawn, and there was a swath of trees down in the front.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: This after she had spent $50,000 redoing the north and south border gardens, following Frances.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: The fruit trees have been replaced, but with the rise in prices Ms. Kramer is holding out until spring before deciding whether to replace the 30-foot palms she lost on the ocean side.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Many people are ''waiting to see if they really want to spend that money,'' Mr. Nievera said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''It's a real change in mentality.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Other clients, though, have asked him to stormproof their grounds, to whatever extent possible.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Earle Mack, whose appointment as ambassador to Finland had just ended when Wilma struck, and his wife, Carol, had to deploy an army of assistants to clean up their estate, which overlooks the ocean and Lake Worth.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''We had 17 workers at the house for three weeks,'' Mrs. Mack said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''There was a couple of feet of sand covering everything.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: There wasn't a single leaf on one shrub or tree.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: The couple asked Mr. Nievera to redesign the front of the property, the worst-hit area.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: A defoliated stretch of Australian pine hedge that ran 100 feet along the front wall was replaced by a low-lying row of pittosporum, a hardy broadleaf evergreen shrub.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: By the front door Mr. Nievera created a pair of parterres edged with Purple Queen ground cover and Green Island ficus, interlaced with diamond-shaped sections of sand-colored Chattahoochee stone gravel and contrasting black lava rock.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''It's hard to get any colorful plants to grow on the ocean side of the house,'' Mr. Nievera said, ''so I chose the purple shrubs and gravel to create a sense of color.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: In the center he placed six mimusop trees, which he described as ''very salt tolerant, hard to find and hurricane resistant.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: The ravages of Frances and Wilma also inspired Mr. Nievera to redesign the garden of his own house, a single-story Bermuda-style ranch at the south end of Palm Beach, which he bought in 2001 for a bargain $495,000.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: In November he tore out an allée of storm-ravaged guava trees that used to line his front walkway and replaced them with pygmy dates, which are more resilient.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: He also cut down all his coconut trees, which had mostly been killed.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''I couldn't take it anymore,'' he said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: And he came up with a novel solution for his ficus hedges, which took a serious beating during both hurricanes.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''Ficus are the least wind-tolerant of plants,'' Mr. Nievera said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: They tend to lose their leaves and are easily uprooted.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''The tendency in Palm Beach is to maintain them very high -- 20 or 30 feet.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: But you can't do that, because the wind rips right through them.''

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: After Frances punched large holes in the ficus, Mr. Nievera decided to trim the top of the hedge into an undulating wave pattern to complement the missing sections, giving it a crazy-quilt style that he refers to as his roller coaster.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Meanwhile, for his clients, he has been busy designing ways to conceal an awkward but increasingly familiar addition to Palm Beach's topography: the large propane-fueled electricity generator.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Both Frances and Wilma felled power lines, leaving some houses and businesses without electricity for more than a week each time.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: (''Palm Beach is very peculiar,'' Ms. Kramer said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''We pay the highest property taxes, but they don't bury the electric cables.'')

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: Without air-conditioning, toxic mold flourished in the 90-degree heat and the damp conditions that followed Frances, ruining expensive paint finishes, playing havoc with antique furniture and forcing some collectors to send paintings to the restorer.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: The long wait for electricity prompted several moguls to buy generators large enough to power a tropical mansion.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: The generators usually take up at least 100 square feet, Mr. Nievera said, and are often seven feet tall.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: They cost an average of $30,000, which does not include the cost of obtaining permits, digging trenches and other aspects of installation.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''It's a carbuncle in the landscape,'' Mr. Nievera said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: His landscaping responsibilities now include locating the generators in accordance with local planning rules and selecting fast-growing shrubs to further conceal them.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: He recently obscured a giant generator behind a wall of white-flowering Confederate jasmine.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''Beauty definitely comes at a price,'' Mr. Nievera said.

column2: Palm Beach Bows to the Wind
column3: ''But people here can afford it.''

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Some key Senate Democrats say they could consider supporting a short-term increase in American troop levels in Iraq, a stance that reflects division within the party and could provide an opening for President Bush as he prepares to announce his revised plan for Iraq as early as next week.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Mr. Bush is expected to outline a strategy that would include adding to American forces, but would link that increase to a plan for economic development in Iraq.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: He has vowed to consult Congressional leaders before delivering his speech to the nation, and he began that process on Wednesday night by inviting House and Senate leaders to a White House reception, though officials said Iraq was not discussed.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Senator Carl Levin, the Michigan Democrat who will lead the Armed Services Committee, said he would not ''prejudge'' the president's proposal.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: While he would oppose an open-ended commitment, Mr. Levin said, he would not rule out supporting a plan to dispatch more troops if the proposal was tied to a broader strategy to begin reducing American involvement and sending troops home.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: ''The American people are skeptical about getting in deeper,'' he said in an interview.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: ''But if it's truly conditional upon the Iraqis' actually meeting milestones and if it's part of an overall program of troop reduction that would begin in the next four to six months, it's something that would be worth considering.''

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: But Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who will become chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, has said he is opposed to increasing troop strength regardless of the plan, calling the idea the ''absolute wrong strategy.''

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: In interviews on Wednesday, several Democratic senators echoed Mr. Biden's view, saying they believed that sending more troops would not resolve the predicament in Iraq.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Democrats have become well-practiced at playing the roles of critic and skeptic, particularly when the subject is the war in Iraq.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: But as the party formally assumes control of Congress on Thursday, the divisions between the committee leaders, party leadership and rank-and-file senators illustrate the fresh burden they face of articulating a response to Mr. Bush's revised Iraq strategy.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Democrats may find it difficult to speak with one voice in response to Mr. Bush's plan.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: And at this point, party strategists said, they do not necessarily intend to.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Over the next three weeks, Senate Democrats plan to call at least 13 hearings on Iraq, to be held by committees that include Foreign Relations, Armed Services, Intelligence, Homeland Security and Judiciary.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates have agreed to testify, officials said, and invitations were sent this week to a raft of former administration officials, academics and military and Iraqi experts.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Short of reducing military financing, which even the staunchest Congressional war critics have been reluctant to do, Democrats say they believe that one of the most effective tools they have to influence policy is to hold televised hearings.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: ''What you are going to find is that this is no longer exclusively a Democratic criticism,'' said Senator Jack Reed, a Rhode Island Democrat who is a member of the Armed Services Committee.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: ''A lot of Republicans are going to be standing up and saying, 'I don't understand what the president's strategy is.'

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: A lot of people will be asking serious questions, and that will be healthy.''

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Senator Evan Bayh, an Indiana Democrat who also serves on the Armed Services Committee, said a troop increase ''might lead to a temporary abatement to the violence, but will only postpone the ultimate day of reckoning.''

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: In an interview, Mr. Bayh added, ''This problem is not going to be solved in Washington by the president of the United States; it can only be resolved by Iraqis.''

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: In a memorandum sent Wednesday to members of the Democratic caucus, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, who becomes the majority leader, pledged that ''Democrats will work with Republicans to bring oversight and accountability'' to the war.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Mr. Reid has said that he will consider supporting a short-term increase in troops, but his spokesman, Jim Manley, declared, ''If it's not temporary in nature, it's a nonstarter.''

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Representative Steny H. Hoyer, a Maryland Democrat who will be the House majority leader, stopped short of saying that Democrats would exercise the power of the purse and decrease financing for American troops.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Yet he said the new Congress was ''not going to sit silently by while policies are pursued with which we don't agree.''

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: Still, the Bush administration intends to try to find support from the crop of newly elected members of Congress -- particularly those who were elected from Republican districts -- as the president works to build support for his Iraq strategy before the State of the Union address, now set for Jan. 23.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: On the issue of sending more troops to Iraq, the White House is also reaching out to Senate Democrats who are facing re-election in 2008.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: ''I am not in favor of that unless the president can convince me otherwise,'' Senator Mark Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat who will serve on the Armed Services Committee, said of a possible troop increase.

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
column3: ''I think that the Congress, after 9/11, was willing to give him the benefit of the doubt on a whole range of issues related to Iraq,'' Mr. Pryor said, ''but we've been there four years now and it's time for him to clearly have the burden of proof.''

column2: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: A man shot and killed by police officers during a burglary here early Monday was identified by law enforcement authorities as the suspect in a string of five shooting deaths in South Carolina over the last 10 days.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: Sheriff Bill Blanton of Cherokee County, S.C., where the killings took place, confirmed Monday evening that the authorities had been seeking the man killed in the burglary, Patrick T. Burris, a felon with a long record who had served seven years in prison and was paroled in April.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: Police still are trying to establish a motive for the killings and any connection between the victims and the suspect.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: The investigation, Blanton said, would shift to learning more about Burris, and whom he traveled with and where he had been.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: "It's not over," he said.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: "It's just changing gears."

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: The killings started June 27 with the shooting of a 63-year-old peach farmer, found in his home in Gaffney.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: Four days later, an 83-year-old woman and her 50-year-old daughter were found bound and shot inside the mother's home.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: The next day, a man and his 15-year-old daughter were shot inside their family's store about a mile from downtown Gaffney.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: Evidence collected at the crime scene and characteristics of Burris' vehicle linked him to the killings, authorities said.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: They declined to give details.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: The shootings terrified residents along the state line between North and South Carolina, leading many to carry weapons, and prompting business owners to keep their doors locked.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: On Monday, about 3 a.m., police in North Carolina received a report of a suspicious vehicle backing up to a vacant house.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: When police arrived, authorities said, Burris opened fire and was killed when the officers fired back.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: Burris had been convicted of multiple crimes in at least four states, and his criminal history was 25 pages long.

column2: POLICE SHOOT TO DEATH SUSPECT IN S.C. KILLING SPREE
column3: "At some point, the criminal justice system is going to have to explain why this gentleman was out on the streets," said Reggie Lloyd, director of the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Government complacency, poor planning and dereliction of duty during Hurricane Katrina contributed to the deaths of dozens of the frail and sick in New Orleans, and to the suffering of many others who were stranded in area hospitals and nursing homes unable to care for them, Senate investigators said Tuesday.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: In the second day of Senate hearings on the hurricane response, the focus was on what investigators called perhaps the most outrageous chapter of the storm: the mistreatment of nursing home and hospital patients during the disaster.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: ''How could such a thing happen?''

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine and chairwoman of the Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, asked the officials from the State of Louisiana, the City of New Orleans and the state association of nursing homes who attended the hearings.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: ''Why were so many left behind?''

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: The witnesses acknowledged a long list of failures that meant there was no coordinated or tested plan in place to evacuate the frail, sick or poor, though studies had warned for more than a decade that an estimated 100,000 New Orleans residents without transportation would need such help in a major hurricane.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: As a result, patients sat in hospitals and nursing homes for days without electricity, fuel, air-conditioning or sufficient food, the witnesses and senators said.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: ''It is natural for all of us to believe that fault lies with someone else,'' said Johnny B. Bradberry, secretary of the Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: ''The real truth is Katrina moved faster than we did.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: All of us on the local, state and the federal levels were overwhelmed, undermined and outmuscled by Mother Nature.''

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Mr. Bradberry, in an interview with Senate staff members before the hearing, acknowledged that he had done nothing to honor an agreement he signed in April 2005 that his department would be responsible for planning the evacuation of the frail in an emergency.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: ''We had no plans in place to do any of this,'' he said.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Instead, he testified Tuesday, his focus was on improving the plan for the mass evacuation of the general population, creating a system that opened all the major highway lanes moving away from New Orleans.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: This ''contraflow'' plan is credited with helping perhaps 1.2 million area residents get out of harm's way.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Dr. Kevin U. Stephens, director of the New Orleans Health Department, testified that starting in late 2004 he had tried to create his own plan with bus companies, riverboat owners and Amtrak to evacuate the city's ''special needs'' population.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: But the negotiations were not complete when Hurricane Katrina hit, Dr. Stephens said, in part because of liability questions.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Nursing homes, meanwhile, were each supposed to have evacuation plans.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: At hospitals, because some patients would inevitably be deemed too ill to move, backup generators were to be in place so care could be provided during and after the storm.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: But both plans failed, the investigators were told, in a breakdown that had been predicted in regional hurricane emergency drills.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: First, only 21 percent of area nursing homes, or nearly 60, evacuated before the storm; one witness said this occurred because in the past, nursing homes were not reimbursed for the cost of the evacuation if the predicted storm did not hit.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: And many hospitals ignored years of warnings to put generators and electrical switching equipment in places protected from flooding, the witnesses said.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Once the storm had passed and the city had flooded, even though thousands of patients needed to be evacuated, nursing home operators often could not call for help.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Even when the requests got through, they were not given a high priority, testified Joseph A. Donchess, executive director of the Louisiana Nursing Home Association.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Extraordinary suffering and even death resulted, Mr. Donchess said.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: At Bethany Nursing Home in New Orleans, for example, which was surrounded by floodwaters, six or seven patients died while they waited four days for buses to move them, he said.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Louisiana statistics released this week show that nearly 70 percent of the 796 deceased Hurricane Katrina victims identified as of late January were 61 years old or older.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Senator Collins read an e-mail exchange that took place two days before the hurricane hit, in which an official of the federal Department of Health and Human Services asked a Louisiana official if help was needed ''for patient movement/evacuation or anything else.''

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: The response, an e-mail message from the federal official said, was that ''they do not require anything at this time and they would be in touch if and when they needed assistance.''

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Dr. Jimmy Guidry, the state health officer of Louisiana, said the offer for aid was rejected because he did not believe that the federal government was prepared to help.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: Ms. Collins said this answer was unacceptable.

column2: Committee Focuses on Failure to Aid New Orleans's Infirm
column3: ''I wonder,'' she said, ''if the dire straits that we heard described this morning would have been as bad as they were if this offer had been accepted.''

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: In an article published on a friendly op-ed page, and from the regal confines of the White House, President Bush greeted the incoming Democratic leadership of Congress on Wednesday with a message of bipartisanship.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: But he also sent another message: I'm still the guy with the big plane, the big office (the oval one) and the presidential seal.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: With the op-ed, in The Wall Street Journal, and in the Rose Garden appearance, Mr. Bush sought to set the governing agenda one day before Democrats were officially to take control of Congress and alter the balance of power that has favored Mr. Bush's party for nearly his entire presidency.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: In doing so, Mr. Bush mixed calls for unity in governing with a series of red flags on his signature issues.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: Tax increases?

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: Forget it.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: ''The elections have not reversed the laws of economics,'' Mr. Bush wrote in The Journal.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: ''It is a fact that economies do best when you reward hard work by allowing people to keep more of what they have earned.''

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: The war in Iraq?

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: ''We now have the opportunity to build a bipartisan consensus to fight and win the war,'' he wrote.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: In other words, we're staying.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: That new Democratic majority?

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: It isn't really so big.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: ''The minority party, especially where the margins are close,'' Mr. Bush wrote, ''has a strong say in the form bills take.''

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: And the president, he added -- lest anyone forget -- has the constitutional authority ''to use his judgment whether they should be signed into law.''

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: Several Democrats said Mr. Bush's words on Wednesday had raised questions about what kind of president would show up when they get down to the business of governing side by side.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: Some Democrats may have hoped it would be the George W. Bush who contritely acknowledged a ''thumpin' '' for his party the day after the elections in November.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: But the evidence suggests it is more likely to be the man who all but ignored the disputed circumstances of his election in 2000, governed from then as if he had an expansive mandate and who -- even as he has employed soothing tones in speaking to and about Democrats for the last two months -- has gradually but firmly reasserted himself on both foreign and domestic policy.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: ''I think what the op-ed showed was the fundamental division within the White House and probably within the president's head whether to stick to the old issues and just talk bipartisanship versus really doing it,'' said Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, the new vice chairman of the Democratic caucus in the Senate, in an interview.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: The first few weeks of January are traditionally when the White House carefully rolls out new or repackaged policy initiatives before the president's State of the Union address, a period when he can set the agenda.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: But for the first time since early 2002, when Democrats controlled the Senate, Mr. Bush has to share power and the national microphone.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: He also has to show that he has a domestic agenda at a time when his presidency is largely consumed by Iraq.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: Both sides were making some effort on Wednesday to play nice.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: White House officials noted that the president had highlighted several areas in which he has shown a willingness to work more closely with Democrats, like on a new minimum wage and a new immigration law.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: And the White House arranged for a plane to bring the incoming Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, and Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, back to Washington from Gerald R. Ford's funeral in Grand Rapids, Mich., in time for a reception with Mr. Bush and the other Congressional leaders.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: In a memorandum that Mr. Reid issued Wednesday to fellow Democrats, he wrote, ''I'm encouraged that President Bush said today that he wants to work in bipartisanship.''

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: But, he added, ''I hope he means it.''

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: And in defining his own approach to bipartisanship, Mr. Reid went on to praise Senator Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, saying Mr. Smith's commentary last month on the administration's war policy -- in which Mr. Smith said it ''may even be criminal'' -- had ''signaled a sea change over how Congress will address the Iraq war.''

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: Mr. Reid promised to work with Republicans to ''bring oversight and accountability to the Bush administration's conduct of the war and ensure a new policy that meets conditions on the ground'' but also ''allows our troops to come home.''

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: Democrats were moving quickly to hold the administration accountable, in their view, for its mistakes, promising to hold as many as a dozen oversight hearings on the war alone in the next few weeks.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: In interviews, White House officials did not hesitate to acknowledge that they were taking advantage of the last day before the Democrats take control to assert some presidential power.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: Nor did they dispute Democrats' suspicions that the White House placed Mr. Bush's opinion piece in The Journal to reassure a target audience of nervous fiscal conservatives -- and the financial markets -- that he remained philosophically opposed to any tax increases.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: But administration officials disputed Democratic assertions that the president was trying to upstage them before their big day.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: ''It's an appropriate time to say where we are on these things and to again reiterate the president's view that we can work together to find common ground,'' said Tony Fratto, a White House spokesman.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: ''It also doesn't mean that a Democrat-controlled Congress passes whatever they want and we sign it -- that's not bipartisanship.''

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: But it was clear that as both sides spoke about bipartisanship, they were defining it on different terms.

column2: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
column3: Mr. Fratto acknowledged as much, saying, ''We'll have to see as we go forward over the next six months, in particular, if everyone has the same understanding of what bipartisanship means.''

column2: Soldier Reaches Plea Deal in the Killing of 3 Iraqis
column3: A soldier from the 101st Airborne Division is scheduled to plead guilty next Tuesday to a reduced charge for mercy killing in connection with the death of three unarmed Iraqi men shot by American infantrymen last spring, according to lawyers for other defendants in the case.

column2: Soldier Reaches Plea Deal in the Killing of 3 Iraqis
column3: The terms of the plea arrangement will allow the soldier, Specialist Juston R. Graber, originally charged with capital murder, to be convicted of aggravated assault and to receive a nine-month prison sentence in exchange for his testifying against three other members of his squad, the lawyers said.

column2: Soldier Reaches Plea Deal in the Killing of 3 Iraqis
column3: The three other soldiers, members of the same company as Specialist Graber in the division's Third Brigade, still face courts-martial on premeditated-murder charges, making them eligible for the death penalty or, barring that, life in prison.

column2: Soldier Reaches Plea Deal in the Killing of 3 Iraqis
column3: Army prosecutors have accused them of carrying out an impromptu plan, following a raid on a marshy island northwest of Baghdad, to kill the three Iraqis after cutting off their plastic handcuffs and forcing them to run, still blindfolded, from the squalid hut where they had been discovered.

column2: Soldier Reaches Plea Deal in the Killing of 3 Iraqis
column3: The two soldiers accused of firing on the men as they fled -- Specialist William B. Hunsaker and Pfc.

column2: Soldier Reaches Plea Deal in the Killing of 3 Iraqis
column3: Corey R. Clagett -- have said they shot in self-defense after the three broke free from the thin ''zip-tie'' handcuffs and attacked them.

column2: Soldier Reaches Plea Deal in the Killing of 3 Iraqis
column3: A third soldier, Staff Sgt.

column2: Soldier Reaches Plea Deal in the Killing of 3 Iraqis
column3: Raymond L. Girouard, the squad's ranking member, is accused of devising the plan to kill the men, then punching Private Clagett and cutting Specialist Hunsaker to give the appearance that they had been attacked.

column2: Hurricane Willa strengthens to Category 4 storm off Mexico's Pacific coast
column3: MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - Hurricane Willa gained dangerous strength early on Monday as it churned toward Mexico’s Pacific coast, an area frequented by tourists, with torrential rain and major flooding in the offing, the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC) said.

column2: Hurricane Willa strengthens to Category 4 storm off Mexico's Pacific coast

column3: Willa was expected to hit Mexico’s west coast on Tuesday afternoon or evening.

column2: Hurricane Willa strengthens to Category 4 storm off Mexico's Pacific coast
column3: Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Vicente, which formed in the Pacific off southern Mexico on Saturday, began to weaken while hovering along the southern Mexican coast on Sunday and by early Monday was located about 195 miles (310 km) southeast of Acapulco.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Arrogance has never been attractive in a leader.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Now, in corporate chief executives anyhow, it may be a career ender.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: The surprising defenestration yesterday of Robert L. Nardelli, head of Home Depot and one of the nation's most imperious and highly paid chief executives, was a victory for shareholders hoping to force corporate directors to be more accountable on the increasingly incendiary issue of executive pay.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Even though the board gave him $20 million that was not a part of his employment contract, perhaps smoothing his way out the door, the departure seemed to be a watershed.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: No longer can executives demand -- and directors happily grant -- contracts worth hundreds of millions of dollars without at least some shareholders uttering a peep.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Indeed, Mr. Nardelli's resignation seems to indicate a rising fear among Home Depot's directors that they would be subject to even more investor ire and personal embarrassment during the 2007 proxy season than they encountered in 2006, when Mr. Nardelli ran the annual shareholder meeting like a lord over his fief.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''The departure of Nardelli is good news for shareholders,'' said Frederick E. Rowe Jr., a money manager in Dallas and president of Investors for Director Accountability.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''To borrow from Winston Churchill, this is the end of the beginning in the war to make directors accountable to the shareholder owners they represent.''

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Mr. Nardelli's fall from the executive firmament was fairly stunning.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: In just six years, he went from being one of the most sought-after chief executives, forged in the management crucible that is General Electric, to a top target of investors outraged by his $245 million in total pay over the last five years.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: That amount was seen as completely at odds with the dismal performance of Home Depot stock on his watch.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Yesterday, the shares closed at $41.07, almost 6 percent lower than they were the day Mr. Nardelli arrived at Home Depot in December 2000.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: 's now will understand that they've got to put their conscience and shareholder wealth well above their personal gain,'' said Jeffrey M. Cunningham, chairman and chief executive of Directorship, an online information service for board members.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''Boards create termination packages when no one even contemplates there is going to be a termination and they are extraordinarily rich.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: You are going to see all those plans rethought and rationalized for the new environment.''

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Shareholders of Home Depot have been smoldering for several years about the company's executive pay practices.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Back when Mr. Nardelli arrived, for example, shareholders raised eyebrows after the company granted him a $10 million loan that it subsequently forgave.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: He has earned $20 million to $37 million each year since he joined the company.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: In 2004, the company quietly changed the measurement it used to calculate long-term incentive pay for executives, upsetting investors when they learned of it later.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Previously, the performance measure was based on a peer-group comparison, but the new measure involved only the company's growth in earnings per share.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: It was more easily reached because it was based solely on Home Depot's performance not that of other companies.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: To some shareholders, changing the performance target in the middle of a year seemed an attempt to ensure a payout despite a dismal performance.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''We had a problem with that change,'' said Bess Joffe, manager for the Americas at Hermes Investment Management, a money management firm owned by the British Telecom Pension Scheme, the largest pension plan in Britain.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''After all, shareholders don't get to change the terms under which they bought their shares midstream.''

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: But it was not until last year that Home Depot's shareholders began to express serious disenchantment with the company's directors over Mr. Nardelli's pay.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Last March, about two months before Home Depot's annual shareholder meeting, the board was named one of the 11 worst executive pay offenders by the Corporate Library, a corporate governance research firm.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: In the weeks leading up to the meeting, shareholder advisory firms recommended withholding votes from Home Depot directors to voice their dismay over the disconnect between performance and pay at the company.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: But Mr. Nardelli's biggest error, and the act that may have set his demise in motion, was his shocking decision to run the annual meeting last May alone, insisting that his directors stay away and limiting questions from the shareholders.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''I've never heard of anything like that happening before, where directors don't show up,'' Ms. Joffe said.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''It's the one time of year that shareholders have a right to be present and stand up and speak their mind and directors have to respond.''

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Stockholders were outraged.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: At least 30 percent of shareholders voting at the meeting withheld support from 10 of the company's directors.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Some 32 percent withheld support from Mr. Nardelli.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Almost 36 percent of those voting withheld support from Claudio X. Gonzalez, chairman and chief executive of Kimberly-Clark's Mexico operations and the director who had headed the compensation committee when the company changed its performance goals midstream.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Many shareholders also favored a proposal urging the Home Depot board to allow its investors to vote on an advisory basis to approve the company's compensation; 40 percent voted for the measure.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Shareholders also supported a measure that would have required the board to accept resignations from directors who failed to receive support from a majority of votes cast.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: After the meeting, Home Depot said it would require such a vote from shareholders for the election of its directors.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Even so, the company continued to tinker last year with its pay practices in a way that may have been intended to generate pay for Mr. Nardelli in periods of poor performance at the company.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Last November, a Home Depot spokesman disclosed that the company's huge stock buybacks, which have the effect of increasing earnings when measured per share, would be included in the calculation of long-term incentive targets.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: In previous years, the effects of the buybacks were excluded from the calculations.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: John A. Hill, the chairman of Putnam Funds, was one investor whose organization voted against Home Depot management at last year's meeting.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: He said he was optimistic that Mr. Nardelli's resignation signaled a new responsiveness among corporate directors.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: But he is uncertain.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''I think if a lot more shareholders withhold their votes for this board in the upcoming proxy season over their agreement with Nardelli, then it will really start to have an impact,'' Mr. Hill said.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''But as long as it is a minority, it won't.''

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: Mr. Hill personally experienced Mr. Nardelli's disdain toward his shareholders.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: As chairman of Putnam Funds, he wrote a letter after the annual meeting to Mr. Nardelli explaining why he had not earned the funds' support at the election.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: He did not get a reply until August, when a reporter asked Home Depot why the chief executive had not responded to one of its large shareholders.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''He had become a lightning rod with the stock down,'' Mr. Hill said.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: ''But his not replying to our letter showed an arrogance there that came in on him.''

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
column3: It seems that ''my way or the highway'' -- Mr. Nardelli's message to Home Depot's beleaguered shareholders in recent years -- does not play that well anymore.

column2: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: (Reuters Health) - With recent revelations that U.S. law enforcement can - and already has - dipped into consumer genealogy DNA databases to help solve crimes, experts say more discussion of the ethical issues raised by this unintended use of personal information is needed.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: It’s unclear, for instance, whether online genealogy site users know their DNA is available to criminal investigators - and whether they’d object to it being used for that purpose, write the authors of an essay exploring the topic in the Annals of Internal Medicine.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: “We’re seeing a divide about this right now.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: On one hand, it’s a powerful technology to solve cases, but it also raises questions for consumers,” said lead author Benjamin Berkman, who heads the section on the ethics of genetics and new technologies at the National Institutes of Health’s Department of Bioethics in Bethesda, Maryland.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: “The idea that they upload their data for genealogy purposes and it’s used in such a different way really surprises some people,” he told Reuters Health in a telephone interview.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: “The terms of service agreements don’t explain this clearly, and even if they did, people wouldn’t read it or find it in the dense legalese.”

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: Berkman and his co-authors were moved to write about the issue after the April arrest of a 72-year-old man suspected of being the Golden State Killer, a serial rapist and murderer who committed at least 12 murders, more than 50 rapes and more than 100 burglaries in California from 1974 to 1986.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: Police detectives had compared DNA from several crime scenes against online DNA-genealogy data to track down this suspect.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: Although investigators have long used DNA for forensic purposes, they have typically compared samples to databases created specifically for criminal justice purposes, the authors note.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: And in the realm of scientific and medical research, people who provide samples have clear expectations for “informed consent.” They want researchers to ask permission, but are generally comfortable with giving it for wide-ranging research uses of the material.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: Ethicists disagree over how specific consumers’ consent should be for their genealogy DNA information.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: “Genealogy is typically done for entertainment purposes,” Berkman said.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: “People may not realize uploading their DNA could be responsible for a cousin’s arrest as well.”

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: This use of DNA information has consequences beyond the person who uploaded it.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: It can result in arrests of guilty relatives for crimes they committed but also potentially false-positives mistakenly identifying innocent people, the study authors note.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: When investigators conduct forensics research with genealogy DNA, they may also interview suspects and contact relatives to obtain more information.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: Since law enforcement agencies haven’t been clear about how these investigations are conducted, it’s tough to debate whether these communications are harmful or an ethical quandary, said Stephanie Malia Fullerton of the University of Washington School of Medicine’s Department of Bioethics and Humanities, who wasn’t involved in the essay.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: “We don’t actually know how many people who have placed their data in these online databases are subject to forensic uses,” she said in a telephone interview.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: “We also don’t know how these partial genetic matches are used, and we can speculate about the possible harms, but we don’t know what exactly is involved or who is contacted.”

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: Berkman and his colleagues note that, under legal theory, people have no reasonable expectation of privacy for “abandoned” materials such as hair or nail clippings or cigarette butts.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: Courts have allowed law enforcement officials to test DNA left behind in different settings, and it can be argued that since users voluntarily upload their DNA into online commercial databases, the legal implications may be simpler to understand than the ethical ones.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: In the future, a commitment to transparency is important, they write.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: Researchers should begin to study how many law enforcement agencies use forensic DNA searching and how they do it.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: These departments should also adopt formalized standards and mechanisms for accountability.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: Lawmakers should also consider placing some restrictions on using DNA evidence so it’s an investigative tool rather than a primary source of evidence, they write.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: “Think carefully before uploading your genealogy data,” Berkman added.

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: “We’re not saying it’s unduly risky or a bad idea, but be comfortable with the idea that police may use your information to solve crimes before you sign up for these services.”

column2: Experts outline ethics issues with use of genealogy DNA to solve crimes
column3: SOURCE: bit.ly/2kC8der Annals of Internal Medicine, online May 29, 2018.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: BEIJING, March 6 (Xinhua) -- To name China's eight non-communist parties is quite challenging for many foreigners, let alone understand the differences between them.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: The press conference was held on the sidelines of the ongoing first session of the 13th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), the top political advisory body, many of whose members are from the parties.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: WHO THEY ARE

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: -- The Revolutionary Committee of the Chinese Kuomintang (RCCK) was founded in 1948 in Hong Kong.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: -- The China Democratic League (CDL), founded in 1941, mainly consists of intellectuals working in the fields of culture, education, science, and technology.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: -- The China National Democratic Construction Association (CNDCA), founded in 1945, mainly consists of patriotic industrialists, business people, and intellectuals.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: -- The China Association for Promoting Democracy (CAPD), founded in 1945, mainly consists of intellectuals working in the fields of culture, education, publishing, and science.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: -- The Chinese Peasants and Workers Democratic Party (CPWDP), founded in 1930, mainly consists of leading intellectuals in the fields of health care, population resources, and ecological protection.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: -- The China Zhi Gong Party, founded in 1925, mainly consists of overseas Chinese who have returned to the mainland, relatives of nationals living abroad as well as those with close connections with overseas Chinese.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: -- The Jiusan Society, founded in 1945, mainly consists of senior and mid-level intellectuals engaged in science, technology, culture, education, medical and health work.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: -- The Taiwan Democratic Self-Government League, founded in 1947, mainly consists of Taiwanese living in the mainland.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: HOW IT WORKS

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua
column3: The leaders shared the highlights of their participation in political consultation, deliberation of state affairs, and democratic supervision.

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua

column2: China's non-communist parties introduce their missions, contributions - Xinhua

column3: The Chinese system is new, because it unites all political parties and people without party affiliation toward a common goal, effectively preventing the flaws of the absence of oversight in one-party rule, or power rotation and nasty competition among multiple political parties, according to Xi.

column3: EVEN before last April's disastrous floods, the Meyers Grove neighborhood along the Neversink River wasn't exactly Malibu, just an unpretentious jumble of modest houses, trailers and bungalows, many of them converted from summer vacation cottages.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: But 10 months after the river roared over its banks, cresting at 11 feet over flood stage, it still looks like parts of New Orleans, with some houses repaired and rebuilt, some vacant and condemned, and others reduced to doleful piles of rubble, waiting to be hauled away.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: Last year's flooding on the Delaware River and some of its tributaries, including the Neversink, may be a fleeting memory downstate, but for residents in Meyers Grove, along Rivers Edge Road down the road in nearby Huguenot and in dozens of other riverside towns and hamlets, it's no more past than Katrina is for residents of the Gulf Coast.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: So, if Mark D. House, the supervisor of the Town of Deerpark in Orange County, whose 9,000 residents include the people of Meyers Grove, sounds a little hyperbolic as he talks about reservoir levels and spillway management, it's not just him.

column3: This is one subject where the upstate/downstate divide is now more divided than ever.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: ''It's like they're holding a gun to my head, it's loaded, they have their finger on the trigger, and they're squeezing the trigger,'' he said, navigating his way around the neighborhood in his PT Cruiser.

column3: ''And they have the gall to say, oh, by the way, if this should go off, it's not our fault and it's not our responsibility.''

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: The gun, if you want to call it that, is the water in the Neversink Reservoir, now over 100 percent of capacity at a time that it's usually around 80.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: When kept at a lower level, the reservoir, which is part of New York City's water supply system, can help prevent or limit flooding, by giving water from swollen rivers a place to collect rather than cascading downstream.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: But keeping such reservoirs as full as possible maximizes the city's ability to provide water downstate even in an extended dry spell.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: The city's Department of Environmental Protection has always said that it's in the water delivery business, not the flood control business, and that, in fact, its reservoirs in the Catskill and Delaware systems have limited abilities to release water and manage flooding.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: But after two severe floods almost back to back, first in September 2004, then in April 2005, that policy now comes across as imperial arrogance to flooded residents and communities.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: So up and down the rivers, people are hiring lawyers, forming organizations, gearing up for something other than business as it's usually been conducted.

Bonacic, whose district encompasses much of the city's watershed, said last week it was outrageous that a year after the flooding, reservoir levels were still at 100 percent capacity, in advance of expected spring rains and snowmelt.

column3: He is calling on officials to lobby against a federal designation the city needs to avoid building a $10 billion filtration system unless the city satisfactorily addresses dam safety and flood control issues.

column3: FOR its part, the environmental agency says it has already altered its policies, consistent with its legal obligations, particularly with the Delaware River Basin Commission, where New York State and its neighbors New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware must approve changes in water releases.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: The agency says it has already begun a program of releases of water based on anticipated snowmelt and has proposed a more ambitious one that would allow releases that would be equal to the water from a one-inch rainfall over a six-hour period.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: ''I think it's a start, and it's a show of good faith,'' said Michael Principe, deputy commissioner of the D.E.P.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: ''We can never reduce 100 percent of the risk, but this is a way of mitigating some of the risk, which is the best we can expect.''

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: 's flood control measures on reservoirs and dams built with limited flood control technology.

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down

column2: Floodwaters Reveal a Divide Between Upstate and Down
column3: Still, it's clear that the recent flooding has, for now at least, changed the balance between the people upstate who live beneath the dams and people downstate who just want to know that water will come out when they open the tap.

column3: Republicans who have consulted with administration officials on personnel said the White House chief of staff, Joshua B. Bolten, was looking for a seasoned Washington hand to succeed Harriet E. Miers, the White House counsel who announced her resignation on Thursday.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: Republicans said Friday in interviews that the White House was now, in essence, seeking a politically savvy outsider with ties throughout the capital and in Congress who might be called upon to become something of a public figure in potentially high-profile fights.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: ''They need somebody who can sit down face-to-face with an ornery committee chairman and work out a conflict over an oversight request,'' said Bradford A. Berenson, a former associate counsel for Mr. Bush during his first term.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: ''The job will require a certain minimum level of stature and a minimum level of political experience.''

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: Several Republicans, including some former administration officials, said the new White House counsel would also need the stature to counterbalance David S. Addington, the powerful chief of staff of Vice President Dick Cheney.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: Mr. Addington has tended to argue against cooperating with Congressional requests for classified information, a position that may require some softening, or at least more diplomacy, in the 110th Congress.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: The White House is, in some respects, seeking a figure who is the mirror opposite of Ms. Miers, who has not shown a high level of comfort being a public figure, especially since withdrawing herself from the Supreme Court nominating process in 2005 under heavy fire from liberals and conservatives.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: Ms. Miers spent most of her career in Texas, and did most of her maneuvering within the White House.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: Mr. Bush's choice will be in the mold of the former solicitor general, Theodore B. Olson, said Republican allies of Mr. Bush who are familiar with the administration's views.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: These people, speaking anonymously to preserve their access to White House officials, said they took Mr. Olson at his word that he was not interested in the position.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: These Republicans said other contenders in that mold include Fred F. Fielding, the Reagan-era White House counsel who is now a corporate lawyer in Washington; Charles J. Cooper, a former Justice Department official under President Ronald Reagan, also now practicing law in Washington; Laurence H. Silberman, the retired United States Court of Appeals judge close to Mr. Cheney; and David Aufhauser, the former general counsel for the Treasury Department who is now the global general counsel for UBS, the Swiss bank.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: Mr. Aufhauser, who has worked with Ms. Miers, also played a crucial legal role for Mr. Bush during the recount of the presidential vote in 2000.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: Another name bandied about by some Republicans, but considered a long shot because he lacks Washington legal experience, is J. Thomas Schieffer, the ambassador to Japan who is both a friend and former business partner of President Bush.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: Mr. Schieffer has been overseas since 2001, having been ambassador to Australia, and may be interested in a Washington job.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: The people familiar with the White House thinking said Ms. Miers's departure, coming amid a number of changes in top administration jobs, had been among the most painful personally for Mr. Bush, who has grown quite close to her over more than a decade of collaboration.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: Her resignation capped months of speculation about her future at the White House.

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress

column2: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
column3: Two administration officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss a delicate personnel issue, said that Ms. Miers was ready to leave all the same, and disputed suggestions that she was forced out of the post, which they said she could have kept had she wanted to.
