column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: MERGERS and acquisitions have been booming, and investors looking for a way to profit from them have a simple solution at hand: they can invest in mutual funds that specialize in buying shares of companies that are being acquired.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: But don't expect to make a killing.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: These funds -- and there are at least five of them -- are generally considered to be having a good year if they double the returns on three-month Treasury bills.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Last year, the five funds returned 10.1 percent, on average, while T-bills averaged less than 5 percent, but still gained far less than the nearly 16 percent return for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Over five years, the funds' return was 5.5 percent, annualized, compared with 6.2 percent for the S.& P.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Mainly, the funds offer extremely consistent gains from a highly diverse portfolio, and at the end of a year investors almost always have more than they did in January.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Consider the Merger Fund, the oldest and biggest at $1.5 billion.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: It has had only one losing year out of 17.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: The Gabelli ABC fund, the second-oldest and third-largest with $193 million in assets, is a perfect 13-0.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: ''What we do is fairly straightforward,'' said Frederick W. Green, president of the Merger Fund.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: ''We're the sleep-well-at-night fund.''

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: The gains come from buying shares in a company that is being acquired, but for less than the acquirer plans to pay, then cashing out when the deal is done.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Because, as Mr. Green says, 95 percent of the mergers are completed, generally within a matter of months, it's a pretty safe bet that buyers will earn the difference, or spread, between the two prices.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: The favorable odds go a long way toward explaining why merger or risk arbitrage, as the strategy is known, produces returns that tend to be lower, on average, than those of other stock investments.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Investors trying to buy the shares after a merger announcement can't expect to get the stock for much less than the acquirer's offer, because the current shareholders can reasonably count on getting that price shortly.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: How much less depends on a number of factors for both buyer and seller -- for example, what their money could reliably earn in another investment, like three-month Treasury bills, or the value attached to the 1-in-20 possibility that the deal will fall through (say, over regulatory problems).

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: When mergers are plentiful, as they are now, fund managers can pick their targets more carefully than usual.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: And with interest rates having edged higher, the spreads have widened between the post-announcement market price and the offer price.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: At times, some merger funds will short the stock of the acquirer as well as buy shares in the target company.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: The tactic is similar to that used by hedge funds engaged in arbitrage, though without black-box secrecy or the risk of leveraging.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: The price of the acquirer's shares tends to slip after the offer is made, so shorting those shares is a way to improve returns.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: The five-year-old AXA Enterprise Mergers and Acquisitions fund, the second-largest fund with $304 million in assets, adds a much riskier arbitrage strategy to the mix.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: One-third of its capital is invested in companies that Mario J. Gabelli, the veteran money manager who oversees the fund along with his namesake ABC fund, regards as having the potential to be acquired.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: For example, three companies in which he invests as takeover candidates are U.S. Cellular, Sensient Technologies and Cadbury Schweppes.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Potential takeover targets in general are more speculative investments than the traditional arbitrage plays.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: If the main appeal of a company is its takeover potential and no offers materialize, its stock price may fall and give the fund a loss.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: On the other hand, if the company is taken over, the fund gets the full measure of the premium the acquirer pays.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Such gambles increase risk, but may also improve total returns dramatically over the standard arbitrage performance -- as was the case in 2006 with AXA Enterprise.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: For the year, according to Morningstar, AXA Enterprise gained 15.2 percent, more than three percentage points ahead of Gabelli ABC, the runner-up, at 12 percent.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: They were followed by the Merger Fund, at 11 percent; the year-old, $7 million QCM Absolute Return fund, at 7 percent; and the six-year-old, $84 million Arbitrage fund, at 6.1 percent.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: But while 2006 was a good year for the funds, not even AXA Enterprise quite caught up with the S.& P. index, which returned 15.8 percent for the year.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Over one-, three- and five-year stretches, the returns of the group averaged several percentage points below those of the S.& P.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Another concern is cost.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: Four of the funds have expense ratios that are higher than the mutual fund average of 1.27 percent, according to S.& P. (And Enterprise has a front-end load, or sales charge, of 4.75 percent.)

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: The exception is Gabelli ABC, whose ratio is half the average.

column2: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
column3: But its minimum initial investment is $10,000 (though down from $50,000 in 2005), versus $2,000 or $2,500 at the other funds.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: INSURANCE companies warn against them, some consumer advocates eye them with suspicion, and many potential clients are not even aware of what they do.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Public insurance adjusters, private claims experts who negotiate with insurers to win settlements for homeowners and businesses, are a misunderstood lot.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Jarrod M. Fischer, an insurance adjuster based in Lake Success, N.Y., who specializes in high-end residential claims, estimates that half the people he meets have never heard the term.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Yet, once ''we explain our service, 9 times out of 10 they'll hire me,'' Mr. Fischer said.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: After years of working in relative obscurity, mainly in the Northeast, public adjusters are becoming increasingly prominent in hurricane-torn Florida, Mississippi and Louisiana.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: In Florida, where a decade of big storms has led to tighter insurance regulations, the profession is flourishing.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: In the mid-1980's the state had only a handful of adjusters, primarily in Miami and Jacksonville; today there are more than 400, said Ray Altieri Jr., the president of Transco American Claims, a public adjuster firm in Tampa.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Only a fraction of homes in the hurricane zone were covered by federal flood insurance and residential reimbursement is capped at $250,000.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Additional reimbursement from a homeowner's policy can mean the difference between rebuilding and defaulting on a mortgage.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: With or without flood insurance, ''the public adjuster is going to identify a greater amount of loss and damage than a homeowner ever would on their own,'' said Leslie L. Knox, the president of Andrew K. Knox & Company in Toms River, N.J., and the incoming president of the National Association of Public Insurance Adjusters, a trade group.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: In the weeks following Katrina, with the number of claims rising -- up to 1.75 million as of Jan. 31, according to the Insurance Information Institute, a trade group -- Louisiana and Mississippi, which had not previously licensed public adjusters, issued emergency directives allowing them to operate once they register with the respective insurance departments.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: By December, 495 adjusters had done so in Mississippi; in Louisiana, the number is 1,170.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: After Katrina hit, Ron Delo, the president of Insurance Claim Consultants, a public adjuster firm in Tampa, tripled his staff to nine, including two in Florida and two in Louisiana.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Mr. Delo said his company is working with about 275 residential clients with hurricane-related claims.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: The claims were averaging $150,000 to $250,000, he said.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Public adjusters, who work on contingency and earn a percentage of the claim, take inventory, hire appraisers and engineers, and negotiate with insurance companies over the extent of coverage and the cost of repairs.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Adjusters say they offer practical knowledge based on the kind of familiarity with the claims process that few homeowners ever have.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: And people who are reeling from the impact of a disaster often appreciate having a consultant to lean on.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: ''My wife and I were in shock,'' said Dennis Hersch, referring to an electrical fire that damaged their triplex apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan in 2004.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: ''One minute your life is all normal and the next minute I had 30 to 40 firefighters trudging through the place.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Everything smelled of smoke.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: There was broken glass.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: It was a nightmare.''

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Mr. Hersch, the global chairman of mergers and acquisitions at J. P. Morgan, and his wife, Huguette, hired Mr. Fischer, who works for the Affiliated Adjustment Group, after he knocked on the Hersches' door after the fire.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Ten months later, Mr. Hersch said, he received a ''very fair'' settlement from the insurance company, close to $400,000.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Mr. Fischer's cut was 8 percent, less than the 12.5 percent rate cap under New York State law.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Controversy over the adjusters' middleman role has risen right along with their numbers.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Mississippi, in particular, had been seen as hostile to the practice.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: When the emergency directive to license them was being discussed, regulators pushed for a 2 percent cap on fees.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: The cap was set at 7 percent, but as part of the directive adjusters are allowed only to assess values and costs and to file a claim -- they may not negotiate with an insurer over coverage.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: In Louisiana last November, the insurance commissioner, J. Robert Wooley, warned that some public adjusters ''take advantage of consumers,'' and that some contractors approach homeowners saying they are public adjusters in order to get work.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: A spokeswoman for the insurance industry -- which is where many adjusters get their start -- argued that consumers can deal directly with the insurance companies on claims, using an in-house adjuster free of charge.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: And Bob Hunter, the director of insurance at the Consumer Federation of America, the national advocacy group, agrees.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: ''Why would you want someone to take a piece of your money?''

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Mr. Hunter asked.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: ''If you really feel like you're getting a runaround from the insurance company and they're really treating you rudely, go to a lawyer.''

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: But some homeowners say they appreciate having a hand when they are feeling vulnerable and overwhelmed.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: As with any contractor, homeowners should ask for references.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: In states that recognize the profession -- Mississippi and Louisiana aside, 38 out of the 50 do, including Connecticut and New Jersey -- adjusters should be licensed, checkable through the state's insurance department.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Bill Bailey, the outside counsel for the Insurance Information Institute, and the managing director of its Hurricane Insurance Information Center, says the right adjuster can make all the difference.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: He tells the story of the time his wife, Irene, was managing a building in Boston and one Friday night in the dead of winter its boiler exploded.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: Unable to reach the insurer, she authorized emergency repairs.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: The insurer turned down the claim, saying she had violated the policy; a public adjuster helped turn that decision around.

column2: In the Wake of Disaster, Help for Hire
column3: ''They can be extremely helpful as long as you know what you're getting,'' Mr. Bailey said.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In 1997, as the government listened in on their phone call, Adham Hassoun, a computer programmer in Broward County, Fla., proposed a road trip to Jose Padilla, a low-wage worker there.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The excursion to Tampa would be his treat, Mr. Hassoun said, and a chance to meet ''some nice, uh, brothers.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Padilla, 36, a Brooklyn-born Puerto Rican who had converted to Islam a few years earlier, knew Mr. Hassoun, an outspoken Palestinian, from his mosque.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Still, according to a transcript of the conversation obtained by The New York Times, Mr. Padilla equivocated as Mr. Hassoun exhorted.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''We take the whole family and have a blast,'' Mr. Hassoun said.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''We go to, uh, our Busch Gardens, you know You won't regret it.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Money-back guarantee.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Padilla, laughing, suggested that they not discuss the matter over the phone.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Hassoun said.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''We're going to Busch Gardens.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: What's the big deal!''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: That conversation took place five years before Mr. Padilla, a United States citizen accused of plotting a ''dirty bomb'' attack against this country, was declared an enemy combatant.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Given that Mr. Padilla and Mr. Hassoun are now criminal defendants in a terrorism conspiracy case in Miami, it sounds suspicious, as if Mr. Hassoun were proposing something more sinister than a weekend at the amusement park.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: He well may have been -- but maybe, too, he was sincere or joking about a Muslim retreat.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Deciphering such chatter in order to construct a convincing narrative of conspiracy is a challenge.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Yet, prosecutors say, the government will rely largely on wiretapped conversations when it puts Mr. Padilla, Mr. Hassoun, and a third defendant, Kifah Jayyousi, on trial as a ''North American support cell'' that sent money, goods and recruits abroad to assist ''global jihad.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Tens of thousands of conversations were recorded.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Some 230 phone calls form the core of the government's case, including 21 that make reference to Mr. Padilla, prosecutors said.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But Mr. Padilla's voice is heard on only seven calls.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: And on those seven, which The Times obtained from a participant in the case, Mr. Padilla does not discuss violent plots.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But this is not the version of Mr. Padilla -- Al Qaeda associate and would-be bomber -- that John Ashcroft, then the attorney general, unveiled in 2002 when he interrupted a trip to Moscow to trumpet Mr. Padilla's capture.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In the four and a half years since then, as the government tested the limits of its power to deal with terrorism outside the traditional law enforcement system, Mr. Padilla is the only accused terrorist to have gone from enemy combatant to criminal defendant.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: His criminal trial, scheduled to begin late this month, will feature none of the initial claims about violent plotting with Al Qaeda that the government cited as justification for detaining Mr. Padilla without formal charges for three and a half years.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Those claims came from the government's overseas interrogations of terrorism suspects, like Abu Zubaydah, which, the government said, Mr. Padilla corroborated, in part, during his own questioning in a military brig in South Carolina.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But, constrained by strict federal rules of evidence that would prohibit or limit the use of information obtained during such interrogations, the government will make a far more circumscribed case against Mr. Padilla in court, effectively demoting him from Al Qaeda's dirty bomber to foot soldier in a somewhat nebulous conspiracy.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The initial dirty bomb accusation did not disappear.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: It quietly resurfaced in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The government filed the dirty bomb charges against Mr. Padilla's supposed accomplice, an Ethiopian-born detainee, at about the same time it indicted Mr. Padilla on relatively lesser offenses in criminal court.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: A Change in Strategy

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The change in Mr. Padilla's status, from enemy combatant to criminal defendant, was abrupt.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: It came late in 2005 as the Supreme Court was weighing whether to take up the legality of his military detention and the Bush administration, by filing criminal charges, pre-empted its review.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In a way, Mr. Padilla's prosecution was a legal maneuver that kept the issue of his detention without charges out of the Supreme Court.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: After apprehending him at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago in May 2002, the Bush administration made a choice: to detain Mr. Padilla militarily, in order to thwart further plotting, rather than to follow him in order to gather evidence that might serve a criminal prosecution.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Now that Mr. Padilla has ended up a criminal defendant after all, the prosecution's case does not fully reflect the Bush administration's view of who he is or what he did.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Senior government officials have said publicly that Mr. Padilla provided self-incriminating information during interrogations, admitting, they said, to undergoing basic terrorist training, to accepting an assignment to blow up apartment buildings in the United States, and to attending a farewell dinner with Khaled Sheikh Mohammed, the suspected master planner of the Sept. 11 attacks, before he flew to Chicago in 2002.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But any confessions by Mr. Padilla while he was detained without charges and denied access to counsel -- whether or not he was mistreated, as his lawyers claim -- would not be admissible in court.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: And it is unlikely that information obtained during the harsh questioning of Al Qaeda detainees would be admissible, either -- and, further, the government is disinclined to expose sensitive intelligence or invite further scrutiny of secret jails overseas.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Probably as a consequence, the current criminal case zeroes in on what the government sees as an earlier stage of Mr. Padilla's involvement with terrorism.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: It focuses primarily on the other defendants' support during the 1990s for Muslim struggles overseas, especially in Bosnia, Kosovo and Chechnya.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Padilla, who was appended to their pre-existing case, in which he had been an unnamed co-conspirator, is depicted as their recruit.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Although prosecutors have declined to discuss the government's strategy, their filings and statements in court provide a picture of the case they are expected to present at trial.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The most tangible allegation against Mr. Padilla is that in 2000 he filled out, under an alias, an Arab-language application to attend a terrorist training camp.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: That application is expected to be offered into evidence alongside the wiretapped conversations, but Mr. Padilla's lawyers say they will contest its admissibility, challenging the government's assertion that the ''mujahideen data form'' belonged to their client.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Robert Chesney, a specialist in national security law at Wake Forest University, called the prosecution a pragmatic one, analogous to ''going after Al Capone on tax evasion.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But Deborah Pearlstein, a lawyer with Human Rights First who has consulted with Mr. Padilla's defense, said that his will never be an ordinary, pragmatic prosecution.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''If Jose Padilla were from Day 1 just charged and tried, then maybe,'' she said.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''But this is a case that comes after three and a half years of the most gross deprivation of human rights that we've seen in this country for a long time.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Further, Ms. Pearlstein noted, the government has reserved the option, should the prosecution fail, of returning Mr. Padilla to the military brig.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: This, she said, ''casts a shadow'' over the current prosecution.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The Bush administration's military case against Binyam Mohamed, 28, the Ethiopian detainee at Guantánamo, put the current proceedings in a different light, too.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In December 2005, Mr. Mohamed was referred to the military commission in Guantánamo on accusations that he conspired with Mr. Padilla on the dirty bomb plot.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: It was little noticed at the time.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But accusations against Mr. Padilla that are nowhere to be found in the indictment against him filled the pages of Mr. Mohamed's charging sheet, with Mr. Padilla repeatedly identified by name.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The sheet referred to the two men meeting in Pakistan after Sept. 11, 2001, studying how to build an improvised dirty bomb, discussing the feasibility of a dirty bomb attack with Al Qaeda officials and agreeing to undertake the mission to blow up buildings.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Mohamed's lawyer, Clive Stafford Smith, said that these charges were based on a forced confession by Mr. Mohamed, who, he said, was tortured overseas into admitting to a story that was fed to him.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''Binyam was told all along that his job was to be a witness against Padilla, Abu Zubaydah and Khaled Sheikh Mohammed,'' Mr. Stafford Smith said, adding that his client ''has no conscience knowledge that he ever met'' Mr. Padilla.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The charges against Mr. Mohamed and other Guantánamo detainees who were headed for prosecution there have been suspended temporarily as a result of the Military Commissions Act passed by Congress in October.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Those charges are likely to be reinstated, a Pentagon official said yesterday.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: That Mr. Mohamed faced dirty bomb charges and Mr. Padilla does not speaks to the central difference between being a terrorism suspect in Guantánamo and a criminal defendant charged with terrorism offenses in the United States.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In Guantánamo, the military commission system that deals with foreign-born terrorism suspects is expected to allow, with some exceptions, the use of information obtained through coercion.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''Federal court rules are restrictive,'' Professor Chesney of Wake Forest University School of Law said.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''The very essence of why they're trying to have that separate military system was to create rules to use information that is deemed by the intelligence community to be trustworthy but wouldn't make it under the federal rules of evidence.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: David Cole, a professor of law at Georgetown University and author of books on terrorism and civil liberties, sees the difference between the two systems more critically: ''What this says clearly is that they feel that they can get away with using tainted evidence in the military commission system that they can't use in the criminal court system.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The Wiretapping Case

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The criminal case against Mr. Padilla has its roots in the prosecution of Sheikh Omer Abdel Rahman, the blind Egyptian cleric who was convicted in 1995 of conspiring to blow up the United Nations and other New York landmarks.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In the early 1990s, Sheikh Rahman's telephone was tapped, and Mr. Hassoun and Dr. Jayyousi, a Jordanian-born American citizen who holds a doctorate in civil engineering, came to the government's attention through phone calls to or from his line.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Then the government, under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, began to eavesdrop on them, which eventually pulled Mr. Padilla into their net, too.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The government presents the three defendants as ''joined at the hip,'' as one prosecutor put it in a hearing last summer.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But Judge Marcia G. Cooke of Federal District Court, noting that Mr. Padilla was appended to a case well under way, asked the government, ''If they are so joined at the hip, why is Mr. Padilla so late to the dance?''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Dr. Jayyousi, a former school system administrator in both Detroit and Washington, D.C., never met Mr. Padilla, his lawyer, William Swor, said.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: It is Mr. Hassoun, the government said, who recruited Mr. Padilla.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But both Mr. Hassoun's and Mr. Padilla's lawyers deny that Mr. Padilla was recruited.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Seven Taped Phone Calls

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Padilla's lawyers and relatives say that he left South Florida for Egypt in September 1998 on a spiritual journey.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: A former juvenile offender, he converted to Islam as part of an effort to straighten out his life, they say.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: His mosque in Fort Lauderdale sponsored his travel, he told friends, relatives and F.B.I.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: agents who interviewed him in 2002.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Hassoun belonged to that mosque, and the telephone transcripts seem to indicate that Mr. Hassoun helped, at the least, with Mr. Padilla's travel plans.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: The seven taped phone calls that bear Mr. Padilla's voice involve conversations with Mr. Hassoun from 1997 to 2000.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: On those calls, Mr. Padilla, unlike some of the other defendants, does not employ what the government says is coded language.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: According to the government, other defendants refer to their jihad-related plans as ''getting some fresh air,'' ''participating in tourism,'' ''opening up a market,'' ''playing football,'' and so on.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: This leads to silly-sounding exchanges where ''the brothers'' discuss going on ''picnics'' in order ''to smell fresh air and to eat cheese'' or using $3,500 to buy ''zucchini.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In contrast, Mr. Padilla's seven conversations with Mr. Hassoun range from straightforward -- Mr. Hassoun tells Mr. Padilla that his grandmother has died; Mr. Padilla tells Mr. Hassoun that he has found himself an 18-year-old Egyptian bride who is willing to wear a veil -- to vaguely suggestive or just odd.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In one phone call, the two men talked about a dream.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: It appeared to be the dream that Mr. Padilla, according to his relatives, cites as having played a crucial role in inspiring him to convert to Islam: the vision of a man in a turban, surrounded by the swirling dust of a desert.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Hassoun brought it up and told Mr. Padilla that he himself had experienced the same vision.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''What do you mean you saw the same dream?''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Padilla asked.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''I saw the dream of the uh person with the turban,'' Mr. Hassoun said.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Hassoun explained how, in his dream, the turban was wrongly wrapped and so he thought the man might be a spy, in which case, he was prepared ''to split his body apart.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But then, he said, he understood that ''the brother was a good one.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''Yeah?''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Padilla said.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In three of the seven conversations, Mr. Padilla made statements that the government has identified as ''overt acts'' in furtherance of the accused conspiracy.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In the first, Mr. Hassoun asked, ''You're ready, right?''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: and Mr. Padilla said, ''God willing, brother, it's going to happen soon.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: That was the summer of 1997, a year before Mr. Padilla left South Florida for Egypt.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In the second, Mr. Padilla told Mr. Hassoun, during a 1999 conversation from Egypt, that he had asked his ex-wife in the United States to arrange for him to receive an army jacket, a book bag and a sleeping bag, supplies that he had requested because ''there was a rumor here that the door was open somewhere.''

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: In the third, Mr. Padilla told Mr. Hassoun in April 2000, that he would need a recommendation to ''connect me with the good brothers, with the right faith'' if he were to travel to Yemen.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Prosecutors say Mr. Padilla is mentioned, although by his Muslim name Ibrahim or by another alias, on 21 additional tapes.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But Mr. Padilla's lawyers contest that interpretation.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: ''That is just nonsensical, Your Honor, that these men who for years, according to the government, have been talking in code all of a sudden are going to throw Osama bin Laden's name around,'' Michael Caruso, a federal public defender, said in court.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Mr. Padilla has pleaded not guilty.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: But before his case goes before a jury, his fitness to stand trial will be evaluated.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: On the basis of Mr. Padilla's lawyers' assertion that he is mentally damaged as a result of his prolonged isolation and his interrogation in the brig, Judge Cooke has ordered a psychiatric evaluation by a Bureau of Prisons doctor to be completed this week.

column2: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
column3: Friday in The Times: The only person on the American mainland still held asan enemy combatant.

column3: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 29 (Xinhua) -- Massive protests led by Brazilian women of different political affiliations shook Brazil on Saturday, as hundreds of thousands people gathered to reject the leading presidential candidate Jair Bolsonaro.

column2: Baker Hughes acquires 5 percent of ADNOC Drilling for $550 million

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: TOKYO (Reuters) - Rising raw material costs and a string of natural disasters that disrupted production sapped business confidence among Japan’s big manufacturers in the September quarter, a central bank survey showed on Monday, taking it to the lowest in more than a year.

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: FILE PHOTO: Employees work an assembly line at a factory of Glory Ltd., a manufacturer of automatic change dispensers, in Kazo, north of Tokyo, Japan, July 1, 2015.

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: The survey gave little indication underlying sentiment had been hit by escalating global trade frictions.

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: But the specter of a fully-fledged trade war weighed on companies’ business outlook, which could threaten otherwise brisk capital expenditure, a bright spot in the world’s third largest economy.

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: The survey casts doubt on the Bank of Japan’s view that a solid economic expansion will help accelerate inflation to its elusive 2 percent target, although there were some signs that companies were gradually passing costs to their customers.

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: “Sentiment is leveling off due to slowing exports and weakening factory output amid worries of a global trade war,” said Takeshi Minami, chief economist at Norinchukin Research Institute.

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: “Still, the level of sentiment is high.

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: I don’t think it will keep deteriorating either, given improving profits and rising prices.”

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: The index for non-manufacturers fell to plus 22 from plus 24 in the June survey, matching a median market forecast and worsening for the first time in eight quarters.

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: Both big manufacturers and non-manufacturers expect business conditions to remain unchanged three months ahead, the survey showed.

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan
column3: Investors took the deterioration in the tankan business mood in their stride, pushing Japan's Nikkei share average .N225 to a 27-year high on Monday, as an extended weakening in yen helped improve export earnings prospects for Japanese corporations.

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan

column2: Natural disasters, trade woes sap Japan Inc's business confidence: tankan

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: by Xinhua writer Liu Chang

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: BEIJING, Jan. 21 (Xinhua) -- Washington loves to brand itself as a "shining city on the hill", yet the latest government shutdown in the heart of Western democracy has once again exposed its chronic flaws.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: The shutdown, the fourth in the past 25 years, is another product of the political battle between the Republicans and Democrats.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: What's so ironic is that it came on the first anniversary of Donald Trump's presidency on Saturday, a slap in the face for the leadership in Washington.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: With the election of Trump and the continued control of both houses of Congress by Republicans, the GOP seemed to have finally got revenge for eight years of a Democratic White House.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: Their most recent victory was the highly controversial tax reform package introducing tax cuts that critics claimed would make the rich richer.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: The Trump administration has backtracked on almost every notable policy Trump's predecessor Barack Obama had put in place, including the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal and the Paris climate accord.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: If there was any legacy that has survived the transfer of power, it was the spirit of noncooperation across party lines.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: The U.S. federal government was shut down when the Obama administration and the Republicans in Congress were locked in a battle on Obama's healthcare plan in 2013.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: Now that another lockdown is underway again, the two major political parties are as usual busy accusing each other of not doing their job.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: Thanks to their unrelenting rivalry, many of America's long-standing problems remain unresolved.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: Last year, gun crimes became more rampant,the wealth gap continued to widen, and the politics grew unprecedentedly polarized.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: The Western democratic system is hailed by the developed world as near perfect and the most superior political system to run a country.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: However, what's happening in the United States today will make more people worldwide reflect on the viability and legitimacy of such a chaotic political system.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua
column3: After all, for most people, the most important criterion for an effective political system is how it helps to resolve their problems, not telling them whom to blame.

column2: Commentary: Gov't shutdown exposes chronic flaw in U.S. political system - Xinhua

column3: SEOUL, Jan. 4 (Xinhua) -- South Korea's foreign reserves rose for 10 straight years through 2018, doubling the 2008 figure when the global financial crisis hit the economy, central bank data showed Friday.

column2: S.Korea's foreign reserves rise for 10 years to 2018 - Xinhua

column2: S.Korea's foreign reserves rise for 10 years to 2018 - Xinhua
column3: For the entire year of 2018, the foreign currency reserves grew 14.42 billion dollars, keeping an upward momentum for the 10th consecutive year.

column2: S.Korea's foreign reserves rise for 10 years to 2018 - Xinhua
column3: It more than doubled the 201.2 billion dollars tailed in 2008.

column2: S.Korea's foreign reserves rise for 10 years to 2018 - Xinhua
column3: As of end-December, the country's foreign reserves were composed of 379.6 billion dollars of securities, 3.35 billion dollars of deposits, 4.79 billion dollars of gold bullion, 3.43 billion dollars of special drawing rights and 2.14 billion dollars of IMF positions.

column2: S.Korea's foreign reserves rise for 10 years to 2018 - Xinhua
column3: South Korea was the world's eighth-largest holder of foreign reserves as of November.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: The new Democratic leaders of the Senate and the House warned President Bush on Friday against sending additional troops to Iraq, setting the stage for what could become a major confrontation over a new war strategy.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Mr. Bush is expected to call for more troops in a speech as soon as Wednesday, as part of a renewed effort to secure Baghdad.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: But Nancy Pelosi, the new speaker of the House, and Harry Reid, the new Senate majority leader, dismissed that approach as a strategy ''that has already failed.''

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: ''Adding more combat troops will only endanger more Americans and stretch our military to the breaking point for no strategic gain,'' Mrs. Pelosi and Mr. Reid wrote in a letter to Mr. Bush.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: ''We are well past the point of more troops for Iraq,'' they added, urging Mr. Bush to begin a ''phased redeployment,'' or gradual withdrawal.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Not all Democrats agree with the position their leaders staked out in the letter on Friday, just days before Mr. Bush is expected to announce a broad strategy involving more troops, accelerated training of Iraqi forces and a large increase in economic and reconstruction aid to Iraq.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: But the release of the letter suggests that a major political battle may be brewing.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: At a later meeting, Mr. Bush met with the former chairman of the Armed Services Committee, Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, who cautioned that Congress would want to take time to consider the strategy before Mr. Bush began implementing it.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: ''The president has had this opportunity now for some weeks, and I think Congress is entitled to an opportunity to independently look at the situation,'' Mr. Warner said.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Mr. Bush has begun to put parts of his plan in place, making official on Friday some changes that will insure new faces are associated with a new approach.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Mr. Bush praised General Casey, who spent much of 2006 pressing for a gradual withdrawal of troops, as ''strong and effective''; he hailed General Petraeus, who has reportedly backed an increase, as ''a soldier of vision and determination.''

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Mr. Bush is also remaking his diplomatic team, nominating John D. Negroponte, the director of national intelligence, to be deputy secretary of state.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Ryan C. Crocker is expected to be nominated ambassador to Iraq.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: His nomination would for the first time place an Arabist with experience in sectarian conflicts, mostly in Lebanon, at the head of the embassy in Baghdad.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: In theory, it could cut off financing, the only way it could actually interfere with the commander in chief's plans.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: But Democrats have said they would not take such a step, largely out of fear of being accused of undercutting the troops.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: That leaves them with only one option: holding a series of hearings, which start next week, immediately after the president's speech, that are intended to expose the divisions within the military over the wisdom of increasing troops.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Many senior officers, including General Casey, have argued that adding American troops will undercut the effort to get the Iraqi government to defend itself.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Some Republican leaders insisted that Congress should not go down that path.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: ''I don't think that we should be dictating military strategy in Iraq from Capitol Hill,'' said Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the Republican minority leader in the House.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: In addition to the 13 senators, Democrats and Republicans, invited to the White House on Friday afternoon, those attending the meeting included Vice President Dick Cheney, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, the Joint Chiefs chairman, Gen. Peter Pace, and Stephen J. Hadley, the national security adviser.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York and Barack Obama of Illinois, who both are considering a presidential candidacy, arrived at the White House at nearly the same time.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: After the meeting, Mrs. Clinton did not issue a statement, while Mr. Obama spoke to reporters about his conversation with Mr. Bush.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: ''I personally indicated that an escalation of troop levels in Iraq was a mistake and that we need a political accommodation, rather than a military approach to the sectarian violence there,'' he said.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: ''I think he recognizes that the status quo is unacceptable and has to change.''

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Senator Mary L. Landrieu, a Louisiana Democrat, said she would consider supporting an increase in troops for a short time if the president could articulate ''specific opportunities for success,'' particularly cities that troops would be dispatched to and how long they would stay.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: Ms. Landrieu also said she would need to be convinced that there was a broader solution to limit American involvement in Iraq.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: ''The American people's patience is wearing thin with the vagueness,'' she said, speaking to reporters as she left the White House.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: In interviews after the meeting, several senators said they could not tell whether Mr. Bush had made a decision whether to call for a troop increase.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
column3: The senators described the meeting as frank but not confrontational.

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq

column2: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: BEIJING, Dec. 31 (Xinhua) -- China's economy has defied doom-mongers again in 2018, and economists believe there are good reasons to remain confident about its outlook.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Although latest economic indicators revealed signs of stress, as industrial profits posted their first drop in three years and consumption growth missed expectations in November, merely focusing on short-term fluctuations will miss the big picture of the economy.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: China's tone-setting economic meeting described problems facing the economy as part of development, noting that the country is still and will be in an important period of strategic opportunity for development for a long time to come.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: SOUND FUNDAMENTALS

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Despite downward pressure from the Sino-U.S. trade frictions, a rebalancing and deleveraging domestic economy and monetary tightening in certain developed economies, China has maintained stable economic growth, offering certainties to a world mired in uncertainties.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Its GDP rose 6.7 percent in the first three quarters of 2018, putting the economy on track to meet the government's targeted growth of around 6.5 percent set for 2018.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Niu Li, an economist with the State Information Center, a government think tank, said the economy is highly likely to rise 6.6 percent this year.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: This means China remains a top performer in the global economic arena, with the IMF forecasting growth of 2.4 percent for advanced economies this year.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: The Sino-U.S. trade frictions have been properly dealt with.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Employment remains stable, consumer inflation is kept at a mild level, resident income continues to grow steadily, while development is more balanced and sustainable with higher quality.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Consumption is set to contribute 78.2 percent of China's economic growth this year, the highest level since 2001, according to a report released by the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences this month.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: "We expect consumption to remain the largest driver of the economy in the next decade," said Ding Shuang, an economist of the Standard Chartered Bank, citing great potential consumption to continue to grow faster than investment amid the ongoing trends of urbanization, aging and a rising middle-income group that demands quality goods and services.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: While consumer spending contributed a bigger share of GDP growth, technology and innovation are picking up the slack as certain traditional industries took a hit.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: High-tech manufacturing and equipment production sectors maintained fast expansion.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: In the Global Innovation Index 2018 by the World Intellectual Property Organization, China became the first middle-income economy on the list of the world's 20 most innovative economies this year.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: The medium-high level of growth achieved during the past year exhibited the vitality and resilience of the Chinese economy, which will ensure its future stability, said Liu Qiao, head of the Guanghua School of Management at Peking University.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: ENOUGH AMMUNITION

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Another reason for the optimism is that the Chinese policymakers have many economic levers at hand to deal with challenges, analysts said.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: The government's options include supply-side structural reform, credit policy, and fiscal firepower.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: On the monetary policy front, economists said broad-based easing is not immediately on the cards, but the central bank may tweak policies to keep funding flowing to the backbone of the economy without funneling credit to companies that are already highly indebted.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: The Standard Chartered Bank said the People's Bank of China might cut the reserve requirement ratio by 200 basis points by the end of 2019 to prevent a tightening of monetary and credit conditions and reduce funding costs for the real economy by providing banks with long-term liquidity at a relatively low cost.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: China's stable economic growth enables a more proactive fiscal policy through deeper tax and fee cuts as well as accelerating government spending.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: UBS economist Wang Tao expected the fiscal budget deficit to rise to 3 percent of GDP in 2019 from 2.6 percent in 2018, and tax cuts to exceed one percent of GDP, mainly in value-added tax, corporate income tax, and individual income tax, together with a reduction in corporate social insurance contribution.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: To boost government spending, the country's legislature has adopted a decision to speed up local government bond issuance before the approval of the annual fiscal budget.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Between Jan. 1, 2019 and Dec. 31, 2022, the State Council will be authorized to assign part of the newly-added quotas for local government bonds each year before the annual budget approval.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Yang Weimin, deputy director of the economic committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference National Committee, said the country should also further supply-side structural reform to fix the mismatch in resource allocation to enhance economic resilience.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Previous structural adjustments should be reinforced, with continued efforts to downsize glutted industries, reduce all types of business burdens and channel more energy into weak areas including infrastructure, according to the annual Central Economic Work Conference.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: FASTER REFORM, WIDER OPENING-UP

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: This year marked the 40th anniversary of its reform and opening-up, which China commemorated with concrete moves to overhaul and reform its economy.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: The country has broadened market access, reduced import duties, built new ground in opening up and provided new platforms for win-win cooperation with the rest of the world.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Foreign ownership restrictions in the financial and auto sectors have been eased, with some ownership caps to be removed completely in the coming three years; tariffs were cut for an array of imported products including cars, consumer products, and industrial goods; and more import duty cuts will come into effect next year.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: Reform and opening-up has gained pace.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: In its latest step, China announced on Dec. 25 a negative list for market access that is shorter and applies to all market players, allowing them to equally enter sectors that are not on the list.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: The government will continue to widen market access for foreign investors while the negative list is expected to be further shortened in 2019, said Tang Wenhong, head of foreign investment management department under the Ministry of Commerce.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: In the coming year, the country also vowed to push forward with reforms in various fields including state-owned enterprises, taxation and financing, land, market access as well as social management.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: To promote foreign trade, China will expand exports and imports and promote the diversification of export markets.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: It will continue to advance the Belt and Road Initiative, actively participate in WTO reforms, and promote trade and investment liberalization and facilitation, according to CICC economist Liu Liu.

column2: Yearender-Economic Watch: Reasons to stay upbeat about the Chinese economy - Xinhua
column3: The past four decades have seen China's metamorphosis from an impoverished backwater into a major contributor to the world's economy, and analysts expected the fresh push to unleash a new wave of development dividends.

column2: Indonesia's inflation edges off in 2018 - Xinhua

column2: Indonesia's inflation edges off in 2018 - Xinhua

column2: Indonesia's inflation edges off in 2018 - Xinhua

column2: Indonesia's inflation edges off in 2018 - Xinhua

column3: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 10 (Xinhua) -- The Swedish elections have ended in a nearly deadlock between the left and right political blocs, leaving the nationalist Sweden Democrats in a kingmaker position, preliminary votes counting showed on Monday.

column3: REUTERS/Jason Miczek

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: By Jon Herskovitz

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: (Reuters) - Global warming has increased the likelihood of more massive, sluggish storms like Florence, capable of dropping record amounts of rain and causing the type of catastrophic flooding that crippled North and South Carolina this week, experts said.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: Most meteorologists agree that climate change can increase the volume of water vapor stored within weather systems.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: More water vapor means more rain, especially when the storm is a crawler like Florence, which slowed to about 2 miles per hour (3.2 km per hour) after slamming into the North Carolina coast.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: When storms such as Harvey, which struck Texas last year, and Florence come to a virtual stall, a deluge of rain can fall in the matter of days, equal to what an area typically sees in a year, they said.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: “It is compelling and sobering to see these storms come in back-to-back seasons,” said Jim Kossin, an atmospheric research scientist with the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: His research suggests that global warming has affected the speed of storms as well as the amount of moisture they contain.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: Florence, which has killed at least 36 people, dumped up to 36 inches (91 cm) of rain in parts of North Carolina since Thursday.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: At least 16 rivers remained at a major flood stage, with three others set to crest in the coming days in North Carolina, the state said.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: It has been a little more than a year since Hurricane Harvey dumped trillions of gallons of water on Texas and the U.S. Gulf Coast, killing 68 people and causing an estimated $125 billion in property damage.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: Based on data from about seven decades of storms, Kossin found tropical-cyclone speed had decreased globally by 10 percent from 1949 to 2016, according to a paper published in June in the scientific journal Nature.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: The reason is that climate change is warming the Arctic much more than it is heating up the Tropics, easing the pressure difference between the two, he said in an interview on Wednesday.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: Pressure differences drive the winds, which in turn can steer and slow down storms, he said.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: In the case of Florence, warmer sea temperatures and the amount of available moisture in the air may have increased rainfall by as much as 50 percent in the hardest-hit areas, according to a study by researchers at Stony Brook University, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and the National Center for Atmospheric Research.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: To make matters worse, Florence was about 50 miles (80 km) larger in diameter due to global warming, putting more people in harm’s way, the study showed.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: “We can attribute that additional rainfall to human-induced climate change,” said Kevin Reed, a professor at Stony Brook University’s School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences, who contributed to the study.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: The paper, still unpublished, may fuel an ongoing debate in the scientific community about whether climate change, induced by human activity, has a direct impact on the strength and size of a storm.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: Global warming has greatly increased the chances of another storm of Harvey’s magnitude hitting Texas again, according to a published study by Massachusetts Institute of Technology Professor Kerry Emanuel.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: The likelihood of more massive rainfalls also should raise red flags for both coastal and inland communities and get them to rethink plans for storm-related inundation, experts said.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: This includes planning for massive evacuations and making improvements to infrastructure related to water-flow resources to help ease the blow.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
