column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: “There is going to be both more inland flooding and more storm-surge, ocean-related flooding because the ocean is getting higher,” said Brion Callori, senior vice president of engineering and research at commercial property insurance firm FM Global.

column2: Florence portends more massive hurricanes in age of global warming
column3: “The biggest risk is burying your head in the sand and not understanding your exposure,” he said.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: At the halfway mark between the onslaught of Hurricane Katrina last year and the beginning of the 2006 hurricane season on June 1, the Army Corps of Engineers has completed only 16 percent of its planned repairs to New Orleans's battered flood protection system, according to corps representatives.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The corps says its work is on track for restoring the system to its pre-hurricane strength by the June 1 deadline, but in the meantime many groups that have studied the disaster are coming up with proposals of their own that they say could be cheaper, faster or stronger.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The Bring New Orleans Back Commission, the group formed by Mayor C. Ray Nagin to produce a blueprint for the city's recovery, issued a proposal on Wednesday to upgrade hurricane protection with measures beyond what the corps has called for.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: To prevent storm surges from pushing into the city's drainage canals, the commission proposed a series of jetties to stand in front of the three canals, which it says could be built quickly and cheaply and provide New Orleans with some much-needed peace of mind.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: ''There is, very much, a tension between things that can be done quickly versus those that might take a little longer,'' Lawrence Roth, deputy executive director of the American Society of Civil Engineers, said in a telephone interview on Friday.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: His group has weighed in with far-reaching recommendations, and other groups are preparing proposals of their own.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The mayor's commission also proposed a network of dams that would block or slow the opening between the Inner Harbor Navigational Canal and Lake Pontchartrain, and block storm surges from flowing up the Mississippi River Gulf Outlet, a navigation channel that has been blamed for a storm surge funnel effect that increased the damage to eastern New Orleans.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The group is also calling for long-term flood-control structures that would block or slow surges at the two passes between Lake Pontchartrain and the Gulf of Mexico.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The fast-track structures would cost $100 million to $170 million, according to the commission's estimates, a fraction of the $3.1 billion the federal government has proposed spending on flood control measures in the area.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The commission said its proposals would not interfere with any of the corps's plans, but would be add-ons that complement the current plans.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The proposals have not yet found broad support among other engineering experts who have been working on strengthening New Orleans's storm defenses, but Dan Hitchings, the director of the corps's Task Force Hope, which is coordinating the hurricane response in Louisiana and Mississippi, said the plans were welcome and would be examined.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: Mr. Roth, of the Society of Civil Engineers, said there would always be competing ideas about how to improve flood protection.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The idea of jetties, he said, might be made moot by closing off the canals and putting in new pumping stations at the lake, as the corps has planned.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: ''Many different people can look at a problem and come up with many different solutions, all with tradeoffs,'' he said.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: ''Which would be better -- jetties or a pump station?

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: You might never get an answer to that.''

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: Meanwhile, the corps's work to restore flood protection to its pre-hurricane levels continues around the clock.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: This month the corps solicited bids for building temporary closures and pumps at the mouths of the city's three drainage canals, and it is rebuilding long stretches of levee in St. Bernard Parish and along the Inner Harbor Navigational Canal.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The corps is looking to measures that will further strengthen the flood protection system, including restoring levees to their originally designed heights.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: These measures can be in place by September 2007, according to the corps.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: Beyond that, the corps has embarked on a two-year, $8 million study to determine how to strengthen the hurricane protection system for New Orleans and southern Louisiana.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: A preliminary version of that report is due in June.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: While the Bush administration's top official on Gulf Coast reconstruction, Donald Powell, has said the government will build a system that is ''better and stronger'' than what was there before, the administration has not committed to what the people of New Orleans desperately want: protection from Category 5 storms, the toughest that nature can dish out.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: Mr. Hitchings said that the corps was slightly behind schedule but that he expected things to move quickly.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: ''It's not linear,'' he said, because the ''gear-up time'' to get contractors in place and to make materials like the enormous quantities of soil available was so great.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: Now ''they're really moving out,'' he said.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The corps built 30 days of weather delays into the schedule, he said, and with a little help from favorable weather, ''I'm very optimistic that they will regain their schedule and in the end get it all finished with plenty of time.''

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The corps's long-term study, he said, would probably have a lot in common with the outside proposals that are beginning to flow in, but ''right now, we're focused on the very near term.''

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The engineering society is investigating the failure of the levees and is working with the groups that will monitor the corps's progress.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: Its recommendations include ''armoring'' the dry side of levees so they are not eroded away from underneath if water spills over the top.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: Without armoring, Mr. Roth said, ''failure is catastrophic because it causes the wall to fail.''

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: The corps has said that the armoring process, like other projects that would go beyond the restoration of the levees to pre-hurricane strength, will have to be approved by Congress.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: ''It's going to take people being willing to take a chance, to be bold, to sort out Louisiana's levee problems,'' said Ivor van Heerden, deputy director of the Louisiana State University Hurricane Center and a member of Team Louisiana, the group formed by the state to investigate the causes of the levee failures.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: His group, too, will be making proposals for upgrading protection for the region.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: ''We may get lucky,'' he said.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: ''Nature may give us another 10 years before we get another Katrina, or maybe not.

column2: Competing Plans to Repair New Orleans Flood Protection
column3: But we've got to seize the moment or we're going to lose coastal Louisiana.''

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (Xinhua) -- U.S. economic growth is expected to slow down in 2019 due to factors including the diminishing effect of fiscal stimulus, further tightening of financial conditions, rising market volatility and trade uncertainty, experts have said.

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: With annualized growth rates of 2.2 percent, 4.2 percent and 3.4 percent for the first three quarters of 2018 respectively and a 2 percent range expected for the fourth quarter, the Federal Reserve estimated that the U.S. economy would wrap up the year with a 3 percent expansion, much higher than the average 2.2 percent annual rate between 2010 and 2017.

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: However, economists warned that the boom is by and large led by the U.S. government's tax cuts and spending increases, and that there are signs that the dividends of those measures are diminishing while the Fed's monetary tightening will weigh more on U.S. growth.

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: "Fiscal boost becoming a fiscal drag and more tightening in financial conditions are going to mean that the growth is going to decelerate," Jeremie Cohen-Setton, research fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, a Washington think tank, told Xinhua in a recent interview.

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: He expected the U.S. economy to expand at around 2.5 percent in 2019.

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: "The slack is diminishing, therefore you're going to have more wage pressures," he said, adding the Fed would continue tightening monetary policy as U.S. inflation "is going to overshoot the target (of 2 percent) a little bit."

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: The Fed raised interest rates for four times in 2018, and most Fed officials envisioned two rate hikes in 2019.

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: "It is more likely that the economy will grow in a way that will call for two interest rate increases over the course of next year," Fed Chairman Jerome Powell told a press conference on Dec. 19.

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: The Fed anticipated that U.S. economic growth would decelerate to 2.3 percent in 2019.

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: Concerns about a loss of growth momentum in Asia and Europe would also likely weigh on U.S. growth.

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua
column3: "For the rest of the world there seems to be some air coming out of the balloon.

column2: Spotlight: Slowdown in sight for U.S. economy in 2019 as uncertainty intensifies: experts - Xinhua

column3: BEIJING, Jan. 2 (Xinhua) -- China's central bank decided Wednesday to ease evaluation rules for qualifying financial institutions to enjoy lower reserve requirement ratios (RRR) in a move to encourage inclusive financing.

column2: China's central bank adjusts targeted RRR policies to support small firms - Xinhua
column3: Financial institutions can deposit less in the central bank as reserve money if they lend a certain share of their loans to small and micro firms each borrowing less than ten million yuan (1.46 million U.S. dollars) from them, the People's Bank of China said in a statement.

column2: China's central bank adjusts targeted RRR policies to support small firms - Xinhua
column3: The evaluation threshold for inclusive financing is lifted from five million yuan, and the new policy takes effect immediately.

column2: China's central bank adjusts targeted RRR policies to support small firms - Xinhua
column3: The move will help the preferentially targeted RRR cut cover more financial institutions, encouraging them to serve more small and micro firms which are usually in high demand of credit.

column2: China's central bank adjusts targeted RRR policies to support small firms - Xinhua
column3: The State Council said late last December that China will improve its policies for targeted reserve requirement ratio cuts to encourage inclusive financing.

column3: In a rare reprise to a rare trial, the jury that convicted a Long Island man of murder by depraved indifference last October in a drunken-driving crash that killed a limousine driver and a 7-year-old girl may be brought back to court for hearings on whether some members acted improperly during deliberations.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: In an answer submitted on Dec. 29 to a defense motion, Robert Hayden, an assistant Nassau County district attorney, agreed that a hearing should be held to determine if jurors discussed what they believed were prior drunken-driving charges against the defendant, Martin Heidgen, 25.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Such accusations were not included in the evidence introduced in the five-week trial, and could be considered a contamination of the jury proceedings.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Beyond that, Mr. Hayden said in his answer, that the belief of a previous drunken-driving arrest was ''not true,'' as far as he knew.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Mr. Hayden said the hearing should be limited to that issue, and rebuffed as ''irrelevant'' several other claims of impropriety raised by Mr. Heidgen's lawyer, Stephen LaMagna, as causes for setting aside the guilty verdict.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Mr. LaMagna also claimed that some jurors felt pressured to vote to convict Mr. Heidgen of the most serious charge, that some discussed the case outside the jury room, and that one said she planned to write a book about it.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: The Heidgen case was unusual because the defendant was prosecuted for a fatal drunken-driving crash under laws treating his crime as the functional equivalent of intentional murder.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Such prosecutions, while not unprecedented, are considered rare and are usually brought only in the most horrific cases.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Mr. Heidgen, whose blood-alcohol level was three times the legal limit, was driving the wrong way on the Meadowbrook Parkway when his pickup truck crashed head-on with a limousine taking a family home from a wedding.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: The crash killed the limousine driver, Stanley Rabinowitz, 59, and Katie Flynn, who had been the flower girl.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: The girl's parents and grandparents, who were also in the limousine, suffered minor injuries.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: After three days of deliberations, the jury told Acting Justice Alan R. Honorof of State Supreme Court that it was deadlocked, but after he sent them back for more deliberations, reached a verdict on the fifth day.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Within days of the verdict, though, the jury forewoman said she had felt pressured to vote for the charge of ''murder by depraved indifference'' that Mr. Heidgen was convicted of, even though she believed he was guilty of the lesser crime of manslaughter.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Based on the depraved indifference conviction, Mr. Heidgen faces a minimum of 25 years in prison.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Manslaughter carries a minimum of 15 years.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Mr. Heidgen's lawyer, who could not be reached for comment on Wednesday, has said that based on interviews with other jury members, he believed that some jurors browbeat the last two holdouts who thought Mr. Heidgen was guilty of manslaughter, rather than murder.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: ''It is fairly rare for hearings like these to be held,'' said George Goltzer, vice president of the New York State Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: ''The general rule is that you don't let a jury impeach its own verdict.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: But if the charges are serious -- say that racism or serious misconduct was involved in the decision or something like that -- the courts have allowed it.''

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
column3: Mr. Goltzer said he was not too familiar with the case, but added that evidence of ''extra-record information'' -- not part of the evidence introduced at the trial -- might qualify as serious enough to review a jury's verdict.

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict

column2: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: FOR investors who have been missing out on the prolonged run-up in the shares of real estate investment trusts, or maybe jumped in only recently, the end may not be in sight: there are growing opportunities overseas.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: Some industry experts say that this is an opportune time to make a move into these nascent markets.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: ''We don't think the U.S. REIT market is played out; it will continue its upward growth,'' said Steven Carroll, co-chief investment officer at CB Richard Ellis Global Real Estate Securities.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: ''But we think the growth will escalate at a much more rapid pace overseas as more markets become securitized.''

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: Last week, Britain became the latest country to offer REITs.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: The corporate structure gives real estate companies favorable tax treatment in exchange for disbursing most of their income to shareholders.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: The addition of Britain brings to 17 the number of countries with public REIT markets, according to UBS Investment Bank; there are also about a dozen other countries with legislation in place or under consideration to create REITs, though with no public market yet.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: Germany is expected to offer REITs this spring.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: In 1994, only three countries outside the United States allowed REITs, according to UBS.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: While the United States is still the world's dominant REIT market, with around $395 billion in market capitalization out of an estimated worldwide total of $608 billion, last year's spate of announced mergers and acquisitions is steadily reducing the number of publicly traded shares.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: A recent report by Ernst & Young suggests that the rest of the globe is poised to surpass the United States by 2008 in terms of total capitalization.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: Much of the new growth, it says, is being driven by REIT markets in Australia, France, Japan, Canada, the Netherlands, Singapore and Hong Kong.

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
column3: ''You can really play the real estate market more effectively now.''

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market

column2: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Mr. Caruso, a 70-year-old grandfather in fragile health, will begin by bowing his head at the final resting place of his brother Joey, who died in childhood from the ravages of diphtheria.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Then he will stop at the partly submerged burial vault of Dr. Casper Pendola, the young physician who attended to the boy in his final, feverish hours.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: At the visit, Mr. Caruso will grapple with how these two departed souls, whose paths crossed by chance, ended up linked forever in a saga of anger and murder.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The case turned the state against an individual, the medical establishment against the immigrant community, and family against family, while plunging Mr. Caruso into torment for most of his adult life.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Eighty years ago next month -- on Feb. 13, 1927 -- Joey Caruso, age 6, died in a tenement apartment in the broad swath of New York then known simply as South Brooklyn.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: That same day, 27-year-old Dr. Pendola, who like Joey was of Sicilian heritage, died in the same apartment.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The child succumbed to disease.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The doctor was the victim of cold-blooded murder.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: And the man who killed him, first by strangling him, then by slashing his throat so severely that his head was nearly severed from his body, was Francesco Caruso, Joey's father.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Sensational by any standards, the slaying set off a maelstrom of news media frenzy, ethnic hatred, ethical and legal debate, and volatile emotion that would keep New York and much of the rest of the nation in thrall for months.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The case became a cause célèbre, a campaign for justice for Italian immigrants that drew in Fiorello La Guardia, Clarence Darrow and other boldface names of the day.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: But however broad the issue became, at its core were a child's death and a father's grief and rage.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: A Laugh, or a Twitch?

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: According to court testimony and other documents, this is how events of that terrible night unfolded.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Francesco Caruso, a beefy, 35-year-old Sicilian immigrant and laborer known as Cheech, lived at 36 Third Street, near Smith Street, with his wife and six children.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: On Feb. 11, his son Joey developed a bad sore throat.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The father tried to treat him with over-the-counter remedies.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: But the next night, the boy took a turn for the worse.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: With no phone in the apartment, the father ran to a local drugstore, owned by one Joseph Pendola, and the pharmacist telephoned his brother, a physician who lived in Maspeth, Queens.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Arriving around 10:45 that night, Dr. Pendola examined Joey, who lay feverish on a cot in the kitchen, and diagnosed his condition as diphtheria, a bacterial disease that ravages the upper respiratory system.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The doctor wrote prescriptions for 10,000 units of antitoxin, to be injected, and a second medication, to be given orally.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The father filled both prescriptions at the Pendola pharmacy, then returned to the apartment, where Dr. Pendola injected the antitoxin.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Leaving the father to administer the oral medication, the doctor departed, promising to return the next morning.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: During the night, however, Joey grew sicker and eventually became delirious.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: According to testimony his father gave in court, at one point the boy stood up in bed and announced, ''Papa, I am dying.''

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: By 10 the next morning, the doctor had not returned.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Mr. Caruso raced back to the pharmacy and called for an ambulance.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: He returned home to find that his son had gone into convulsions.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The boy died in his arms.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Not until noon did Dr. Pendola reappear at the apartment.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: It was the events that followed that led to the bloodletting.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: According to Mr. Caruso's testimony in court, upon being informed of the child's death, the doctor simply laughed, although the New York Court of Appeals would later characterize the doctor's reaction as ''some twitching of the facial muscles that might be mistaken for a smile.''

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Whatever actually occurred, the enraged father wrapped his powerful hands around Dr. Pendola's throat and began strangling him.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: When the doctor fell, Mr. Caruso pulled a butcher knife from a closet and stabbed him twice, fatally, in the throat.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: By nightfall, Mr. Caruso was in police custody, charged with first-degree murder.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Newspaper articles describing the crime were predictably sensational.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: ''Physician Is Slain by Crazed Father as Boy Patient Dies,'' blared the headline in The New York Times.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: ''Crazed Father Flees Bier; Confesses After Capture,'' shouted The Daily News.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Taking note of Mr. Caruso's Sicilian heritage and lack of formal education, the articles variously described the defendant as ''dull-eyed and expressionless,'' an ''ignorant father'' given to speaking ''broken English,'' and ''a raging giant whose black eyes were afire with hate and revenge.''

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Deliberations, and Death Row

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The trial, before Judge Alonzo McLaughlin in Kings County Court, then at Joralemon Street and Boerum Place in Downtown Brooklyn, had moments of high drama.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Jury selection, which began April 4, proved to be a complicated affair and took two days.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: When a brief postponement was granted, the doctor's distraught widow, Helen, stood up in the gallery and shouted: ''This man murdered my husband, and it was a cruel, cold murder!

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: He should be killed.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Instead, he gets an adjournment.''

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Once the testimony got under way, the defendant's own words were chilling.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: ''I said he had killed my boy and I was going to kill him,'' Mr. Caruso said of the doctor.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: ''Soon he didn't breathe anymore, and I ran to the kitchen, got a carving knife and stabbed him in the throat.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: My wife stood in the doorway and saw it all.''

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Ultimately, the jury rejected the defense's argument that Mr. Caruso was suffering from temporary insanity and concluded that his actions had been deliberate and premeditated.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: On April 7, Mr. Caruso was convicted of first-degree murder, which carried an automatic death sentence.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: As the judge congratulated the Caruso jurors, noting that ''any other finding would have been a miscarriage of justice,'' the defendant was packed off to death row at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Star-Studded Counsel

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Then the tide turned.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: A campaign to spare Mr. Caruso's life picked up momentum among Italian-American friendship societies.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: An ambitious New York congressman named Fiorello La Guardia visited the Caruso family.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: A defense committee was organized by a press agent named Alexander Marky, and thanks to him, Mr. Caruso's wife and daughter were able to make appeals for mercy over the radio.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The defense committee recruited renowned lawyers to its cause, including Walter Pollak, who would later help defend the young African-Americans sentenced to death in the notorious Scottsboro Boys case.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The committee's most prominent member was Clarence Darrow, the legendary defender of evolution in the Scopes ''monkey trial,'' who came out of retirement to help draft Mr. Caruso's appeal.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: On Nov. 22, alleging 14 trial errors and citing more than 100 other cases, this star-studded legal team persuaded the Court of Appeals to void Mr. Caruso's conviction for first-degree murder and order a new trial.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The court's chief judge was Benjamin Cardozo, who would go on to join the United States Supreme Court.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: At the Caruso home, the defendant's family celebrated the good news with a fat Thanksgiving turkey.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: At the Pendola home, the doctor's widow rocked her baby daughter, Catherine, and wept.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: ''We have nothing to be thankful for,'' she told reporters.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: ''My baby and I are alone.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: And the man who killed my husband, my baby's father, is alive and may go free.''

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Mr. Caruso's new trial began two months later, and this time around, matters took some curious turns.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: A jury was impaneled in a brisk two hours; the very next day, Jan. 31, 1928, Judge McLaughlin, who had presided at the first trial and sentenced Mr. Caruso to death a scant nine months earlier, halted the proceedings to allow Mr. Caruso to plead guilty to first-degree manslaughter.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The prosecutor, on record as saying Mr. Caruso should face the first-degree murder charge again in the second trial, also did a turnabout, agreeing to the manslaughter plea.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The judge then sentenced the defendant to serve a maximum of 20 years.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: In the end, Mr. Caruso served only six years.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Returning to his family, he fathered another son, Dom, and lived the rest of his life in relative obscurity, working as a laborer, a house painter and a caretaker.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: He died in 1968, at age 77.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: After the Anguish

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: For decades, Dom Caruso had a troubled relationship with his father, who, in the son's eyes, despised him because he could never replace his beloved brother.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: As Dom remembered it, his mother once told him that his father had tried to have the midwife write the name ''Joey'' on his birth certificate when he was born, but the mother had vehemently rejected the idea.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: One morning in 1952, when Dom was 16, his father sat him down at the breakfast table of their Jericho, Long Island, home and, already drunk on red wine, as was his custom, began to tell an extraordinary story.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: According to Dom, his father said that Dr. Pendola was not the first man he had murdered.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The father, a strapping man of 230 pounds, said that he was a longtime ''made man'' in the Sicilian Mafia, and that, through beatings, knifings and shootings, he had served as an enforcer for Salvatore D'Aquila, an Al Capone associate and the capo di tutti capi of the New York Mafia.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: So, Dom Caruso recounted, when Cheech Caruso found himself facing the electric chair, he was not abandoned.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Al Capone and Salvatore D'Aquila helped to set up a defense fund, hire top-flight lawyers to work on Mr. Caruso's appeal, and orchestrate the abrupt denouement of the second murder trial by pressuring Gov.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Alfred E. Smith or one of his top lieutenants.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The governor, who would run for president that year, enjoyed huge support from Italian-Americans.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: The father's tale is almost impossible to substantiate.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: On the one hand, Dom Caruso has no physical evidence of the father's statements about the Mafia and the trial.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Moreover, Dom's own family has been at least partly skeptical of the tale; for example, his siblings hotly disputed Dom's claim, based on his talk with his father, that their brother Sal had been named after Salvatore D'Aquila.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: As for the involvement of Smith's administration, the best evidence is very unspecific.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Thomas Reppetto, author of ''American Mafia: A History of Its Rise to Power,'' said that the governor was undeniably under the sway of powerful party bosses, particularly those in Tammany Hall, who would not have hesitated to seek a favor from the Mafia.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: But, Mr. Reppetto also said, he knew of no proof that Al Smith had ever done favors for the Mafia.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: On the other hand, there are some facts that lend weight to the father's story.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: On the day after Mr. Caruso's arraignment, for instance, The New York Times noted that in 1918 Francesco Caruso had been arrested by the police and fined $100 for carrying a concealed pistol, not a fix encountered by a regular laborer.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Then there are the turnabouts of the judge and prosecutor at the second trial, and the question of how the costly appeals effort on Mr. Caruso's behalf was financed, even if it was a cause célèbre.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Whatever the truth may be, it is difficult to know exactly what relatives of the victim may have felt about this claim or about the case in general.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Attempts to reach direct descendants of Dr. Pendola -- through death, Social Security and newspaper records and through St. John's Cemetery -- were unsuccessful.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Among relatives who could be located and did agree to speak was Michael Criss, whose great-grandfather Pietro Pendola was Dr. Pendola's cousin.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Mr. Criss, who teaches at Oklahoma State University and is the unofficial historian of the Pendola family in the United States, said he had first heard about the murder from cousins who were small children when it occurred.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: ''I think what Caruso did was heinous,'' Mr. Criss said, ''even if you take into consideration his emotional state.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: However, I see no reason to blame his family and descendants for his actions.''

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: When one of those descendants, Dom Caruso, visits St. John's Cemetery, the first member of his family ever to do so, he will find two graves about a 10-minute walk from each other.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: They are remarkable for their unremarkableness.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Joey's final resting place is an unmarked charity grave, which was paid for by the Roman Catholic Church's Society of St. Vincent de Paul.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Dr. Pendola is buried in a marble family vault shaded by pine trees.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: There is the surname Pendola, but there is no visible monument bearing birth or death dates, and no first name.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: There are no words of solace or affection, no religious symbols or biblical inscriptions, no mention of the fact that the deceased was a husband, a father and a practitioner of the healing arts.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: For Dom Caruso, whose profound sadness over what happened that wintry night in 1927 extends to the Pendola family as well as his own, the primary concern remains how the outcome of the case must have affected the doctor's widow and daughter, even though he was never able to ascertain their fate.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: ''I doubt that poor Helen found any peace in her lifetime,'' Mr. Caruso said of the doctor's widow, who, according to Mr. Criss, died three decades ago.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: ''I hope and pray that Catherine did.

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: I'd like to believe that.''

column2: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
column3: Neal Hirschfeld is the author, with Kathy Burke, of ''Detective: The Inspirational Story of the Trailblazing Woman Cop Who Wouldn't Quit.''

column2: 21 Portuguese women killed in domestic violence in 2018 - Xinhua
column3: LISBON, Sept. 13 (Xinhua) -- At least 21 women have been killed in Portugal since the beginning of 2018 in cases of domestic violence or violence in intimate relationships, more than the number of the whole of last year, according to the country's Observatory of Murdered Women on Thursday.

column2: 21 Portuguese women killed in domestic violence in 2018 - Xinhua
column3: Twenty-one women had been killed by their former or current partners or by their close family members by Sept. 12, the Union of Women for Alternatives and Answers (UMAR) said, citing figures gathered by its Observatory of Murdered Women.

column2: 21 Portuguese women killed in domestic violence in 2018 - Xinhua
column3: Contrary to what has happened with the murder, in which there has been a decreasing trend, the numbers of femicide have remained constant, Elisabete Brasil, head of UMAR was quoted by Portuguese Lusa News Agency as saying.

column2: 21 Portuguese women killed in domestic violence in 2018 - Xinhua
column3: "It's still too early to talk about the total number, but we have already confirmed 21 women and this is brutal considering we are in September and we already have the same level of deaths from last year," she said.

column2: 21 Portuguese women killed in domestic violence in 2018 - Xinhua
column3: Figures from last year's report of UMAR revealed that at least 20 women were killed in the cases of domestic violence.

column2: 21 Portuguese women killed in domestic violence in 2018 - Xinhua
column3: Brasil said that levels of violence and the suffering inflicted on victims had also increased.

column2: 21 Portuguese women killed in domestic violence in 2018 - Xinhua
column3: She blamed the political figures and the general public for what she described as "silence" on the deaths caused by domestic violence.

column2: Mexican police arrest suspect in murder of journalist - Xinhua

column2: Mexican police arrest suspect in murder of journalist - Xinhua

column2: Mexican police arrest suspect in murder of journalist - Xinhua

column2: Mexican police arrest suspect in murder of journalist - Xinhua

column2: Mexican police arrest suspect in murder of journalist - Xinhua

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: MANILA, Aug. 12 (Xinhua) -- Days of torrents of rainfall and flooding battered a widespread area in the Philippines, displacing nearly 383,000 people, a disaster agency said on Sunday.

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: Based on the latest reports, a total of 88,000 families or 383,000 people from different places on the Philippine main Luzon Island were displaced due to the large-scale rainfall and flooding.

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: The Metro Manila and nearby Rizal province are the most affected places by the flooding.

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: And in the two areas, the National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC) said, about 40,000 people have been evacuated to safer grounds to avoid rising waters.

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: A major river in Marikina, a city in Metro Manila, swelled on Saturday night, forcing the local government to evacuate 3,783 families or 17,676 people living near the riverbanks to 19 government temporary shelters.

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: NDRRMC spokesman Edgar Posadas said no flood-related death has been reported as of Sunday.

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: Heavy rains continue to dump water in Luzon and some parts of the central Philippines this week.

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: State weather bureau predicted that another tropical storm will continue to enhance the southwest monsoon that could bring "scattered to widespread rains across the western section of Luzon until Monday."

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: The NDRRMC raised the alert status to red at 8:00 a.m. Sunday as the agency closely monitor the relief efforts and assistance to affected communities.

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: The NDRRMC said more than 105 million pesos (about 1.97 million U.S. dollars) worth of assistance has been provided to the affected residents.

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: "With the continuous rains expected to be experienced until Monday, residents in flood-prone and low-lying areas are advised to heed the call of their local government units regarding pre-emptive evacuation," the NDRRMC said in a statement.

column2: Flooding displaces 383,000 in Philippines - Xinhua
column3: The agency urged the public "to take necessary precautions" and to be vigilant.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: MUTUAL fund managers are unfairly blamed for poor performance of their funds.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The track record of the average manager doesn't lag that of a simple buy-and-hold strategy because the manager is an awful stock picker.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: Instead, the underperformance results from unprofitable transactions that are forced by the buy-and-sell decisions of shareholders.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: This defense of the average fund manager comes from a new study called ''Does Motivation Matter When Assessing Trade Performance?

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: An Analysis of Mutual Funds.''

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The authors of the study, which has been circulating as an academic working paper, are three finance professors: Gordon J. Alexander of the University of Minnesota and Scott Gibson and Gjergji Cici, both at the Mason Business School of the College of William and Mary.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: A version is at papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract-id=641743.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The professors' research builds on fund managers' motivations to buy or sell a stock.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The most obvious, of course, is that they believe that the stock they're buying will climb and that the stock they're selling will fall.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: But only some trades purely reflect such convictions.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: When investors are pouring money into the fund or selling in droves, managers have to buy or sell stocks that they would not have traded otherwise.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The study used a new method for segregating fund trades according to these different motivations, allowing the professors to measure managers' pure stock-picking abilities as well as the effects of fund inflows and outflows on fund performance.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The key to the approach was measuring how much money was being invested in a fund, or withdrawn from it, at the time of each transaction.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: Consider a large purchase that a fund manager made during a period when investors were, on balance, withdrawing a lot of money from the fund.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The professors assumed that because the manager didn't have to buy the stock in order to invest a large inflow of cash, he must have believed that it would be an above-average performer -- a ''valuation-motivated buy,'' in the professors' parlance.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: Similarly, a ''valuation-motivated sell'' would be a big sale that occurred when there was a large net inflow of cash into a fund.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The professors built two hypothetical portfolios, one for the valuation-motivated buys and the other for the valuation-motivated sells.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The portfolios changed composition every quarter.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: From January 1980 through December 2003, the professors found, the first portfolio performed 2.8 percentage points a year better than the stock market as a whole, on average, while the second trailed the market by an average of 0.7 percentage point a year.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The study says this means that ''when fund managers make purely valuation-motivated trades, they beat the market by a substantial margin.''

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: Then there are the trades that are intended primarily to meet redemption requests or to put new cash to work in the market.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The professors assume that ''liquidity-motivated buys'' are those that occur when there is a large inflow of new cash, while ''liquidity-motivated sells'' occur amid a large number of redemption requests.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: They acknowledge that some of these trades may be motivated by considerations other than liquidity.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: But, they say, the average trade in their liquidity-motivated categories is less likely than that of the valuation-motivated groups to be a pure reflection of managers' beliefs about a stock's potential.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The professors built two portfolios of stocks in these liquidity-motivated categories, one for the buys and one for the sells.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The relative performance of the two liquidity portfolios was nearly opposite that of the valuation-motivated versions, with the buys now lagging the market and the sells outperforming it.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: In fact, the liquidity-motivated sells outperformed the buys by two percentage points a year, on average.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: In other words, the transactions that managers must make to meet liquidity needs eliminate much of the profit from trades made for valuation reasons.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: Transaction costs, which were not included in the calculations, coupled with management fees, eliminate the rest of that profit for the average fund.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The professors interpret their findings to mean that mutual fund investors pay a high price for the chance to invest or withdraw money at any time.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: And the cost is borne by all investors, whether or not they take advantage of the opportunity.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: The investment implication is clear: don't pay for liquidity unless you need daily access to your money.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: Are closed-end funds the preferred alternative for long-term investors?

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: It might appear that way.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: After all, the amount of assets under management at closed-end funds doesn't change when investors buy or sell shares, because the number of shares outstanding is fixed.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: This means the managers of closed-end funds are immune from rapid inflows and outflows of cash.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: But Professor Gibson said in an interview that he did not think closed-end funds were the way to go.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: Because the funds' assets under management don't change even when performance is awful, the closed-end fund industry ''helps entrench poor-performing managers,'' he said.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: And because these funds won't receive new money even when performance is spectacular, he said, they tend to ''turn away the best managers who want to grow asset-based fees.''

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: Because of those considerations, Professor Gibson says he instead favors open-end mutual funds that significantly restrict short-term trades.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: Such funds, he says, are more likely than closed-end funds to attract better managers and offer a powerful incentive for them to beat the market.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: And because of the restrictions on short-term trades, long-term investors don't subsidize the liquidity needs of the short-term traders.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: Professor Gibson says he particularly likes funds that charge redemption fees on short-term trades, especially when the fees go back into the fund.

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: It's easy to see why short-term traders don't like these fees, he said, but ''if you're a long-term investor, they are your best friend.''

column2: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
column3: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT: STRATEGIES Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of MarketWatch.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: Every day the line snakes down a spartan corridor on the eighth floor of City Hall here, as hundreds of people clutch a piece of paper inscribed with a fateful percentage that could force them to abandon their home.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: The number is always over 50, and it means a house was so damaged in the flooding after Hurricane Katrina -- more than half-ruined -- that it faces demolition, unless the owner can come up with tens of thousands of dollars to raise it several feet above the ground and any future floodwaters.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: But there is a way out, and that is why so many people stand in line every day, collectively transforming this battered city.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''What you need to do is talk to a building inspector and get that lowered below 50 percent,'' a city worker calls out to the crowd.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: And at the end of the line, in a large open room down the hall, that is exactly what happens, nearly 90 percent of the time, New Orleans officials say.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: By agreeing so often to these appeals -- more than 6,000 over the last few months -- city officials are in essence allowing random redevelopment to occur throughout the city, undermining a plan by Mayor C. Ray Nagin's rebuilding commission to hold off on building permits in damaged areas for several months until more careful planning can take place.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: That plan, greeted by widespread opposition, including from the mayor himself, is now essentially dead.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: House by house, in devastated neighborhoods across the city, homeowners are bringing back their new-minted building permits and rebuilding New Orleans.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: As many as 500 such permits are issued every day, said Greg Meffert, the city official in charge of the rebuilding process.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: And there is no particular rhyme or reason to who gets a permit, or consideration of whether their neighborhoods can really support its previous residents.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: One city building inspector, Devra Goldstein, called the proceedings on the eighth floor ''really fly-by-night, chaotic, Wild West, get-what-you-want.''

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: The floor, she said, represents ''a plan by default.''

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: It is also testament to the fierce desire of many displaced New Orleanians to re-establish themselves, no matter the odds.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''They told us, if things look close, chances are we can get the assessment lowered below 50 percent, and we can start rebuilding,'' said George Aguillard, a 65-year-old retired longshoreman waiting patiently in the largely African-American crowd at City Hall.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''At my age, there's no starting over in a new house,'' said Mr. Aguillard, a resident of the flooded Pontchartrain Park neighborhood.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: His damage assessment came in at 52.13 percent.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: But there may be a steep price to the city's largess in allowing so many people to move back into flood plains without having to elevate their homes.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: Past federal flood insurance directors say the practice violates the program, which established the 50-percent rule to guide safe building in flood-prone areas.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: Most communities have adopted it as a minimum standard, say officials of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which runs the flood program.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: In exchange for heavily-subsidized flood insurance for residents, the program expects cities to insist on flood-resistant construction.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: Some cities that violate the flood rules have been ousted from the insurance program, putting thousands of residents at huge risk.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''They should be suspended, absolutely,'' said J. Robert Hunter, a former head of the federal flood-insurance program who is now director of insurance at the Consumer Federation of America.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''You can't fake it,'' he said.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''I sympathize with these people.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: But you shouldn't say 'Well, you're poor, therefore you can build in a dangerous place where you can be flooded again, and killed.'

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: He added, ''You can't destroy the flood program to achieve a short-term goal.''

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: Another early director of federal flood insurance, George K. Bernstein, was equally critical, saying the practice of reducing flood damage percentages was ''just ripping off taxpayers.''

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''If New Orleans is phonying the damage reports so as to allow inadequate construction, they ought to get thrown out of the program,'' he said.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: But up on the eighth floor, the downward revisions are over in a matter of minutes.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''It was pretty smooth,'' said Charles Harris, an Orleans Parish sheriff's deputy who had four feet of water in his eastern New Orleans home, and whose percentage of damage was changed to 47 from 52.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''They were really helpful.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: I thought it was going to be a combative thing.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: I was ready to put on my shield.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: It wasn't like that at all.''

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: Kevin François, an air-conditioning repairman with a house that was rated as 52 percent damaged, said, ''It was basically an in-and-out process.''

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: He, left City Hall with a number several points less than 50.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: Homeowners have to justify any changes to their damage assessments, he said, and must provide the details of their rebuilding plans.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''What's swinging the vote is, 'I'm going to do it this way,' '' he said.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: But some leaving City Hall here are still in a pugnacious mood, despite the friendly reception.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''I didn't give them a chance,'' Florestine Jalvia said proudly, having brought her assessment down to 47 percent damaged from 52.5 percent.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''I think the city is trying to avoid a major public fight,'' said Ms. Goldstein, the building inspector.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: Out in the once-flooded neighborhoods, there is feverish activity, at intervals.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: Those hard at work scoff at the commission's idea of holding off on rebuilding until it becomes clearer which areas have a chance of coming back.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: ''I'm not listening to that, man,'' said Kristopher Winder, as he finished gutting his mother's house in the Gentilly neighborhood.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: He had brought it back down to its frame.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time

column3: ''I was mad.

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time
column3: I thought it didn't make no sense.''

column2: Rebuilding New Orleans, One Appeal at a Time

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: China's central bank said late Friday that it had raised the reserve requirement ratio for banks, the fourth increase in six months, to further tighten the nation's money supply.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: The modest move, which takes effect this month, increases the reserve ratio by half a percentage point, to 9.5 percent.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Analysts said it was the government's latest warning that too much money in the financial system could ignite inflation and perhaps fuel a stock market bubble.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: ''This is a warning shot,'' said Dong Tao, the chief economist for non-Japan Asia at Credit Suisse.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: ''If the stock market continues to go up, we might see further tightening.''

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Raising the amount of cash reserves that Chinese banks keep on hand with the central bank effectively restricts the amount of money that banks can lend.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: While not being very restrictive, the central bank aims to curb excessive lending to new factories, real estate projects and road construction.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: The move also comes as China's stock market is booming after several years in the doldrums.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Last year, the country's key index -- the Shanghai exchange -- rose 130 percent to close at 2,675, a record and the best performance of any major stock exchange in the world in 2006.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: The market reached a 16-year high in December, as millions of investors who had been sitting on the sidelines in 2004 and 2005 jumped back into stocks.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Analysts say the government is determined to keep the economy expanding but is concerned about growing so quickly that the economy might crash before 2008, when Beijing is host to the Olympic Games, viewed as the ultimate coming-out party for China.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Overinvestment in real estate and construction has been among the chief worries for the government.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: And for much of the last two years there have been frequent warnings and government measures to tame a wild property run.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: The Central Bank said that last October, for the first time in five years, the bank savings of Chinese citizens decreased from the month before, presumably as more money went into the stock market.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Credit Suisse estimated that more than $30 billion in bank deposits have flowed into mutual funds or direct plays into the stock market over the last six weeks.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Many analysts say now that the bull run will continue in 2007, prompting even more money to flow into the market.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: One Chinese mutual fund raised $5 billion in a single day recently before closing its doors to new investors, an astonishing achievement here, according to some economists.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, which was publicly listed only last October, here in Shanghai and in Hong Kong, has already gained over 70 percent.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: This week, prices shot up again, before falling sharply Friday.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: The run-up means companies in China can once again raise money in the Chinese market rather than relying on the Hong Kong stock market.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: But huge risks remain in a market that many analysts have long derided as a gambling den crowded with companies with suspect accounting.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Several economists say that more increases are expected in the coming months, to tame the economy and the stock market.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Hong Liang, a Hong Kong-based economist at Goldman Sachs, said that the government had used the reserve ratio as a policy tool to help manage the economy but that it had not been very effective in cooling things down.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: She did not ''expect it to have much impact on the real economy or the financial markets.''

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: Large amounts of money flow into the country through foreign investments and surplus dollars from trade.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: China also has a high savings rate.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
column3: So many people are looking to put that money to work -- in real estate, the stock market and even by investing in art and antiques.

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply

column2: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply

column2: WITH TAKEOVER BID, SIMON AIMS TO CONTROL 30 PERCENT OF U.S. MALLS

column2: WITH TAKEOVER BID, SIMON AIMS TO CONTROL 30 PERCENT OF U.S. MALLS

column2: WITH TAKEOVER BID, SIMON AIMS TO CONTROL 30 PERCENT OF U.S. MALLS

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: The execution of Saddam Hussein was initially hailed as an example of democratic justice being served in Iraq, but leading members of Congress said Thursday that the conduct surrounding the hanging could undermine United States strategy in Iraq and complicate efforts to help the new Iraqi government succeed.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: The White House has declined to criticize the execution, portions of which were shown online in a bootlegged video.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: Several Republican senators who have been among President Bush's biggest supporters in the Iraq war said they were troubled by the video and fearful of the reverberations it could provoke.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: ''It's a very bad thing, it's harmful, and I'm sorry that it happened,'' said Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican who has been a White House ally on its Iraq policy.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: ''Obviously, it unnecessarily inflames the emotions of the Sunnis.''

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: While the White House says that Mr. Bush has not seen the video -- recorded without authorization with a cellphone camera -- several members of Congress said that they had seen it.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: More important, they said, the rest of the world had, too.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: As Mr. Bush inches closer to presenting his revised Iraq plan, Republican and Democratic lawmakers expressed dismay at the scene surrounding the final minutes of Mr. Hussein's life.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: They said it was another sign of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki's inability to deal with the sectarian divide in Iraq.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: ''It is a very unfortunate episode, and they are still trying to sort out accountability,'' said Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: ''The key to success in Iraq -- whatever success we are able to achieve -- is reconciliation, and this certainly was not a helpful chapter in that.''

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: Whether the execution ultimately has political repercussions beyond Iraq and here in the United States remains an open question.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: But as senators prepared to be called to the White House as early as Friday for briefings about the president's Iraq plan, the video emerged as a new complication.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: In the video, Mr. Hussein was shown standing with the noose around his neck at dawn last Saturday in Baghdad, facing a barrage of mockery and derision from unseen tormentors.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: The images showed Mr. Hussein amid shouts of ''Go to hell!''

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: and ''Moktada!

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: Moktada!

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: Moktada!''

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: in reference to a radical Shiite cleric, Moktada al-Sadr.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: Speaking at the White House after a meeting with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Thursday, Mr. Bush said he had wished the execution had ''been done in a more dignified way.''

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: He said he appreciated that Mr. Maliki was investigating the way the execution was handled, but that he did not dwell on it during their video conference on Thursday.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: Mr. Bush said Mr. Hussein had received a fair trial, the likes of which his enemies had not.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: ''He was given justice; the thousands of people he killed were not,'' Mr. Bush said.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: Senator Susan M. Collins, a Maine Republican, said she was troubled by the swiftness of the execution, adding that ''taunting someone who is about to be executed is just blatantly unacceptable.''

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: The images contained in the video would almost certainly inflame sectarian tensions throughout the region, she said.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: ''I have no grief for Saddam Hussein, but it makes it more difficult for Iraqi leaders to forge the political solution that I think is necessary to quell the violence,'' Ms. Collins said.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: ''It threatens the very existence of the nation and thousands of Americans and Iraqi lives to have Saddam mocked before his execution.''

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: It was unclear whether the newly ascendant Democrats in Congress planned to make an issue of the handling of the execution.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
column3: It is not likely to be a part of promised Senate hearings on President Bush's Iraq policy, according to aides in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes

column2: Lawmakers Criticize Video of Hussein’s Final Minutes
